PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr ACTING SPEAKER (Mr Leo McLeay) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.PRESENTERS: ALDRED; ANDREW; BEALE; BEAZLEY; BROWN; BURR; CAMERON; CAMERON; CHARLES; CHARLESWORTH; COHEN; CRAWFORD; CROSS; EDWARDS; FATIN; FITZGIBBON; HOWARD; KERR; LINDSAY; LLOYD; MACKELLAR; MILDREN; MILLAR; MOUNTFORD; PORTER; PRATT; ROCHER; SCOTT; SCOTT; SHACK; SIMMONS; SINCLAIR; SNOW; SPENDER; SULLIVAN; WHITE

PETITION.TITLE: `Authority Required' Prescriptions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens showeth:

that your petitioners deplore the Federal Government's decision to remove 53 Pharmaceutical drugs from the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme including the best available for the treatment of high blood pressure, cancer, epilepsy, high cholesterol and uneven heartbeat-and place them for cost saving reasons only on a special list requiring Authority from a Canberra bureaucrat, and;

that we believe a patient's doctor is clearly the best judge for medication needed for their particular illness and that it is therefore wrong and unfair to force that doctor to seek permission from a bureaucrat in Canberra who has no personal knowledge of that case.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will call on the Government to immediately abandon the proposal and keep its election promise of high quality and universal health care for all Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Aldred (from 81 citizens), Mr Andrew (from 230 citizens), Mr Beale (from three citizens), Mr Beazley (from 54 citizens), Mr Robert Brown (from 81 citizens), Mr Burr (from 120 citizens), Mr Donald Cameron (from 196 citizens), Mr Ian Cameron (from 83 citizens), Mr Charles (from 83 citizens), Dr Charlesworth (from 81 citizens), Mr Cohen (from 27 citizens), Ms Crawford (from 71 citizens), Mr Cross (from 27 citizens), Dr Harry Edwards (from 51 citizens), Ms Fatin (from 135 citizens), Mr Fitzgibbon (from 107 citizens), Mr Howard (from 28 citizens), Mr Kerr (from 72 citizens), Mr Lindsay (from 54 citizens), Mr Lloyd (from 27 citizens), Mr MacKellar (from 49 citizens), Mr Mildren (from five citizens), Mr Millar (from 271 citizens), Mr Mountford (from 334 citizens), Mr Porter (from 25 citizens), Mr Pratt (from 350 citizens), Mr Rocher (from 61 citizens), Mr John Scott (from 13 citizens), Mr Les Scott (from 81 citizens), Mr Shack (from 66 citizens), Mr Simmons (from 194 citizens), Mr Sinclair (from 27 citizens), Mr Snow (from 621 citizens), Mr Spender (from 24 citizens), Mrs Sullivan (from 54 citizens), Mr White (from 189 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: `Authority Required' Prescriptions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That whilst acknowledging the Government's desire to contain the growth in health costs, the introduction of 61 new drugs to the `Authority Required' listing will result in potentially serious delays in patients receiving medication prescribed by their doctors.
Your petitioners request the House to immediately reverse the Government's decision and withdraw these drugs from the `Authorities Required' list.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Charles (from 81 citizens), Mr Cobb (from 79 citizens), Mr Scholes (from 108 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Customs (Cinematograph Films) Regulations
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.
The petition of citizens of Australia points out to the House that the ACT Classification of Publications Ordinance 1983 has legalised the screening of blasphemy, indecency, and obscenity.
Because Parliament has traditionally respected the beliefs of its people, your petitioners therefore request that the House:
1. retain section 13 of the Customs (Cinematograph Films) Regulations as is;
2. control all censorship criteria and guidelines by substantive legislation;

3. give earnest consideration to these matters, in order that no Attorney-General shall ever again have the power to change our social and home environment for generations to come, without full and thorough debate in both Houses of Parliament.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Dr Charlesworth (from 44 citizens), Mr Courtice (from 11 citizens) and Mr Shack (from 124 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Customs (Cinematograph Films) Regulations
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.
The petition of citizens of Australia points out to the House that the ACT Classification of Publications Ordinance 1983 has:
degraded men;
lowered the status of women;
affected the safety of children; and
escalated crime including sexual crime.
Because the Parliament has a role to play in the well-being of the people of this Nation, your petitioners therefore request that the House:
1. not adopt a Non-Violent Erotica (NVE) Video classification;
2. not permit NVE in cinemas;
3. retain section 13 of the Customs (Cinematograph Films) Regulations as it is;
4. control all Censorship criteria by substantive legislation; and

5. give earnest consideration to these matters, in order that no Attorney General shall ever again have the power to change our social and home environment for generations to come, without thorough and full debate in both Houses of Parliament.

PETITION.TITLE: Pension Entitlements
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned shows:

We are gravely concerned at the Government's proposal to reduce significantly the pension and access to fringe benefits to persons who in good faith bought market linked insurance bonds, friendly society bonds, approved deposit funds, deferred annuities and unit trusts to protect their savings.

Your petitioners request that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, amend the proposed legislation to ensure that it will not apply retrospectively and that provision is made to protect savings against inflation.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cowan (from 20 citizens), Mr Lloyd (from 51 citizens) and Mr Pratt (from 20 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Government Statistical Surveys
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that the surveys of the Australian Bureau of Statistics represent:
1. an unnecessary demand on the time of certain Australians;
2. an intrusion in to the private affairs of individuals and families; and
3. excessive penalties for non-compliance.

Your petitioners therefore request that the House take action to pass legislation making government statistical surveys voluntary and to ensure the protection of the privacy of Australians from government departments and authorities.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Andrew (from 122 citizens) and Mr Rocher (from six citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Crime and Violence on Television
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that there is too much crime and violence on Television and this is breaking down the standards and codes of behaviour in our society.

Your petitioners therefore ask the House to call on the Federal Government to require Television Stations to improve the standards of shows, news and current affairs programmes by reducing the incidence of crime and violence broadcast every day into people's homes.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Burr (from 105 citizens) and Mrs Sullivan (from 1,131 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Spastic Welfare Association of Western Australia (Incorporated)
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia within Western Australia shows:
That the management of the affairs of the Spastic Welfare Association of Western Australia Incorporated is a matter of grave concern for the following reasons:
(a) The active involvement beyond normal duties of senior members of the staff in the organisation of a Special General Meeting to remove certain Board Members from the Board of Directors.

(b) The subsequent appointment of replacement Board Members, the expulsion of a Member of the Association and the actions taken to reverse the positive moves made to bring the Association into line with the Government's `New Directions' policy for disabled persons.
(c) The financial management of the Association, in that the needs of the disabled Members of the Association are treated as of secondary importance.

Your petitioners therefore pray that an Independent Enquiry be appointed to investigate and report on the Administrative and Financial Management of the Spastic Welfare Association of Western Australia (Incorporated).

PETITION.TITLE: Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament Assembled.

The Petition of citizens of Botany Municipality and surrounds. Respectfully showeth our concerns about possible changes relating to the Kingsford-Smith Airport, which will seriously affect our lifestyles in regard to noise pollution, road traffic and safety.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House allow: no lifting or decreasing of curfew hours, no additional runways at Kingsford- Smith Airport, no increase of size of semitrailers servicing the airport, work on a second airport to commence immediately.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom Charges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia wish to express their absolute opposition to the Privatisation and Deregulation of the Australian Telecommunications Industry. Your petitioners humbly pray that the House will take the necessary steps to ensure:-
That Telecom's social responsibilities are preserved and extended and adequately funded.
That the telephone service is accessible and affordable to all.
The maintenance of public ownership and control of telecommunications services in Australia.

That Telecom consumer's rights are respected by the establishment of mechanisms whereby their grievances can be adequately represented. Especially domestic, small business and socially disadvantaged people within the community.
Also, your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament will reject current proposals to:-
Impose State and Local charges and taxes on Telecom.
Alter the legal status, employment conditions and organisation of Telecom from a public sector service provider to a commercial corporation.
Take away Telecom's regulatory function and place this with a new body called Austel.
Remove Telecom's ``Buy Australia'' policy, thus threatening local manufacturing.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, your humble petitioners showeth:
1. The proposed Australia Card will have a dramatic impact on the lives of all Australians.
2. Therefore your petitioners request a national referendum on the Australia Card Bill before the proposal is resubmitted to Parliament.
As in duty bound your petitioners will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Road Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Indi electorate respectfully showeth that:
Australians living in rural and non-urban areas rely to a great degree on the local road network for all facets of their lives.
Funding for roads is an essential part of the Commonwealth's responsibilities for the maintenance of the transport infrastructure.
Road funding under the Hawke Government has decreased significantly in real terms and local government is particularly disadvantaged by this decline.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled urge the Government to:

Immediately address the serious problem of a rapidly deteriorating road network which is confronting local government by allocating more resources, along with State Governments, to local road funding.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Disability Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully shows that we are concerned with the implementation and interpretation of the Disability Services Act 1986.
We therefore humbly request that Parliament takes necessary action to:
(1) Halt implementation of the Act until 1 July, 1989.

(2) Ensure that prior to 1 July, 1989, formal agreement be reached by the Department of Community Services and Health and appropriate Peak Councils on eligible services, including definition of services and identification of client groups.
(3) Ensure that prior to 1 July, 1989, formal agreement be reached by the Department of Community Services and Health and appropriate Peak Councils on funding formulae for eligible services.
(4) In the interim, funding to services approved under the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act 1974 continue to apply to staff salaries, equipment and maintenance items.

PETITION.TITLE: X and R-Rated Video Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned:

Note that a majority of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material has strongly opposed the proposition that a new NVE category will contain that material as defined in the current `X' classification.

Call upon the House of Representatives to request the Government immediately to implement the recommendation of the majority of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material by introducing substantive legislation to ensure that X-rated video material (and its R-rated equivalent) is refused classification for the purpose of Commonwealth laws.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Identification Numbering System
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The Hawke Labor Government's ID card proposal is the most far reaching and intrusive piece of Australian legislation ever, and that on all the evidence available will not tackle in the most cost-efficient and effective manner tax and social security fraud.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Reject Labor's ID card proposal to prevent a gross waste of taxpayers' money and a significant infringement on civil liberties.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Immigration
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
The subject of Immigration is of deep concern, and supports the following significant community views placed before the FitzGerald Committee on Immigration:
(1) That Asians accounting for 40% of the total migrant intake is viewed with considerable concern by the Australian people;

(2) The Anglo-Australian sense of superiority of their culture previously manifest in the policy of assimilation remains a significant factor in the community and should be taken into account as the wishes of the people on this important matter;
(3) It is a matter of concern that 43% of one million of those residentially qualified migrants to take out citizenship have not done so;

(4) It is a major recommendation that the Federal Government consult the Australian people by Referendum on the subject of Asian immigration, and then affirm its commitment to the immigration policies which conform to the general wishes of the majority of the people, and should be recognised by the Government as such.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, urge the Parliament to: Protect our National Identity, and preserve the Australian way of life.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives, in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that there is widespread concern by farmers and consumers about the proposal to irradiate food in Australia. Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, should:
(1) block the introduction of food irradiation into Australia;
(2) ban the import of Cobalt-60 and Caesium-137 and Caesium-134 to be used to irradiate food products;
(3) ban the import of all machinery used for food irradiation (electron beam, X-ray etc.);
(4) ban the importation and sale of irradiated food in Australia;
and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth: We most strongly oppose the process of Food Irradiation by radioactive Cobalt-60 or any other radioactive substance.

We oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process by State Governments. We express our deep concern at this attempt to extend the use of radioactive substances and exposure of workers to irradiation.

We call on the House to immediately ban the importation of radioactive Cobalt-60 or other radioactive substances and to immediately disallow the regulations that permit the irradiation of food here in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Fishing Agreement with the Soviet Union
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully draws to the attention of the House:
that the activities of the Soviet Union in our region and in particular the South Pacific are detrimental to and threaten the security of our country.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House:
urge the Government not to enter into a fishing agreement with the Soviet Union.

PETITION.TITLE: Romania: Human Rights
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives of the Parliament of Australia assembled. We the undersigned, are appalled that the Rumanian Government plans the commencement of the destruction in September of 7,000 villages, hundreds of thousands of peaceful homes and homesteads, thousands of churches, historic monuments and cemeteries. With this barbaric action millions of people will be disadvantaged, even sent to their death with these totalitarian actions.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give these matters earnest consideration and request the Rumanian Government to abandon these horrific acts against the Rumanian community and its minorities.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Importation of Radioactive Substances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That we most strongly oppose the process of `food irradiation' by Cobalt-60, caesium-137, caesium-134 or any machine sources.
That we oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process being permitted in Australia.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Federal Parliament ban the importation of any radioactive substances or machinery for the purposes of food irradiation, disallow regulations permitting the irradiation of food in this country, and ban the irradiation of food in this country, and also ban the importation of food treated by irradiation.

We also call upon the parliament to advise the Federal Government to withdraw from the Asian Regional Co-operative Project on Food Irradiation and the International Consultative Group on Food Irradiation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Arbitration Inspectorate: Australian Capital Territory Office
PETITION.PARA: The humble petition of citizens of the Australian Capital Territory and surrounding districts respectfully showeth-
1. The Arbitration inspectorate is established to secure the enforcement of awards and agreements of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.

2. Without this inspection service many employees, particularly those who are young or not members of trade unions would have no adequate means of securing their legal entitlements to award wages and conditions. Employers who are not members of employer organisations would have inadequate information as to their obligations to their employees.
3. Any reduction in the staff numbers of the ACT office of the inspectorate or the erosion of its independence would:
(a) severely curtail the activities of this office, especially the provision of advice and information on awards and employment conditions by the inspectors; and
(b) leave the ACT inadequately serviced particularly as the Territory moves towards self-government.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that:
1. No reduction be made to staff numbers in the ACT office of the Arbitration inspectorate.
2. All available positions for inspectors be filled.
3. The ACT office be an independent Regional Office of the Department of Industrial Relations headed by an officer of the level of Chief Inspector as is currently the case.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Buddhist Leaders: Imposed Death Sentences
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House.
That the Australian Parliament expresses its repugnance that the Socialist Republic of Vietnam has kept imprisoned, 47 Buddhist leaders since 1984.

And further, that the regime in Vietnam has recently tried and sentenced to death: Thich Tri Sieu and Thich Tue Sy, two distinguished scholars from amongst the 47. Both of these religious academics are intellectuals of the higher order, being scholars in Buddhist Scripture.

Your petitioners therefore request the House to denounce the intentions of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam and to call on the Vietnamese Government for clemency and a remission of the death sentence as being barbaric.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Government Analytical Laboratories
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of Parliament assembled, the undersigned citizens, respectfully showeth:

1. That we are extremely concerned over the discovery of the bacteria Listeria Monocytogenes in imported cheese found in Australia. The bacteria has been identified with deaths in America and Switzerland and can cause abortion in pregnant women, meningitis and perinatal septicaemia in newborn infants.
2. That the work of the Australian Government Analytical Laboratories in sample testing and analysis of food products has been severely reduced due to ill considered budget cutbacks.

3. That the Public interest function of A.G.A.L. have been put in jeopardy through these budget cutbacks and through a failure to establish a compulsory programme of regular testing of both imported and domestic food products.
Your petitioners therefore call on the House to-
(a) Give the highest priority to establishing the Public interest functions of the Australian Government Analytical Laboratories.
(b) Require the Departments of Primary Industry and Energy and Health to put in place a regular compulsory programme of analysis and testing of food products, both imported and domestic.
(c) Require that such testing be conducted through the Australian Government Analytical Laboratories.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens in Australia, draws to the attention of the House that the irradiation of food by any means degrades the nutritional value of food and is potentially harmful to the health of all consumers and to the environment.
Your petitioners therefore request that your honourable House:
1. Withdraw from the Asian Regional Co-operative Project on Food Irradiation and from the International Consultative Group on Food Irradiation.
2. Take all possible steps to prevent and disallow the irradiation of food in Australia.
3. Ban the export and importation of irradiated foods and animal feeds.
4. Take steps to obtain a testing device to make possible the identification of irradiated foods, as soon as one becomes available.

PETITION.TITLE: Foreign Longline Fishermen in Australian Waters
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth that:
The following Amateur Recreational Fishermen and Women and others formally make a strong protest against the activities of the Foreign Longliners in Australian waters.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Closely monitor the activities of these foreign longliners so that the Australian fishing industry is in no way affected by their presence.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare Facility: Runaway Bay and Helensvale Districts, Queensland
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of certain electors of the Division of Moncrieff draws to the attention of the House the absence of a Medicare facility in the Runaway Bay and Helensvale districts.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House urgently look into establishing a Medicare facility as soon as is possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blanchard Mr C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs I present the interim report of the Committee entitled The Effectiveness of the Support Services for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Island Communities, together with the minutes of the proceedings and evidence received by the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to present to the House the interim report of the Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs on the effectiveness of support services for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities. The report reports on progress the Committee had made so far in the inquiry. In part the report is about the need seen by the Committee for a change in direction in the inquiry but it also points to major problems identified in the effectiveness of support services. The inquiry's terms of reference were very broad and this has created difficulties for the Committee in dealing in detail with the wide range of issues that have been raised. The Committee has therefore decided to divide its reference into four areas that will be dealt with progressively and reported on separately. The report expands on the reasons for this change of direction and the four areas of the future inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: While the breadth of the terms of reference has been a problem, it has also been salutary for the Committee. It has demonstrated the depth of basic needs that still remain in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities. Addressing these basic needs is not directly a matter for the Committee under its terms of reference but it is one that I highlight now to the House and suggest the importance of continued Government action to meet these needs. The report discusses the context of service delivery to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities. It concludes that the process of service delivery has become complex with the involvement of a large number of players at all levels of government. The often identified problem of lack of coordination and cooperation in the policies espoused by differing levels of government and in the funding of programs continues to be a major area of concern. The Committee will address ways of improving the situation in its future areas of inquiry.

Aboriginal policies are expressed by all governments as involving Aboriginal self-determination and self-management. However, it is evident that Aboriginal people have not been given the control for the services provided to them that would be commensurate with these policies. Far from communities being in control of services provided, the services are often imposed, and are not meeting the urgent needs of communities. Catering to Aboriginal needs in the areas of support services and giving Aboriginal people effective control is not easy. Certainly a greater coordination between government and other agencies and a greater degree of cooperation with those Aboriginal organisations involved in providing services will assist.

But attention must also be paid to the authority and management capacity of the Aboriginal community organisations which are the mechanisms for providing support services. The structures through which Aboriginal people run their communities have largely been imposed. Often they do not fit well with traditional values and culture while also lacking status and recognition within non-Aboriginal institutions of government. Aboriginal people need a much greater say in these structures so that they are more compatible with Aboriginal values and are more representative as organisations.

Aboriginal community organisations are also often poorly resourced in both financial and human terms. As a generalisation, the quality of staff involved in Aboriginal community organisations is inadequate. Commitment is often evident, but professionalism is less so. But I would like to add that there are many people involved in this area who are very dedicated and work very effectively.

Education and training for community management assume great importance. In particular, efforts to train and recruit Aboriginal people to the management and administrative positions in their own communities and organisations are of prime importance. To date the efforts in this direction have been inadequate and irrelevant. The issues I have just outlined summarise the Committee's findings. These will be matters that will be pursued in future inquiries on this reference. I hope to be able to report to the House next year with positive recommendations to address the problems I have outlined above.

Before I close, I wish to pay tribute to my fellow members of the Committee, who have worked very harmoniously. It is one of those rare committees representative of all parties where the members speak freely and frankly, but at the end there is a degree of unanimity about what we want to do and what we would like to see done. In particular, I pay tribute to the Deputy Chairman, Mr Chris Miles, who unfortunately could not be here today, and to the other members of the Committee, including Mr Andrews, who was on the Committee at the time this report was prepared, Mr Ian Cameron, Mr Campbell, Mr Connolly, Mr Cross, Mr Gayler, Mr Snowdon and Mr Tickner. I would also like to pay tribute to the secretariat and in particular to the Secretary to the Committee, Mr David Elder, who is in the House today, and also to the staff-Peter Stephens, Wynne Allen, Clare Brien and Peter Ratos. As I said earlier, this Committee has worked well together. We look forward to presenting a fuller report to this House in the near future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr I.M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: -On behalf of the shadow Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles), who unfortunately is not with us today but is lucky enough to be in America, I second the interim report, The Effectiveness of the Support Services for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Island Communities. On behalf of the Opposition members on the Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs, I thank the staff very much. I point out that Mrs Wynne Allen is of Aboriginal descent. It is very good to have attached to the Committee somebody who really knows what she is talking about when it comes to the problems of Aborigines.

SPEECH.PARA: The members of the Committee come from a wide spectrum of Australia. That is very important. The honourable member for Moore (Mr Blanchard), our Chairman, is from Western Australia; the shadow Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, the honourable member for Braddon, is from Tasmania; the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) is from South Australia; I am from Queensland; the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) is from Western Australia; the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) is from Sydney; the honourable member for Brisbane (Mr Cross) is from Queensland; the honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Gayler) represents the Torres Strait islands and the north Queensland area, where there are many Aboriginal communities; the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon) has plenty of Aborigines in his electorate and has his hands full. He worked for the Central Land Council before becoming a member of parliament, so he obviously brings many skills to the Committee. The Committee also includes the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner) from Sydney. He takes an urban type of interest in Aborigines but he puts on a haversack and a bush hat when he goes out into the bush and I think the Aborigines eventually accept him. The honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster) has recently joined the Committee and he will obviously add his expertise.

This inquiry was started some 18 months ago after we had an inquiry into the homelands lasting 18 months. After those trips we felt that the greatest need for Aboriginal people was properly trained advisers. Although Aborigines in rural Australia-we have to differentiate between urban Aborigines, who tend to group into a suburb, and rural Aborigines, who tend to group into communities-have self-management in most of their communities, not all of them have the skills to manage their communities properly. Many Europeans are still employed by the Aborigines because they feel that they need the skills that Europeans have to offer them. It was felt that many of these people were not adequately trained to carry out their tasks. I would go as far as to say that many Aborigines are better trained than some of the European advisers that I have run into in some of these communities. We decided to look at how effective these people were.

Obviously, with the Aborigines themselves taking on more responsibilities, we also felt that they lacked training. Unfortunately, they live out in the bush and many of them have not had what we would term a proper education. They have obviously had a good education in bush ways; they are able to make fire with a couple of sticks and do all sorts of things that we cannot do. In some ways they are much better educated than we are.

We always look at Aboriginal problems through European eyes, which is probably a bit of a pity. It is difficult for us to look at their problem through Aboriginal eyes. We go about our task very quietly, as we should. As a Committee we have been very effective in bringing about changes and helping the Government and the Ministry. Although we report to the Parliament, the relevant Minister receives the report and is meant to act on the suggestions that we put forward. Since 1980, when I became associated with the Standing Committee, we have seen some good changes within the Aboriginal communities throughout Australia. Nevertheless, once again, we are presently seeing all sorts of ructions.

No doubt, when spending the amount of money available to this group of Australians-$800m or $900m-there is some waste. That does not apply only to Aborigines: we ought to understand that there is an awful lot of waste in any area of government expenditure. Telecom Australia is always a classic example, and I am going to speak about Telecom at lunchtime in the grievance debate. We have only to look at the way it operates. The number of trucks it needs to put down one post hole is pretty staggering. Obviously there is always room for improvement. We can never have sufficient education and we can never be well enough trained. The job of this Committee is to look at and recommend to the Government how we can effectively improve the training of these people.

We found that the Committee's inquiry was too broad and we more or less had to call the meetings to a halt and put in an interim report and relook at where we were going. The Aborigines in these communities all have needs, as we do, and when we went there they poured out to us everything they needed, from swimming pools to gardens, from trucks to Toyotas-you name it. We felt we were being inundated by requests and that we had to get back to our particular brief, which was to look at training. There are a lot of good training programs in place, particularly those associated with the local government area. We have decided that the future direction the inquiry will take will be to look at the community management of Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders. I think the House should understand that the Torres Strait Islanders are a separate and different community. We are intending to go back to the Torres Strait to look at the Islanders' problems.

I have already said that the education and training of community administrators is very important. There is a whole shaft of government advisory services, at both the Commonwealth and State levels. They number hundreds. This is totally confusing to these people who have never had to deal with so many public servants at once. I think Toomelah is a good example. I think about 23 different departments had to decide whether they would bituminise a road there. Consequently the roads never get bituminised because no-one wants to make a decision and one passes the problem on to the other. We feel there is room for improvement in streamlining the services given to these Australians.

My final point is fairly close to my area of interest, and that is local government. I believe that in Queensland in particular, the State Government, my National Party Government, always gets buckets tipped on it for what it does not do, but I can assure honourable members that the Queensland Aborigines--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House notes with profound regret the financial crisis in the UN due principally to the arrears of the USA, and also the threat to the effectiveness of the World Bank posed by the failure of the US to ratify the General Capital Increase, and calls on the US Administration and Congress to swiftly authorise in full payment due to both the UN and the World Bank.

The United Nations (UN) is going through a renaissance, at least in public recognition of the value of its work. UN mediation is centrally involved in defusing the conflicts between Iran and Iraq, in Afghanistan and in Angola. A UN military observer group is in place between the forces of Iran and Iraq to reinforce the cease-fire after their terrible eight-year war. A 50-member UN force, called the UN Good Offices Mission, in Afghanistan and Pakistan is observing the Soviet Union's withdrawal from Afghanistan, and an agreement between the opposing forces in Angola is leading to a cease-fire which is likely to involve a large UN peacekeeping force, perhaps 7,000 strong.

These three developments, all of which occurred about the middle of this year, have led some people to say that `peace is breaking out all over'. It would be fine if that were true, but it is a rather optimistic over- simplification. Nevertheless, significant progress has been made in three of the most destructive contemporary conflicts and the United Nations has played a central role in the steps towards cease-fire or reduction in tension in each of those places. This has led to a sudden widespread improvement in public perceptions about the value of the mediating and peacekeeping work of the United Nations. It was one of the reasons for the award of the Nobel Peace Prize to the United Nations peacekeeping forces this year.

The United Nations peacekeeping forces began in November 1956 with the creation of the United Nations emergency force in the wake of the attack on the Suez Canal by Britain, France and Israel. Peacekeeping forces started on a shoestring and are still operating that way. Since the initial use of United Nations observer or peacekeeping forces, nearly half a million men and women have served and 733 have died. At present there are five peacekeeping forces in operation involving about 10,000 military personnel and 2,000 civilians in such places as Cyprus, the Indian-Pakistani border and the Lebanon. However, the existing peacekeeping forces are $US484m in arrears, of which nearly $US100m is owed by the United States. The biggest part of that debt, $US83m, is owed by Washington for its share of running the United Nations interim force in southern Lebanon, a unit of 5,800 troops from nine countries.

Those arrears in payments for peacekeeping are only one of many areas in which there are arrears by members to the various parts of the United Nations system. At the end of 1987, outstanding contributions to the United Nations general account totalled $US353m, of which the United States owed $US253m-well over two-thirds. It is true that many other countries, mostly developing countries, are in arrears too, but their contribution and arrears are small in proportion to the total United Nations budget. For many years it was the Soviet Union that was most in default in payments to the United Nations. But for the last two years the Russians have paid their annual general assessment in full and on time and have caught up on their arrears. The only other major debtor at present is South Africa, which owes the United Nations general account $US31m, which is nine years of its subscriptions.

Throughout 1988 the UN Secretary-General, Perez de Cuellar, has been warning that the United Nations might have to close its doors at the end of the year if US arrears are not paid. For example, on 15 June he said that `insolvent, the organisation will have to cease its operations and would be unable to meet its commitments to member states and to staff' unless US arrears are paid by October or November. Many governments have also been urging the US to catch up on its back payments.

The origin of the crisis is in the attitudes of the Reagan Administration to the UN system. The Reagan Administration has been sceptical and often hostile to the UN. The reason is simple: the US no longer controls the UN because of the large number of member countries, each of which has equal voting rights. Until the 1960s it was possible for the great powers to control enough votes to achieve their goals. Following the growth of the number of independent countries, this is no longer automatically possible.

In the early 1980s many countries began, quite properly, to urge greater cost effectiveness on the UN. There is no doubt that many parts of the organisation had become overblown and relatively inefficient. In 1985 the US said that it would withhold part of its dues until there had been progress with organisational reform. A reform plan was adopted by the General Assembly in 1986 which called for a 15 per cent reduction in staff as well as a thorough review of functions, working methods and policies. The Secretary-General reported in April this year on progress with reform. It is widely recognised that there has been very substantial progress towards the target of reducing staff by 15 per cent and reform in the functioning of all aspects of the UN secretariat in such areas as public information activities, conference servicing, administration and finance. Despite that progress, the US has fallen further behind in payment of its subscriptions. In July the New York Times published an editorial in which it praised the growing effectiveness of the United Nations not only in peacekeeping but also in the improved efficiency of its general operations. The editorial said:

Yet just as the United Nations achieves a new measure of significance, the United States assumes the dishonourable role once played by the Soviet Union; number one UN deadbeat. What started as a reasonable policy-withholding dues to spur badly needed reforms-has degenerated into a muddled breach of faith.
Further on it said:
A once reasonable policy has become nothing more than an evasion of responsibility, endangering the critical UN role in a number of peace efforts and diminishing the United States.

At the beginning of September the US owed the UN general budget $467m-out of a total budget of $800m. As well as that, the US owe substantial amounts to various specialised agencies. For example, it owed the Food and Agriculture Organisation $67m, which is over 135 per cent of its annual assessments.

In September, President Reagan announced that the US would remove part of its arrears by paying $44m of subscriptions overdue for 1987 and $88m for the first quarter of 1988-89. The Administration also announced that it would seek full funding from October next year and that a plan would be drawn up to repay the arrears over the following five to seven years. Clearly, that was a disappointing statement. It means that it will be five to seven years from October next year before the US will have caught up with overdue subscriptions to the UN and its specialised agencies. That means that at the end of the current US financial year, in October 1989, there will still be $279m owing to the UN general budget, $169m to affiliated agencies and $111m for peacekeeping forces. So although the motion we are now debating was placed on the Notice Paper in August and it appeared, when President Reagan announced that the US would be repaying its arrears, that the motion might be out of date, it is now quite clear that the motion remains relevant. The effect of the Reagan Administration's annual commitments would be that the US remains in arrears for another five to seven years.

The UN Secretary-General has called for all states to make payments in full and on time as required. That requirement should apply to every country-to the US no less than to every other state. The problem lies not only with the Administration but also with Congress. Delays have been caused by congressmen who have been critical of the UN and have retarded the passage of appropriations through the House and the Senate. That is why this motion urges both the Administration and the Congress to authorise prompt payment in full.

It is Congress which is presently delaying the approval of the first instalment of the general capital increase (GCI) to the World Bank. In February the executive directors of the bank unanimously recommended approval of a general capital increase of $US75 billion to the bank's governors. This brings the bank's total authorised capital to $US171 billion. Within two months, 77 per cent of shareholders had given support to the general capital increase, the US being the only major shareholder which had failed to give that support. This has not delayed introduction of the general capital increase, however, because only 75 per cent of voting support is required and governments have until September 1993 to complete their new capital subscriptions. As a result of the GCI, it will be possible to increase significantly the bank's sustainable level of lending and to achieve a nominal growth in lending of about 10 per cent a year over the next five to six years-that is, more than $20 billion annually by the early 1990s. It is therefore very important that the US also authorise participation in the general capital increase, yet Congress is delaying authorisation as a bargaining lever to force the Administration to take more effective action to deal with the Third World debt crisis.

While one can be entirely sympathetic with the concern about US Administration inaction and the ineffectiveness of policies so far for handling that crisis, it is counterproductive to use this mechanism to try to force that change of policy. Delaying the capital increase delays the capacity of the bank to increase lending-lending which is desperately needed by indebted developing countries.

This is not the moment to debate the effectiveness of the bank. Some of its policies can be justifiably criticised. The House will be debating the Australian contribution to the general capital increase shortly. For the present, the House should simply urge full US participation, in conjunction with the 142 other member countries which have already authorised their contributions to the general capital increase, so that the bank can continue to provide urgently needed funds for development projects in Third World countries.

The reason for this motion is to add to pressure on the United States Administration to recognise the value of the whole UN system and the multilateral financial institutions by giving them the financial support which their obligations require. To do any less is to reduce the capacity of the UN for mediation of conflict, for peacekeeping and to reduce the capacity of both the UN and the World Bank to contribute to development in the Third World. During the 1980s much of the Third World has gone through a depression more severe than even the Depression of the 1930s in industrialised countries, so the need for UN and World Bank development activities is greater than it has ever been. As the largest and most powerful of the industrialised democratic countries, it is important for the US to justify its claims to Western leadership by fulfilling the obligations which membership of the international system involves.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whilst the motion has some relevance and some good points, it is part of a general refrain from the Left of the Australian Labor Party against the United States of America. I would like to put it in its perspective and indicate some of the reasons why the United States Government and Congress have been tardy in meeting United Nations subscriptions and in ratifying the general capital increase of the World Bank. We have to look into the history of the participation of the United States in international forums and the contribution of the United States to world peace over the course of this century to have some idea of the perspective within which we must place this motion.

SPEECH.PARA: I go back to the First World War where there was a sense of great idealism on the part of President Wilson in wanting to establish the League of Nations. We all know the sorry history of the League of Nations, where isolationist forces in the United States Congress did not back President Wilson in support for the League of Nations-something which, I believe, was a world tragedy of the century. It may not have succeeded in stopping the Second World War, but at least there might have been something in place which gave us something of a chance.

After the Second World War the United States embarked upon an entirely different policy. It was one of the great supporters of the new United Nations which started up in San Francisco with such hope. It was a major financial supporter of the United Nations and other international bodies pursuing the course of economic development and peace.

TALK.START.PARA: —It had strong bipartisan support.

—As the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business says, it had very strong bipartisan support in the United States. There was also the Marshall Plan put forward by General Marshall, a former United States Defense Secretary. Under the liberalising influences of Presidents Roosevelt and Truman, it was possible to pour money into a devastated Europe and also, through extensive programs of support for underdeveloped countries throughout the world, the United States made a major contribution to not only post-war reconstruction but also the economic development of the underprivileged around the world. Its support for the work of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund contributed enormously to world progress and stability in economic terms. Once it became clear to the Americans that their major ally in the Second World War-the Soviet Union-was not going to pursue a democratic course, once it became clear that the Soviet Union had, in effect, occupied the whole of eastern Europe and subjected those countries to non-democratic communist regimes and once it became clear to the Americans, with the pressure on Berlin and the wonderful resistance to that by President Truman, that their role was not just one of promoting through the United Nations peaceful initiatives but clearly had to be-and very sadly, from their point of view-a military role, institutions such as the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation and ANZUS were set up to protect the free world by force of arms if necessary.

SPEECH.PARA: It is worth reminding the House that over a period of some 20 years the United States had a massive superiority in nuclear weapons over the Soviet Union. It was possible over a long period after the Second World War for the United States to obliterate the Soviet Union without any fear of retaliation. Such is the nature of the world's oldest democracy, such is the nature of the restraining forces on the body politic of that country, that there was never the slightest suggestion that the United States would use that awesome power for evil purposes. Eventually the Soviet Union built up its nuclear forces either to parity or the possibility of retaliating in a devastating way.

At the time, because to a very great extent of the democratising and liberalising influences of the United States in world affairs and its pressure on the old colonial nations, more and more new nations became free of their colonial masters. Unfortunately, very few of them took on a democratic form of government, but they all gradually assumed membership of the United Nations. So, from a relatively small body of members back in the 1940s, the United Nations has grown to the present situation where it has 159 members. The regrettable part of that is that the vast majority of those 159 members do not share the democratic ideals of the United States and have forms of government which deny to their citizens free votes and a free press.

As this historical movement built up the United States, which had contributed in a humanitarian, open and liberal way to the democratisation of much of the world and to its economic reform, reconstruction and progress, found itself in the bar at the very institution which it had done so much to help create. Increasingly, the debates in the United Nations became dominated by ratbaggery, abuse, anti-democratic sentiments, vicious attacks on the United States and its allies and selective attacks on nations, almost regardless of the degree of their error.

I would single out the treatment of South Africa and Israel as two examples of the extraordinary bias that developed in that body over a period of years. There have been many policies in all countries that we could criticise. I am merely saying that, for example, South Africa has been denied the chance to speak in the United Nations General Assembly for many years. That is the reason for its arrears to the United Nations mentioned by the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore). The reason it has not paid its dues is that it has not had a voice in the General Assembly. If Albania, Romania and various other countries of that kind which are guilty of the most appalling atrocities can speak in the United Nations General Assembly, anybody else should be allowed to speak. I give South Africa as an example of a country that is not allowed to speak.

While very nasty regimes paraded themselves self-righteously within the United Nations General Assembly, the United States paid most of the bills. The United States had one vote out of 159. It paid 25 per cent of the budget and 31 per cent of the budget of peacekeeping activities of the United Nations. During this period the United States was constantly berated and attacked and was subject to hypocrisy and ratbaggery, so much so that when Dr Jeanne Kirkpatrick became the United States Ambassador to the United Nations and was asked what her first step would be in her ambassadorship she said, `I will take down the notice on the United States table which says ``Kick me'' '. That is what she said. She decided to defend the liberal and democratic record of that country in the United Nations, which she did with considerable distinction.

It is not terribly surprising that the democratic body at the heart of the United States Government-the United States Congress, which I remind people is elected under a liberal constitution which has lasted over 200 years; the oldest democracy on earth and certainly a most effective one--

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been amended a few times.
—Yes, it has been amended a few times.
—That is part of the process.

—That is part of the process and the amendments are done in accordance with that marvellous liberal mechanism which was devised by the founding fathers and which has worked so well. That Congress naturally got absolutely fed up with paying a quarter of the budget and 31 per cent of the peacekeeping costs of a body which constantly abused and attacked it. People are only human. United States taxpayers are the same as taxpayers anywhere else in the world. If they are forking out a huge proportion of the costs of the United Nations and paying through their taxes for one of the highest defence budgets in the world and one which has been the biggest contribution to peace in the world, paying very largely for the defence of Europe when the Europeans dragged the chain on their defence costs, and paying for global armies and a naval capacity which are there to protect our peace and freedom, is it not sensible for the United States Congress to ask a few questions about how that money is being spent? That is basically what happened.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1986, during the Reagan Administration, the United States announced that it would withhold part of its dues. It did not say that it would do so until people stopped berating it, because that was the role of the body and people could say what they liked in the United Nations General Assembly; it said that it would not pay until administrative reforms were instituted. The extraordinary rorts in the United Nations administration were held back until something was done about them. The United States actually pulled out of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation (UNESCO). There had been a continuing scandalous regime under the former Director-General, Mr M'Bow. Money was wasted all over the place. There was hardly any accountability. it pursued anti-democratic policies in relation to the communications and information side of its work. We did not pull out of UNESCO. I am glad we did not. I am a member of the national commission of UNESCO in Australia. We have different interests. As I am a supporter of UNESCO, certainly under its new Director-General, Mr Mayor, who is trying to reform the organisation and clean out the rorts, I say that if the United States, Britain and Singapore had not pulled out of UNESCO Mr M'Bow would probably still be there and the rorts would still be continuing. If President Reagan had not put the squeeze on UNESCO by starting to withhold some of the cash, the extraordinary rorts would have continued.

The Soviet Union, which has done nothing in the cause of human freedom and the extension of democracy since the war, certainly not since the revolution and even before that, has been one of the biggest participators in the rorts in the United Nations administration of any country in the world. It has not just been Third World countries and crook little non-democratic totalitarian regimes from small countries that have been rorting the United Nations system, sending people there on short term assignments with no career dedication to the work of the United Nations. The Soviet Union has also rorted the system. I object to this motion because it gives a totally wrong impression of the contribution of the United States.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bilney Mr G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to participate in this debate and to support the motion moved by my colleague the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore). While taking note of the points made by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), I still think that the balance of the motion is correct. As the previous speaker did, I want to confine my remarks largely to the United Nations and, particularly, to the peacekeeping side of the United Nations' operations.

SPEECH.PARA: As honourable members will know, when the United Nations was first set up it was the hope and expectation of those who established it that it would play a major role in the keeping of the peace which followed the Second World War. That is why the first aim of the new organisation, which is mentioned in article 1.1 of the United Nations Charter, states:

To maintain international peace and security, and to that end: to take effective collective measures for the prevention and removal of threats to the peace, and for the suppression of acts of aggression or other breaches of the peace, and to bring about by peaceful means, and in conformity with the principles of justice and international law, adjustment or settlement of international disputes or situations which might lead to a breach of the peace.

To that end it was envisaged that the Security Council, the instrument created by the Charter for this purpose, would have its own armed forces contributed to by members and that it would play a genuine peacekeeping role of that kind. That hope was stillborn. For many years the United Nations played very little role as a peacekeeping kind. Such role as it did play, gradually increasing over time, was by means of improvisation. Gradually it worked its way towards being able to play a role in peacekeeping operations, according to some fairly ad hoc, but gradually better understood, principles.

Those peacekeeping forces which it was able to establish followed the lines suggested first by Paul Martin who, at one time, was a Canadian Minister for External Affairs. According to his definition, peacekeeping would take place under UN auspices and have as its objectives the prevention of violence or its curtailment when it broke out-with the proviso that the peacekeeping force itself would only use force as a last resort in self-defence. A peacekeeping force was designed to create or restore an environment in which a peaceful solution to the problems could be considered; and was not in itself a form of conciliation and mediation but was capable of reinforcing efforts at mediation.

Furthermore, under those guidelines it was decided that the UN would only respond to a request for peacekeeping forces under the conditions that a request emanated from a recognised government or governments; that it command general support in the United Nations, including the support or, at least, the acquiescence-in the case of Korea, the absence-of the permanent members of the Security Council; that hostilities must have formally ceased in the area; and that member states themselves must be willing to contribute forces.

Those are very tight guidelines. They are very specific. It means that the UN can only intervene in very specific circumstances and in limited ways. Therefore, the aim of the Charter, based on the belief that international conflicts could be prevented, was not part of that scenario. It was the case that help could be given only when the parties involved in a conflict were in agreement. Nevertheless, it has been the case that there have been a number of peacekeeping operations carried out in that ad hoc, improvised way really from quite soon after the beginning of the formation of the United Nations.

I want to put on the record a list of those conflicts in which Australia has participated as part of a United Nations peacekeeping force. It is the case that Australia, while not being as major a contributor as some other countries to peacekeeping operations of the United Nations, has nevertheless been a very consistent and committed participant. Australia participated in the United Nations Commission for Indonesia, UNCI, from 1947 to 1950. Australia's contribution was one representative and up to 15 military observers at any time. Australia contributed to the United Nations Special Committee on the Balkans. It contributed to the unified command in Korea. Of course, that was the only occasion on which Australia contributed a force level component. Australia contributed to the United Nations Yemen Observation Mission; the United Nations Emergency Force II, UNEF II, to which it contributed 44 men in a helicopter unit; the United Nations Truce Supervision Organisation in Palestine to which it contributed 13 men; the United Nations Military Observer Group in India and Pakistan, UNMOGIP, where it has contributed a force of six men from 1949 to the present; and the United Nations Peacekeeping Force in Cyprus, UNFICYP from 1964 to the present. Australia's most recent contribution has been 15 officers to the United Nations Iran-Iraq Military Observer Group, UNIIMOG, dating from 1988 until the present time.

I wanted to mention specifically UNFICYP, which is one of our longstanding involvements with the United Nations peacekeeping operation. Recently I was in Cyprus and had the opportunity to visit that group and to have lunch with its members. I pay tribute to--

TALK.START.PARA: —They are excellent; I agree.

—I acknowledge the interjection of the shadow Minister at the table. Commander Campbell Thompson is the leader of the 20 Australian personnel and also the commander of the joint force of Swedes and Australians which does an excellent job in very difficult circumstances there. United Nations operations, however, have been a comparatively small scale sort of thing, run on a total annual budget of less than $300m at present.

SPEECH.PARA: We are now looking at a very different situation resulting from a number of things which have happened. The lack of rapprochement, between the superpowers, the United States and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, has always bedevilled the United Nations in its peacekeeping operations. Recently there has been a conscious use by the Soviet Union of the United Nations as a means of advancing the kinds of policies which Mikhail Gorbachev is now promulgating-policies such as greater disengagement and more international respectability for the Soviet Union. As the previous speaker pointed out, the Soviet Union in the past did not pay its dues as it ought to have. It has now paid up. Also there is now a considerably greater degree of pragmatism on the part of the Third World. It may be that this is a response to the United States tactic of withholding contributions, as has been suggested. That may well be the case but the amount of anti-United States, anti-Western posturing which now goes on in the United Nations has considerably reduced from that of two or three years ago. I think that there is also an attitude on the part of some other major contributor countries that the United Nations is a good way of spending money, contrary to what one sometimes hears. For example, not so long ago Japan made a one-off contribution of $20m specifically earmarked for peacekeeping.

As a result of all these factors there has been a considerable enhancement in the prestige of the United Nations and its ability to deal with peacekeeping issues. However, it is now very greatly hampered by the lack of money for these operations. If peacekeeping forces are dispatched to all the trouble spots where peace is now breaking out-I am thinking of the Gulf, Afghanistan, Namibia, the Middle East and Cambodia; I think we all pray that it will be possible for the UN to send peacekeeping forces to those areas-we are looking at an annual bill which could run to something like $2 billion, which is about twice the regular budget of the United Nations. In those circumstances one cannot afford to have major contributing countries not paying their dues, particularly when I think it could well be argued-indeed, is argued within the Congress of the United States-that those objectives serve the interests of the United States just as much as they serve the interests of the world community in general; in fact, more. It is to be hoped that the attitude which has been displayed by the United States Administration in recent weeks, whereby some moves have been made towards removing the United States from its status, as an American congressman described it recently, of a `deadbeat' in the United Nations, will change, and that a motion of this kind may help in that regard.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House congratulates President Reagan on his contribution to world peace and economic prosperity during his 2 terms as President of the United States of America.

On Tuesday of next week certainly the free world and the world in general will know who will be leading the free world's largest democracy. A climax will have been reached in what have been some years of political speculation. For the purpose of both the motion appearing in my name and the debate this morning, I am not particularly concerned about whether it is a Bush or a Dukakis win, whether the win goes to the Republicans or to the Democrats. I am more concerned about using the forum of this Parliament to congratulate the present President of the United States of America (USA) on his performance as President of that democracy.

I want to say to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and to those who are listening that it is not my task nor my intention, nor I believe the intention of the honourable member for Casey (Mr Halverson), who will second this motion, to in any way paint the image of the President of the United States as if he were perfect. Of course he is a human being-warts and all. But I want to make and reinforce the point that he is not the gun-toting Rambo that was popularly portrayed early in the 1980s, nor is he the incompetent man that has been portrayed in the latter part of his presidency. In fact, this image of an incompetent figurehead has done him no justice at all and his record as President belies all that has been done by the popular press to in some way portray him as a less than effective President of the United States of America.

I noted with interest that the mover of the motion that preceded this one, the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore), and the seconder, the honourable member for Kingston (Mr Bilney), were both anxious in their own quiet way to erode what was the United States' standing in the United Nations by referring to the failure of the United States to meet what were its obligations to the United Nations. I want to take up the point made by the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), who so effectively pointed out that, far from the United States losing its interest in the United Nations, it was simply using what leverage it had to put some pressure on the United Nations in order to keep that body in some sense of perspective with the rest of the world. I think we should remember that in any debate on the United States we are dealing with the people who are our principal allies. It has been too easy for this Parliament to run with the popular image of the USA and of Americans as brash and overbearing both in their individual and in their national relationships. I am guilty of having done the same thing. In the 1970s I was a visitor for an extended period in the United States of America. Obviously I was much younger. I left Australia with all of the preconceived ideas that Australians had in the 1970s about the United States of America. I was concerned about campus unrest and Vietnam and wondered frankly whether in a place in as much turmoil as the United States of America I would ever get home again. I discovered, in the six months I spent there, I could not have been more at home than I was in that great democracy.

I think it is time we stood up in this Parliament and said something about what President Reagan has done during his two-year term as President of the United States. It has been too easy to paint him as the President who has extended the deficit and as a dithering, uncertain and hesitant manager or, as I said earlier, to suggest that he is some sort of warmonger. This is an image born out of the press perception of a gunslinging cowboy. When first this motion appeared in my name I hesitated about speaking to it, but I investigated what has been President Reagan's record, and it is the result of that investigation that I bring to the House this morning. I have moved, as I indicated, that this House congratulate President Reagan on his contribution to world peace and economic prosperity.

What has President Reagan done for world peace that the popular press has not picked up? Let the President speak for himself, for this is the forenote that was prepared as a cover for seven of his speeches that were put together in May of this year. President Reagan said:

Abroad I have tried to convey the message of a strong America, dedicated to the quest for peace and the cause of freedom-in speeches before the British Parliament in London and the Brandenburg Gate in West Berlin, in the halls of the United Nations and to the citizens of Brazil, Mexico, Costa Rica, China, South Korea, Japan, Italy, Spain and France. I have sought to communicate to the people of the Soviet Union and other nations across the barriers of distance language and political ideology.

Whatever the occasion for the speeches presented . . ., I have always tried to speak plainly about the enduring values upon which this nation was founded: faith in God, commitment to democracy, the quest for peace, limited government, reliance on the free enterprise system, and an unyielding belief in human freedom as the essential key to human achievement and the progress of mankind.

Seven years ago, when I first took office as President, who would have believed that we could sign an agreement with the Soviets not only to stop building additional nuclear weapons, but indeed to eliminate some of them?

Some might say that that is merely the rhetoric that we have come to expect from all political figures, but the truth is that President Reagan in eight years in office has done more than anyone else to secure some sort of lasting peace in the world, and he has done it from a position of strength. He has been accused of committing more of the US Budget to defence spending than the US could afford. But the truth is that that action alone took the US back into a level playing field in terms of defence expenditure and, as Reagan said on the television program Reagan on Reagan, `National security is my first priority, more important than a balanced budget'.

Having levelled the outlay on arms and forced the Russians to recognise that the Americans were prepared to match them weapon for weapon, suddenly President Reagan found, as he had anticipated, a Russian force prepared to negotiate. Certainly it meant that the free world had a popular image of Reagan as a Rambo President but-and I reiterate-who would have believed seven years ago that we could sign an agreement with the Soviets not only to stop building additional weapons but, indeed, to eliminate some of them? That achievement alone ought to be echoed round the world as a tribute to President Reagan. After eight years the Cold War has begun to thaw. Few people can claim to have equalled the contribution to world peace that this man has made during his two terms as President. As the President said to students gathered in Moscow:
Nations do not distrust each other because they are armed: they are armed because they distrust each other.

Because of his passionate commitment to democracy he backed freedom fighters around the world-in Grenada, Afghanistan, Angola and Central America. I know that that is an invitation for honourable members opposite to be critical of his actions in any one of those countries, but we deceive ourselves if we pretend that confrontation and war can ever be comfortable or perfect. The President, faced with a choice not unlike that which his countrymen faced at the end of the Second World War over the bombing of the Japanese cities of Nagasaki and Hiroshima, had to make difficult decisions, which he made courageously and which have assisted democracies to be established in countries previously under threat. His objectives of peace and freedom have been achieved because he was prepared to negotiate from a position of strength. The negotiations he undertook to set in place the intermediate-range nuclear force (INF) agreement are probably the most significant demilitarising action since World War II.

If President Reagan's image as a peacemaker has been distorted by the popular press, the misrepresentation has been nothing compared to what has happened to his reputation as an economist. He has been blamed for burgeoning government deficits when the real perspective is that from 1965 to 1980 the American budget went up five times while the deficit went up 52 times. I refer to a statement made by Mr Niskanen, the President of the Cato Institute. In May this year he said that the American economy was in fine shape compared to the situation when Reagan took office. Niskanen cited not only the sharp decline in inflation but also increases in productivity and growth from what he termed the dismal record of the Carter Administration in the late 1970s. He said that real earnings had bounced back after their decline during the presidency of Jimmy Carter.

Critics opposite may well say, `Look at the enormous level of American debt; look at what has been run up and look at this sort of overburden that the whole world economy faces'.
