Before we are seen falling for that cheap anti-American line that we have come to anticipate, let us look at the relative American debt compared to our own. In 1986 the Australian debt-it has burgeoned since-stood at $70.1 billion and the American debt at $525 billion. The population in Australia is 16 million; the population in America is 241 million. Before honourable members opposite throw stones they should look at the debt per American citizen as compared to that per Australian citizen. They would discover, as everyone I hope knows, that in 1986 every Australian owed-thanks to the actions of this Government; and it has only got worse but I want to cite figures I can verify-$6,600 while the American debt per head was $3,300. We are hardly in a position to be critical of President Reagan's economic policies.

The unemployment rate of the United States of America under this President is at its lowest level in 14 years, while the US economy generated a world record rate of employment-10 points above that generated in Europe and one point above that generated in Japan. What is the secret? How did President Reagan do it in spite of what has been a popular press campaign against him? As he said during the television show earlier this week Reagan on Reagan:
The best way to increase government revenue is to cut taxation.

We have not heard much of that from honourable members opposite, have we? Time prevents me from making the other points I wish to make in the President's defence. Suffice it to say that he has been a man committed-I say this as one representing a rural electorate-to breaking down the level of protection that American farmers are currently enjoying. I refer listeners to an article in today's Australian on page 15 where national affairs commentator, Des Keegan, has written:
A Bush win will underpin commodities while Dukakis might tip the US into recession and lower prices.

My farmers quite frankly hope that President Reagan is followed by another Republican President. While I do not know, I have a sneaking suspicion that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) does as well. The great tribute to President Reagan must be the way he has engendered a pride of America in Americans, while here our pride in being Australians has been sapped. While we have spent our bicentennial year apologising, President Reagan has spent eight years making Americans proud to be Americans. It has been easy to belittle him and to denigrate him but we should not lose sight of the positive reinforcement that has been the hallmark of his presidency and that we could well emulate to our advantage in this nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johns Mr G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot support the motion before the House simply because it attempts to concentrate purely on President Reagan and his efforts to help secure some elements of peace. We might equally congratulate Gorbachev on his efforts in achieving some elements of peace, particularly through the intermediate-range nuclear force (INF) treaty. But to single out Reagan is to argue from an ideological point of view and, frankly, a blindfolded stance. Agreement was reached on this particular treaty because it suited both sides. The INF is a good agreement, although it is a very small step in the very long march to securing peace. The outstanding issues are matters such as space defence, the future of the anti-ballistic missile treaty, and the verification of sea launched cruise missiles. It is simply not true, as some would have it, that the Russians were dragged kicking and screaming to the negotiating table over the INF treaty. It is not true, as is the popular image, that the United States was hanging tough on the issue and that the Russians were down to their last rouble and were forced to reduce some of their weapons systems. I submit that without the change of leadership in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR) to Gorbachev there would have been no agreement. We must look at the efforts of both sides to understand their contribution to world peace. Our Government's view is that both superpowers must seek to resolve their problems. I quote from a speech made by Bill Hayden in Moscow on 30 May 1984:

SPEECH.PARA: Just as it takes two to make war, it takes two to forge the peace.
Similarly, in a recent speech in September this year, Senator Evans made the point:

We believe that peace . . . will not be ultimately guaranteed by threats of mutual assured destruction or elaborately constructed military defences, but rather by acceptance of the concept of Common Security-the notion, put most simply, that countries cannot, at the end of the day, enhance their own security by threatening other countries . . .

This motion raises Reagan as the great peacemaker. It is incumbent on me to look at Reagan's record and be critical, in the most positive sense, of Reagan's contribution. I want to range across seven different areas, time permitting. The first is that we cannot escape the fact of Reagan's massive spending on weapons and the effect that has had on America's domestic priorities and its economy. Second, Reagan did take an early belligerent stance on nuclear arms agreements, even if in the later years he softened his approach. Third, he refused to negotiate on the important areas, like naval-based weaponry and, of course, he pushed his strategic defence initiative, or the star wars initiative, I think to the great detriment of peace negotiations. Fourth, his overwhelming desire has been to re-establish the superpower game plan of good versus evil; I believe he has upped the ante in the superpower conflict. Fifth, he has a record of dealing with terrorism that has confused the demonstration of power by the US with the exercise of that power, and it has brought the US undone in a most embarrassing way. Sixth, his policy of low intensity conflict, as in Nicaragua, has been a disgrace and has led to what I would call `dirty little wars'. Seventh, and finally, he has a disdain for the United Nations, and has certainly sought to interfere in that body's governance and deliberations.

Recognising that I am responding to this motion on Reagan, I need to make these criticisms. The reality is that the Reagan Administration has tried to buy back its fallen pride, post-Vietnam, through its massive spending on defence. Reagan made those wonderful statements about standing tall in Main Street, but the American taxpayer has suffered enormously for that Reagan stance.

I shall cite some figures. A major source of government spending has been, of course, in the area of defence. The amount spent on defence in the first five years of the Reagan Administration was $US1 trillion, almost exactly the amount by which the national debt increased in this same period. This level of defence spending represented a military tax of over $US16,000 on each of the nation's 62 million families. Whilst we should not just line up the American debt with expenditure on defence, it is fairly obvious that the overexpenditure on defence has had an enormous impact on the American taxpayer. Further, the reality is that Reagan took a very belligerent stance early in his presidency on the matter of nuclear arms agreements. The failure of the SALT II agreement-Strategic Arms Limitation Talks-was partly due to Reagan's brinkmanship, and frankly he almost caused heart failure amongst North Atlantic Treaty Organisation (NATO) allies.

Let us look not just at the record of Reagan, but also at the score card of the United States in the area of agreements. First there is the anti-ballistic missile (ABM) treaty, currently under siege but still intact, and there is no idea when we will get a renegotiation. Second, there is the SALT II agreement. The US has been bending the rules on that one, but it has not broken them. Thirdly, there is military spending where there was a five-year binge, followed by a recent three-year freeze. There has been a 21 per cent growth in the buying of strategic nuclear warheads. There has been no growth in strategic nuclear launchers, thank goodness. The MX missiles have become simply a shadow of their former and original concept, thank goodness. Star wars itself has received huge budgetary growth but, as there is no deployment in sight, again we can be thankful for that. ASAT-anti-satellite-testing has suffered a congressional imposed bilateral moratorium. As for nuclear testing, Reagan has succeeded in staving off the limits to nuclear testing. We agree that there has been a treaty success with INF, and we look for a potential success with the new negotiations for the Strategic Arms Reduction Talks, START, but as yet nothing has been achieved.

Let us look at some area where Reagan has refused to negotiate. The fact is there has been very little discussion about naval weaponry, the reason being that the US has such a large lead over the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics in the ability and deployment of its navy. The US and the Soviets have 6,350 naval nuclear weapons between them. None of these weapons is covered by any arms control agreements. Superpower naval nuclear arsenals include long-range land-attack cruise missiles, depth bombs, artillery projectiles, gravity bombs, anti-submarine rockets and surface-to-air missiles. Of these, only the cruise missiles are subject to any ongoing negotiations.

Further, Reagan has pressed on with his Flash Gordon diplomacy via the SDI, the strategic defence initiative, or star wars. But there has been great confusion as to how Reagan has sold the notion of star wars. He presented the SDI as a way of initially escaping deterrence, the protection of the people against nuclear weapons. But almost immediately Reagan's experts assured him that this could not be achieved, so SDI was then touted as a way of enhancing deterrence. It would not protect people from nuclear weapons; it would protect nuclear weapons from nuclear weapons. It hardly advances the cause of peace.

Further to that, we enter the area where Reagan has sought, ideologically if you like in terms of the debate, to re-establish superpower dominance over world affairs. He has brought power to his presidency by establishing the so-called evil of his `opposite empire', and it is that debate that brought Reagan undone. It is not just newspaper talk; he generated that state of mind.

Then, of course, there is the Reagan record in dealing with terrorism, with the use of military intervention as a counter-terrorist measure. We remember the so-called surgical strike at Libya, which was a military and political disaster, and which did not even achieve the aim of killing Gaddaffi. But it certainly upset the NATO allies and set them back on their heels. It is that sort of instability that Reagan has created. The cure for terrorism is not counter-terrorism, such as the raid on Libya; it lies in the search for political solutions to complex political problems, like getting Israel out of Lebanon and restraining it from raids against the Palestinians and from carrying out search and destroy operations against Lebanese villagers. The fact is that when the Americans created the so-called surgical strike they had no idea that that would mean babies would be needing surgery. I think it eventually shocked not so much the American people but others around the world when Reagan so outrageously performed that act of anti-terrorism.

Of course, there were other examples where Reagan tried to use his power in minor ways, such as having his warships based in the Persian Gulf and his marines based in the Lebanon, as well as the tragedy this year of the American warship, the USS Vincennes, that unfortunately and tragically shot down an Iranian civilian airliner. I am using these points not as criticism but only to demonstrate the fact that the Americans have been unable to differentiate between establishing that they are powerful but not using that force, and indeed using that force.

Further, of course, there is the matter of what I have termed the `dirty little wars', what the Americans and probably the Russians would call `low intensity conflict'. The fact that the Americans in support of the Contras in Nicaragua have used that sort of weapon to support their own ideology has again shocked many of us. I take a short quote from Tip O'Neill, the now retired Speaker of the House of Representatives:
I wouldn't liken them, have them as freedom fighters at all-
he is talking about the Contras-

I look on them as vicious, fiendish people who ran a government and put the nation where it is at the present day. He (President Reagan) talks about them as being freedom fighters. I get sick to my stomach.

To complete my comments, I would like to refer to the main conclusion of the report of the congressional committees which investigated the Iran-Contra affair and which, even as late as yesterday, President Reagan blamed as some sort of media beat-up. The main conclusion of that eminent group was:
The common ingredients of the Iran and Contra policies were secrecy, deception, and disdain for the law.

Reagan knew what was going on but simply denies that. I want to conclude on one other point-I want to talk about Reagan's stance in the United Nations (UN). The fact is that the UN has matured. It has a more internationalist stance, not just the old pro-Western alliance stance that it had. Reagan, and especially the Americans, have found this hard to cop so they have been playing heavyweight with the UN and have decided now to move their aid according to how nations vote in the UN. I will give one last quote. In a press conference in August 1985 the new United States Ambassador to the UN, General Vernon Walters, explicitly linked a country's UN voting pattern to the health of its bilateral relations with the US when he made the following observation- Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Mountford)-Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Halverson Mr R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Any critical and unbiased assessment of Ronald Reagan's achievements in his eight years as President of the United States of America (USA) must include a very positive reference to his significant contributions to world peace and economic prosperity. In regard to the latter, Ronald Reagan's record speaks for itself.

SPEECH.PARA: On the `home front', Reaganomics has resulted in the longest period of peacetime economic growth in the history of the United States-more than 70 months of steady growth, low inflation and broad prosperity. Ronald Reagan will become the first US President to complete his term with both inflation and unemployment lower than when he was elected. Even his most ardent and persistent critics are impressed by the record shattering run of the current recovery.

The facts cannot be denied. When President Reagan came to office, inflation was running at 10.5 per cent. It is now 4 per cent. The unemployment rate was 7.4 per cent. It is now 5.4 per cent. The home mortgage interest rate was 13.2 per cent. It is now 9 per cent. The lowest personal income tax rate was 14 per cent when Reagan was elected. It is now 11 per cent. The highest rate was 70 per cent. This has been reduced to 50 per cent.

Between 1981 and 1986 real median household incomes-the best measure of family prosperity-rose 9.1 per cent. Compare this with the decrease of 3.4 per cent during the Carter Administration. Real median incomes of all male fulltime workers rose 3.8 per cent. Under Carter they had dropped by 6.4 per cent. The so-called `misery index'-the sum of America's inflation and unemployment rates-has plummeted from 17.9 per cent in January 1981 to 9.4 per cent in August 1988.

Since the end of 1980, nearly 16 million net new jobs have been created in the United States. This represents some 90 per cent of all the jobs created by the Big Seven industrial economies. In August 1988, a record 115 million Americans were employed, and the unemployment rate of 5.4 per cent was the lowest for 15 years. Real gross business and personal investment has risen 25.6 per cent since 1981. Under Carter it declined by 2.3 per cent.

It is interesting to note that two of the traditionally most disadvantaged groups-blacks and women-have made real progress during the Reagan Administration. Since 1981, black teenage unemployment rates-which had remained virtually static under Carter-have fallen from 41 per cent to 31 per cent. The unemployment rate for adult black males was 12.1 per cent. It is now 9.5 per cent. From 1981 to 1986 real median incomes of black families rose 10.1 per cent. Under Carter they dropped almost 6 per cent.

Female unemployment has now fallen to the same level as that of men. Nearly 50 million women now hold paying jobs-over 8 million more than when Reagan first took over the presidency. Since 1981, the number of women in management occupations has risen by more than 70 per cent and in skilled production jobs by more than 52 per cent. For every category of full-time worker-black and white, male and female-real median incomes have risen since 1981.

These achievements are the result of the national economic reforms which President Reagan described as having been designed with the objective of `increasing economic activity from the bottom up'. The program was based on his belief that, if given the opportunity, the people themselves will provide the solutions to their problems. `As is often the case', he said, `the best thing government can do is get out of the way'.

Certainly the US faces a huge Budget deficit and a growing trade deficit-although it is worth noting that the federal Budget deficit, which nearly tripled between 1981 and 1986, declined by nearly 30 per cent in 1987. And as John Makin, Director of fiscal policy studies at the American Enterprise Institute for Public Policy Research, points out:
The inescapable facts about the Reagan-years deficits are that they neither caused the sky to fall nor induced some great calamity (though many economists predicted otherwise).

The fortunes of the free world are closely attuned to and influenced by the fortunes of the United States. If the US falters, we all suffer. If the US is doing well, we all share the benefits. The current US economic revolution has had a positive international impact. Opportunities for expanding trade with America have been beneficial to many countries whose own economies have been under pressure. In some cases, the additional export earnings made all the difference.

In his address last year to a joint meeting of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, in Washington, President Reagan outlined the central themes of US economic policies and relations-especially with developing countries-in the following words:
. . . trade rather than aid, mutual benefit rather than charity, a hand up rather than a hand-out.

He renewed the long term and substantial US commitment to helping solve the problems of the Third World-advocating the adoption on a wider scale of the economic concepts and reforms that had reinvigorated America's economy during his term of office, and a free and fair world trading system.

He has consistently emphasised the undeniable relationship between freedom and human progress, and his contribution to economic prosperity and world peace has, at least in part, been based on this unswerving dedication to the cause of freedom.

President Reagan identified the promotion of freedom and democracy as the key to world economic growth, and equated economic freedom with political freedom. He has pursued his commitment to promoting democracy abroad and building a safer and more durable world peace in many different ways-assessing the available options and acting accordingly.

Pressure from his Administration helped oust former Philippine President Marcos, and Haitian dictator `Baby Doc' Duvalier. US troops helped topple the inept Marxist regime in Grenada. He has campaigned against the discredited government of Panamanian strongman Noriega.

He has maintained his commitment to supporting the so-called freedom fighters-whom he described as the `key to peace'-in Afghanistan, Nicaragua, Cambodia and Angola. His support for the Afghan rebels was a major factor in the Soviets' decision to start withdrawing their troops from Afghanistan.

His meetings with General Secretary Gorbachev of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, and the signing of the INF treaty-the intermediate-range nuclear force treaty-further underline his approach and commitment to world peace and security. Unlike some other US Presidents who have had the opportunity to take the initiative in improving relationships between the two most powerful countries in the world, Reagan did not let the chance go by.

The result has been a series of successful and constructive summit meetings, and a treaty providing for the abolition of an entire class of US and Soviet nuclear missiles. The INF treaty is a landmark in international postwar peace initiatives. Most significantly, it is an arms reduction rather than just an arms control agreement.

There is, of course, a lot more to be done. But the longest, most challenging and difficult journey does not start until someone takes the first step-and this is what Reagan, often in the face of considerable opposition, has done. President Reagan has been an inspiration to the world. If those opposite are not persuaded by my arguments, perhaps they will be convinced by the words of our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). I quote from page 837 of Hansard of 1 September:

As Americans prepare to elect a new President I want to take this opportunity to pay tribute to President Reagan and the members of his Administration, particularly Secretary of State George Shultz, for the leadership which they have provided to the Western Alliance during their time in office. The progress which has been achieved on a variety of world issues, and particularly in the area of arms control, has unlocked the door to what may very well be a new era of peace and cooperation.

Very rarely do I find myself agreeing with the Prime Minister, but in this case there can be no doubt as to the accuracy of the sentiments he has expressed. I say to President Reagan: Congratulations. Your successor, whoever he may be, certainly has a hard act to follow.

TALK.START.PARA: —The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday. The honourable member will have leave to continue his speech when the debate is resumed.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 1 September, on motion by Mr Webster:
That this House-
(1) declares that this nation enjoys basic human rights and freedoms unequalled anywhere in the world and that these rights and freedoms are not under threat;
(2) acknowledges the inherent dangers in inserting ``rights'' clauses in a written Constitution; and

(3) expresses its concerns that the changes to the Constitution proposed by referendum question number 4 would allow Commonwealth Governments to meddle with and deprive Australians of their basic rights and freedoms.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr D.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are resuming the debate on the motion concerning the human rights and referendum question moved by the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster) on the last private member's business Thursday. The last part of the motion states that the House:

SPEECH.PARA: expresses its concerns that the changes to the Constitution proposed by referendum question number 4 would allow Commonwealth Governments to meddle with and deprive Australians of their basic rights and freedoms.
The referendum questions have now been voted on and defeated, but it is interesting to go over a few points once again, particularly in light of the words:
. . . would allow Commonwealth Governments to meddle with and deprive Australians of their basic rights and freedoms.

What absolute drivel. I had something to do with the referendum campaign in my area and engaged in some very interesting correspondence with a number of religious people, particularly a bishop that I know quite well. We are still good friends after the event, but we had an exchange of viewpoints on this matter. I believe that a number of religious organisations now feel that they may have been misled or were wrong in the perceptions that they put forward at the time. It is simply not true that the changes would have allowed Commonwealth governments to meddle, as the honourable member for Macquarie stated in his motion. Section 116 of the Constitution states:
The Commonwealth-
I repeat: the Commonwealth-
shall not make any law for establishing any religion . . . for any office or public trust under the Commonwealth.

The Commonwealth is mentioned twice in section 116 of the Constitution. No other government or State is mentioned. The third part of the motion relates to referendum question No. 4 regarding religion, trial by jury and acquisition of land. There is an anomaly in the relevant sections of the Constitution in that they refer only to the Commonwealth. As the Constitution stands at present, because the referendum was defeated, a State may establish a religion, a State may deprive people of their land and not give them recompense, as has happened, and a State is not necessarily covered by the section with regard to trial by jury-because States are not mentioned.

That was the whole purpose of the very innocuous-as we on this side of the House thought-changes proposed to the Constitution. People decided to read all sorts of things into them, but they would not have changed the Commonwealth's powers one iota. There was great meddling not on the part of the Commonwealth but on the part of those opposite, who want to stay in yesterday's land-the men of yesterday who want to hold everything up. They say, `Let us not progress. Let us not have a new national anthem'-we have one-`and let us not have a new national flag'. A new flag is not on the Commonwealth agenda but it will happen one day, as surely as we are sitting here now. Time will pass Opposition members by. In the early 1970s the then Prime Minister, Mr Whitlam, put forward many ideas that were frowned upon by the conservatives as outrageous-the communists were obviously going to take over!-but within only a decade, and even before this Government came to office, many of his thoughts were totally accepted by the people. Those opposite are men of yesterday trying to hold everything back. Why do they not look forward for once? They know the Constitution is deficient. Why do they not try to make it a little better and a little more operative for all of us?

The motion before the House spells out that those opposite are men of yesterday when it talks about allowing the Commonwealth Government `to meddle with and deprive Australians of their basic rights and freedoms'. That is absolute drivel and everyone in this House knows it. Even those who fought against the referendum changes know that the changes would not have meant anything of substance as far as the Commonwealth was concerned. I see the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) making notes. I am talking about the substance of the Constitution in regard to the Commonwealth. The proposal would have changed things as far as the States were concerned. It would have stopped them from establishing religions, for example, which they are now allowed to do. We could have the Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen feast day or the Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen religion. It is perfectly legal for such things to be established. There could be a State religion of Queensland. It is perfectly legal under the Constitution.

Unfortunately, the people of Australia did not want to make a change a few weeks ago, but it will happen. The men of yesterday will be defeated eventually. When those sorts of questions come up again we will probably not be here. When the next government brings those questions up people will accept them for what they are worth, as they have accepted Mr Whitlam's many thoughts for an equitable society. They will accept the goodness in those suggestions. People accept good suggestions. They may not accept them straightaway, but they will accept them eventually because they will see that they are right. The motion before the House suggests that the Commonwealth will meddle in and deprive everyone of their freedoms and rights. There is talk also of looking at the Bill of Rights and such things. The United States has had a Bill of Rights since its inception, but there is something draconian in such legislation as far as the conservatives in this Parliament are concerned.

The changes that have been put forward from time to time by this Government since its election in 1983 have looked at ways to improve our Constitution, to make our lives better. We are not looking backwards, as are so many on the other side; we are looking forward. We have changed our national anthem and we will make changes to our national flag in years to come-It may take 10, 20 or 30 years-who knows? But it will happen. It is inevitable, just as Australia will one day become a republic. It might be 50 years from now but it is inevitable. I am not suggesting that we rush into it tomorrow, but we should be talking about it constructively so that we are in a position to accept it and get the greatest benefit from it when it happens. I am not suggesting that we should cut off our ties with the Commonwealth. I think that it is a very good thing that we are in the Commonwealth and that we should stay in it.

However, we should be talking about these things constructively rather than putting a dampener on every conceivable idea that comes forward. `Do not let us worry whether a proposal has any merit or whether it will benefit Australians, the poor and Aboriginals', in whom you, Mr Deputy Speaker, have much interest, is the sort of nonsense the motion puts forward. The motion is yesterday's motion from yesterday's men. We on this side of the House are quite happy for honourable members opposite to go on like that, because until they wake up to themselves they will stay on that side of the House for a long time.
I will resume my seat and let others speak, but I hope and trust that the House will reject this motion for the nonsense that it is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I found the contribution of the honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Charles) most amusing. It is rather strange that we have a very sad situation for the two Government speakers. They are here at a wake because this motion was proposed prior to the referendum questions on 3 September and, because of the parliamentary process, it comes before the House only now. We know the answer. We know that the people of Australia have thrown out the referendum questions lock, stock and barrel. Yet the honourable member for Isaacs talked about Opposition members being yesterday's men. I can tell you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the referendum questions are yesterday's questions and the people of Australia resoundingly defeated them and threw them out. It was not the Opposition-members of the Liberal and National parties-which threw them out: the people of Australia threw them out. They will throw out this Labor Government at the very next opportunity because they have learnt over the course of the last five years just what the Labor Government is all about. It is the highest taxing government Australia has ever had. People know that because they are hurting. They know that this Labor Government is totally out of touch with the reality of ordinary Australians. They know that because they are in the housing queues, they are paying the interest bills and they are suffering from inflation. The people of Australia are now fully aware of the iniquity of the Hawke Labor Government and what it is doing to them.

SPEECH.PARA: At a succession of events, the Australian people have told the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and all their hangers-on that they are finished with them, that they do not want them. We have only to look at the Adelaide by-election at which Labor was rejected and at the Port Adelaide by-election, where there was a tremendous swing against Labor. In the New South Wales election Labor was trounced and thrown out. The Victorian election was an absolute cliff-hanger. Labor held on to office by a mere handful of votes. Again, the people of Victoria gave Labor the message. Then there was the by-election for Oxley, the seat held previously by the Governor-General designate. Boy, what a message was there. The people of Oxley resoundingly, again, said to Labor, `Your time's up: it's time to go'. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys), who is at the table, smiles but it is a smile of worry and fear, is it not? It is a nervous smile because he knows the truth of what I am saying. What has come through is that the people of Australia do not want more control; they do not want big government; they do not want the dead hand of bureaucracy to come and throttle them. They want to live a life as free as possible from government interference.

I was interested to hear the honourable member for Isaacs say that the changes would never mean anything. He saw me scribbling notes and very quickly said, `Oh, yes, not for the Commonwealth but for the States'. What he said, before he bent over backwards to qualify what he said, was that the changes would never mean anything. He was right because the whole purpose of the four referendum questions was to concentrate more power in Canberra. That is what the referendum was all about. It was not interested in trial by jury, freedom of religion, local government or anything else: those are all window-dressing issues. The only question of importance was question No. 1, because that was the question designed to emasculate the Senate, to destroy the Senate, to give the government of the day more power, to concentrate more power in Canberra, to take power from the people and encapsulate it here, hopefully for the Hawke Government. That is not on at all because the people of Australia have seen through the Hawke Labor Government. They have seen through it because they have seen how it gets on with its big-moneyed mates.

Just as an aside, Mr Deputy Speaker, it was an insult to the people of Australia when the price of beer was reduced in the Budget. I suppose that is fine for everybody who enjoys a glass of beer-I do-and a glass of wine, but nobody was after it. There was no great pressure from people saying, `We want cheaper beer'. The pressure was the $400m that could have been spent on roads and on getting rid of the assets test on social security and veterans' affairs pensioners. But no, the Government said to the people of Australia, `We in the Labor Party think you're a lot of mugs. We'll give you cheaper beer. That'll keep you happy'. It goes back to the Roman days of bread and circuses.

Honourable members opposite are so stupid that they think the people of Australia are taken in. I can assure them that that is not the case. I will go through it again: the Port Adelaide by-election, the New South Wales election, the Brisbane City Council election and the Victorian election. The Government has the Western Australia Inc. election coming up soon. It should prepare for it because the Australian Labor Party will get another great kick in the guts. Forgive me if I speak as a real Australian, but come the Western Australian election, Labor will get kicked in the guts again. It is all that it deserves.

The honourable member for Isaacs made passing reference, as a smokescreen, to the United States Bill of Rights. He knows, just as I and everybody else in this House know, that the American Bill of Rights bears no relationship whatsoever to the Australian Bill of wrongs that the Government tried to introduce. Again, the Australian people were not fooled then and they threw out, rejected, the whole concept of the Bill of Rights, through the agency of the Senate. That is why this Labor Government brought in those referendum questions: to gain more power over the Senate; to lessen the power of the Senate and to concentrate the power in Canberra. The people of Australia do not want that. Australia is a Federation. Australia is a collection of States working together with the Commonwealth, and it works very well providing Big Brother in Canberra does not try to grab control of the lot. That is what the people of Australia have rejected.

It was very interesting to listen to the honourable member for Isaacs. He epitomises what Labor is really on about. He has brought it out in its true colours. He said that a new flag is inevitable. Does he have any Returned Services League members in his electorate? He will not be getting their votes. He said that a republic is inevitable in Australia. I for one reject that concept totally. He can bluster and say that we are yesterday's men living in the past, but I am living right now. I am learning from the past and I am living for the future-the future of all Australians. That is what we on the Opposition side are all about because, unlike Labor, we are not out of touch. We are not swanning around with multimillionaire mates. We are not doing that. We are out in the electorate talking to the people we represent all the time. We know what the people of Australia want. Increasingly, every time they get the opportunity they are giving the Hawke Labor Government the message, `Go; for heaven's sake go'. Regrettably, we are not going to have the opportunity to put that message firmly through the ballot box until probably late next year. When the opportunity does come, the people of Australia will say to the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and the honourable member for Isaacs, `Your time is up; it is time to go'.

The people of Australia are concerned about freedom. They are concerned about liberty. They do not want an expansion of the tentacles of Canberra power. They want to be left to live their lives as free of government interference as possible. That is what Australia is all about-letting ordinary Australian citizens get on with their lives free of the dead hand of Labor control.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion moved by the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster) stresses, in the first instance, that the citizens of Australia enjoy human rights and freedoms unequalled anywhere else in the world. I have no real argument with that. But I do have to take him to task over the other propositions where he talks about Commonwealth takeovers. If he wants to talk about freedoms, he ought to start looking at the various States. I would like to cite Queensland. In that State we have no freedom of information, as we do in the Commonwealth and other Labor States. There is no right to fair and democratic voting systems. The system there has been prostituted and impaired because of the gerrymander and the rorted boundaries. The individual rights to justice in that State have also been placed in doubt by the politicising of the police force. This has been demonstrated by the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct. We have noted revelations in recent times involving the stood down Commissioner of Police.

SPEECH.PARA: The rights of Queenslanders have also been diminished in the corporate area. I want to dwell on that for a moment. I want to talk about the rights of people when it comes to corrupt tendering systems. The Fitzgerald inquiry, regrettably, is touching on only part of the problem. Whilst I commend Mr Fitzgerald and his investigators for their commitment and perseverance and the way they have argued through and worked at trying to uncover what is going on in Queensland, until they start addressing the corporate area they are not really going to get to the issues. In 1978 I named some 40 people in Queensland-police, business people and sporting personalities-who were involved in SP bookmaking. It was covered up by the police and by the Government then. We had a total cover-up across the board until now, when the Fitzgerald inquiry has substantiated the claims I have made. This week my claims about political interference and the attempts to expose the corruption behind the Stanwell powerhouse tenders were also proven. It was shown by a raid on certain documents that there was direction of the Police Department, and particularly Commissioner Lewis, by the Premier.

There is corruption right throughout Queensland. It has been there for a long time. Even with the Ahern Government it has prevailed. Corruption is rife in all the State Government dealings. Premier Ahern said on this morning's AM program that his Government had nothing to do with the sort of things coming out of the Fitzgerald inquiry-the Fitzgerald revelations. I have a lot of time for Mike Ahern. I have known him for 20 years, having served for 15 1/2 years in the State House. But he and other Ministers are still in the Cabinet that was set up by Bjelke-Petersen. They cannot distance themselves unless they are prepared to really open the lid on the investigations and allegations that have been made. There is a need for a judicial inquiry into the Stanwell tenders because the police inquiry was discredited. The Auditor-General inquiry by Mr Craven was inadequate. He refused to follow up additional allegations that I made.

I now challenge Mike Ahern to release Cabinet minutes of special meetings of Cabinet held on 3 August and 6 August 1987. He should tell us who were the Ministers who attended those meetings. The first meeting was a general meeting. The second meeting was a special one called by Bjelke-Petersen to overturn the original decisions to award a contract for the sale of the Queensland Fish Board which originally was going to P. Manettas and Co. Pty Ltd and was changed to Raptis Co. Pty Ltd. I have spoken to Mr Nick Manettas of the company in question. I have also spoken to John Diacopoulos, who is a lawyer. He has briefed me on two occasions. I have here correspondence which backs up what took place. I have here a telex signed by Mr John Diacopoulos cancelling the appointment after having been verbally advised that Manettas had been the successful tenderer.

On 3 August 1987 a Cabinet meeting was held, where the sale of the Fish Board was determined. The number of tenders started at eight and went down to four. It finally ended up at two. But Manettas won. That was on 3 August last year. On 6 August Bjelke-Petersen was back. He called a special Cabinet meeting and he overturned it. It was not just a change of heart. I have here a statutory declaration that outlines the corruption that existed at the highest level. It is a statutory declaration taken under the Oaths Act of Queensland. It says:

Mr Bedford claimed that . . . Mr Raptis had paid the sum of $250,000.00 to the Jo Bjelke Petersen Foundation, and the Premier of Queensland, Mr Jo Bjelke-Petersen, had then called his ``rump'' cabinet, and reversed his own Cabinet's decision, by awarding the tender and contract to purchase the Fish Board, to Mr Raptis's company.
It goes on to say:
I then phoned Mr Peter McDonald-
who honourable members would know was the private secretary of the then Premier-
(and I have a transcript and proof of this phone call and others) when I pleaded with Peter McDonald, that it was essential for the integrity and future fishing viability . . .

He goes on, inter alia, to ask whether Mr Raptis paid $250,000 to the Bjelke-Petersen Foundation. In a statutory declaration Peter McDonald says that Mr Raptis did pay the money. Here we have a statutory declaration, backed up by statements made by a lawyer, which is backed up by documentation by a public affairs accountant, that there has been corruption at the highest level. I have interviewed Nick Manettas and other people, and this decision apparently was made by Bjelke-Petersen. A full investigation is needed into the Bjelke-Petersen Foundation. It is run by a firm of solicitors, Flower and Hart of Adelaide Street, Brisbane. It just so happens that the daughter of Sir Edward Lyons-R. G. Lyons-apparently manages the Bjelke-Petersen Fund. There is a need for a full inquiry by the Fitzgerald inquiry or a judicial inquiry to match up the contract decisions in Queensland with the successful tenderers and also to match the donations to the Bjelke-Petersen Foundation.

Mr Ahern's bona fides are now on the political agenda. Did Mr Raptis donate $250,000 to the Bjelke-Petersen Foundation, as claimed under oath in this statutory declaration? When was this donation made? Was it made after a special meeting between Raptis and Bjelke-Petersen? What Ministers knew of the deal? What Ministers attended that special meeting on 6 August last year? Was Mr Ahern at that Cabinet meeting? Was Mr Harper at the Cabinet meeting? Why did they agree to change the terms of that decision to sell the Fish Board? Why did Raptis get prime land worth hundreds of thousands of dollars right on the river bank for about $100,000 and then get a monopoly of the fishing industry in Queensland? We have a right to know in Queensland. This is when we talk about freedom and rights.

Mr Harper, the Minister for Primary Industries, has now tried to get out from under. That man ought to stand down. There ought to be a full judicial inquiry. The terms of reference of the Fitzgerald inquiry must be expanded because Ahern's credibility is on the line. Corruption has been rife in that State for decades. It is not just the police. The main area comes back to government contracts. The key is the Bjelke-Petersen Foundation. If Ahern wants to set himself aside from the Fitzgerald inquiry, let him open up the Bjelke-Petersen Foundation. Let him open it up. Match the donations with the contracts that his Government, while he has been in Cabinet, has given to the rorters, the corrupters of that State.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is now adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

INTERJECT.PARA: (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House is of the opinion that attempts by the Leader of the Liberal Party in Victoria to undermine Melbourne's bid for the 1996 Olympic Games are unacceptable and extremely short-sighted.

I have moved this motion because of what was a fairly cheap attempt to score political points out of efforts to obtain the Olympic Games for Melbourne. In my view it was an attempt to take away from the campaign being conducted for the games. As we are all aware the Olympic Games in Seoul was an important point for promoting bids by Australia for the staging of the Olympic Games. As it was impossible for the Premier of Victoria to be part of the team promoting Melbourne's bid, the Victorian Minister for Sport and Recreation, Mr Trezise, went to Seoul to join with the Lord Mayor of Melbourne and other prominent Victorians to promote Melbourne as the site for the 1996 Olympic Games. Mr Kennett, during a visit to Geelong, in what I think was one of those efforts where his mouth was working but not communicating at all with his brain, said Mr Trezise should not have gone to Seoul but should spend the four days in Geelong. That was a stupid and unhelpful comment.

Mr Trezise left Australia on the Sunday of election week and was back in Australia four days later. He joined the group in Seoul to show that Victoria's bid was supported by the State Government and, I would have thought, all political parties in Victoria. He returned home almost immediately. He spent 50 hours on aeroplanes in four days. I think that it ill-behoved the Victorian Leader of the Opposition to try to score points on this issue, especially as it had no electoral effect whatsoever. Mr Trezise is not a person who occupies a marginal seat. He has been the member for Geelong North for 24 years and is well known to his electorate.

I do not want to use this time for the purpose of relating history. I want to advance the cause, firstly, of holding the Olympic Games in Australia and, secondly, of holding them in Melbourne which I think would be the most appropriate venue and which I think would be the most economic solution as far as Australia is concerned. Firstly I say that the Olympic Games is one of the greatest events in the human calendar. On the world stage it is pre-eminent. For the one-hundredth Olympic Games to be held in Australia would be a great asset and a great achievement for Australia and Australians-irrespective of which city were to be chosen.

It will be very difficult for Australia's bid to be successful because, quite obviously, Athens in Greece, the home of the original Olympic Games and the venue of the first modern Olympic Games, will be pre-eminent and have an enormous advantage over all other applicants. However, every Australian should unequivocally support the bid to have the games in Australia. The games will do enormous good for Australia on the international stage. I believe that Melbourne has the facilities, the capacity and the history of involvement both as a participant in and venue for sport in Australia to make it the obvious site. There is no question that Melbourne is the most pre-eminent city in Australia as far as any form of sporting endeavour is concerned. It is the most successful and has the best attended venues. At this stage it has the facilities which would enable it to conduct the Olympic Games without excessive outlays of public funds. Shortly a decision on which Australian city will go forward to the International Olympic Committee as the recommended site and the site supported by the Australian Olympic Federation will be made. Once that decision is made, every Australian should get behind the chosen city.

I think it is fair to say that Brisbane has made an extremely good job of running World Expo 88 and that most Australians are proud of that success. I believe that Melbourne has much to offer. I believe that for Victorians there is much benefit to be gained by the staging in Melbourne of the 1996 Olympic Games. The attention of the world is concentrated on the Olympic Games. The degree of publicity and international attention which will be generated could not possibly be purchased with any sum of money. For Australia the guaranteed success of the games in Melbourne, as has been the case with every major sporting activity that has ever been promoted in that city, will ensure that it achieves the recognition and the kudos that will come to it as the country staging those games, provided it is done with professional competence and with the full support of the public of this country.

It is my belief that nothing should be allowed to occur which would detract from Victoria's and Melbourne's efforts. As a Victorian it is my belief that it is essential that every effort be made to obtain the games for Australia. I believe that at the time the events referred to in this motion occurred, politics temporarily overcame the long term needs. I am certain that had Jeff Kennett been elected Premier, which he was not, he would have been leading the race to support Melbourne's bid. I believe that every Victorian wishes our bid success and appreciates the enormity of the benefits which will flow to our State if it is successful. If Victoria's bid is not successful, then an Australian bid must be supported no matter which city is chosen.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is there a seconder to the motion?
—I second the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shipton Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion moved by the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes) is one condemning the Leader of the Liberal Party in Victoria, Mr Kennett. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House is of the opinion that attempts by the Leader of the Liberal Party in Victoria to undermine Melbourne's bid for the 1996 Olympic Games are unacceptable and extremely short-sighted.

That is the motion the honourable member has moved before the House today. I believe that in so doing the honourable member has prejudiced Melbourne's bid. The honourable member is playing cheap politics by attacking the Leader of the Liberal Party, Mr Jeff Kennett, in Victoria and is prejudicing Melbourne's chances of getting the 1996 Olympics. He is playing cheap politics with Melbourne's bid for the Olympic Games. I think that is disgraceful. I had hoped that he would have come into this House and moved a motion that would have got bipartisan support from all Victorian members of both sides of the House, not only for Australia's bid, but for Melbourne's bid. But he attacks the Leader of the Liberal Party, and it is irresponsible and harmful to Melbourne's and Victoria's chances of getting the Games.

For a Victorian Federal Labor parliamentarian to raise this issue in this way in the wording of this motion at this time must make us ask whether the Federal Labor Party has deserted Melbourne and whether the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), a member for a Victorian seat, and his other Victorian Labor colleagues, support Melbourne's bid. We have a Federal Labor parliamentarian coming into this House and moving this motion, which is damaging Melbourne's chances of holding the Games. He has gone over the wrong ground and old ground and has raised issues that should never have been raised in the first place. The Victorian Premier, Mr Cain, must be cringing because of the motion that the honourable member for Corio has put before the House today. It does not advance Melbourne's bid; it harms and hurts the chances of that bid; in fact, it endangers that bid.

I hoped the member for Corio would have withdrawn the motion and that he would have needed the words of the Chairman of the Australian Olympic Federation, Australia's International Olympic Federation representative, and the Vice-President of the Olympic Federation, the world body, Mr Gosper, who said in September in Australia that politics should be taken out of Melbourne's bid for the 1996 Olympic Games. I agree with that. I hoped the honourable member for Corio would have agreed with that. But he has brought cheap politics into the debate again, and that is to be regretted.

Let me go over the Victorian Liberal Party's position. Mr Jeff Kennett, the Leader of the Opposition, on 9 August 1988-which was prior to the calling of the Victorian election-wrote a letter to the Lord Mayor of Melbourne, Councillor Lecki Ord. I will read it to the House. It states:
My dear Lord Mayor,
The Liberal Party of Victoria totally supports the City of Melbourne's bid to hold the 1996 Olympic Games in Melbourne.
Melbourne has the facilities required within easy reach of the City to professionally conduct the games.
Such an event would be in the interests of all Victorians and Australians.

Jeff Kennett has not equivocated from that position; he has not varied one iota from that position. In fact, the official position of the Victorian parliamentary Liberal Party is in the document that has been prepared by the Melbourne City Council and has gone to the Australian Olympic Federation as part of the bid. As I understand it, the Melbourne City Council understands clearly that the Liberal Party in Victoria is giving the Melbourne bid unqualified support. As I said, Mr Kennett has not equivocated at all. The bid has always had his total support. The former shadow Minister, Mr Tom Reynolds, was briefed throughout the building up and the preparation of the Melbourne bid and is totally behind it. The new shadow Minister, Mr Phil Gude, is totally supportive and is working with the Town Hall authorities in a bipartisan way to get the Games for Melbourne. As I said, the formal bid document contains the support of the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Kennett, in Victoria.

I think the honourable member for Corio had a rush of blood to the head during the Victorian election campaign and put this motion on the Notice Paper. I think he regrets it. I think he should have withdrawn it. Because of some little tete-a-tete over a local government policy issue during the Victorian election campaign which at that time was blown out of all proportion, he has gone over that ground again, re-raised the issue and, I think, prejudiced Melbourne's bid.

I think that there are good cities in Australia bidding for the Games. That is one point where I agree with the honourable member for Corio opposite; in fact, I agree with him about Melbourne. But I wish he had not raised it in this way at this time, prejudicing Melbourne's bid. Honourable members should read the honourable member for Corio's motion. Honourable members do not come into this House and move motions lightly. This motion states:
That this House is of the opinion that attempts by the Leader of the Liberal Party in Victoria to undermine Melbourne's bid for the 1996 Olympic Games are unacceptable and extremely short-sighted.

The honourable member for Corio has come into the chamber and attacked the Leader of the Opposition in a condemnatory way, when what all Victorian members on both sides of this House ought to be doing is getting behind Melbourne's bid and not prejudicing it in this way.

I happen to believe that there are three good cities. I just happen to live in Melbourne and think that Melbourne is the best contender. I think that Melbourne is the sporting capital of Australia; in fact, I know that Melbourne is the sporting capital of Australia. In Melbourne we get the greatest turnout of spectators for sporting events of enormous variety. We get the greatest number of participants in sports across the board. I think that makes Melbourne an ideal city to be the Olympic host. We have got the great Melbourne Cricket Ground, the scene of great cricket and football events. Great heroes have been on that ground. We had that great cricket ground as the host stadium for the 1956 Olympic Games where the new form of closing ceremony of the Olympic Games was evolved because of the spirit of Melbourne. The spirit of Melbourne has been carried forward from 1956 to all closing ceremonies at the Olympic Games, where all athletes from all countries mingle together with great emotion and feeling for peace in the world. I think that makes Melbourne the ideal city in which to conduct opening and closing ceremonies. It is a great track and field venue at which to hold the 1996 Olympics. I would say to those who are critical of Melbourne's bid that Los Angeles had very successful Games in 1984, and Los Angeles had hosted a previous Olympic Games and in fact beat the great city of New York for the bid to be the host city for the 1984 Olympics.

I think that Melbourne has a proven track record. It conducted the very successful 1956 Olympic Games all those years ago. But in Melbourne today there is fantastic community feeling and support for the 1996 Games. This was evidenced by the recent Totalizator Agency Board phone-in. There were some 12,000 phone calls and 40,000 people in Melbourne indicated that they would support that bid in a positive way and would act as drivers and would open their homes and let visitors stay with them and be volunteers generally during the Games. These are just some of the virtues of Melbourne, the great city. Melbourne does have the capacity. It has the facilities in the centre of the city. All the transport facilities lead into that central area and those venues around the Melbourne Cricket Ground and the tennis centre, which could be used for gymnastics, basketball and many other Olympic events.

Melbourne has great capacity. It has the venues, the sporting facilities, the transport system, the hotels and the hospitality to host the 1996 Games. I also believe that it would be the most cost effective city to host the Games, because we have in place those marvellous capital assets to which I have just referred-the Melbourne Cricket Ground, the transport system, the tennis centre and other great venues. For instances, an international rowing course at Carrum in Melbourne has just been built and it is an ideal place to hold the rowing and canoeing events in the 1996 Olympic Games. I regret that I had to rise today to speak on this motion because the honourable member for Corio has raised it in the wrong way at the wrong time.
