DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Aged and the Ageing-Nuclear Power-Taxation-Health Funds-Education-Helicopter Service Tender: Port of Gladstone and Hay Point-New Zealand: Anzac Frigate Project-Queensland Government-Telecom

PROCTEXT.PARA: Question proposed:
That grievances be noted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to participate in this grievance debate on this Thursday. I want to use this debate to say a word or two on behalf of those who are too ill, too frightened or too apprehensive to speak for themselves, namely, the aged and the ageing in our community. It is particularly significant that I should stand here in what is likely to be my last grievance debate in 1988, given the popularity of the grievance debates on both sides of the House to bat, effectively I hope, for those people who, in our bicentennial year, we must recognise persevered on our behalf, for those people who saw difficulties that my generation has never experienced, for those people who did without, for those people who fought for this country on our behalf, for we have inherited all that they did for us.

SPEECH.PARA: In the last five years the aged communities have been forgotten by the Hawke Government. They have been attacked by the Hawke Government with things such as assets tests and taxes on superannuation. Nowhere has this been more acute than among veterans who fought on behalf of every Australian to keep the nation free. They have been subjected to an unprecedented attack from the present Administration. We are indebted to the aged in our community. Even if one were to view them from a purely cynical political viewpoint, they would be an increasingly important part of the make-up of the Australian community. The reality is that in our bicentennial year we recognise that people live longer now than they have at any other time in Australia's history. By the year 2010 the number of Australian people over 45-I will be one of them next year-will be between 8 1/2 million and 8.7 million, or 40 per cent of our population, a rise of 70 per cent in that proportion in 21 years. In fact, the number of people over 80 will go from 2 per cent to 5 per cent of our population by the year 2031.

I recognise that the Government, sensitive to what will be the electoral backlash of what has been termed grey power, has announced the results of the Professor Cass inquiry into the ageing in our community and has, in response to the by-election results in Adelaide, Port Adelaide and Oxley, set up the Hawke aged task force comprising, I am pleased to note, from this side of the House the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt), the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman), the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Katter) and the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson). This is nothing more than window dressing.

I want to elaborate on two experiences in my rural electorate of Wakefield which further reinforce the cruel uncertainty the aged face. The real care that the Hawke task force for the ageing may ultimately inject into the Parliament will be not only overdue but also too late. Aged people have a choice to remain in what has been the family home, to move into a retirement village which, from their point of view, will frequently be self-funded, or when age and sickness no longer allow them to be independent, to move into a hostel and ultimately into a nursing home.

In my electorate there is increasing confusion and an increasing shortage of facilities and nursing home beds for the aged. But the Government has currently been obsessed with what has been called the HACC program-the home and community care program-designed to take the pressure off nursing home beds. On this side of the House there is no criticism of the concept of a HACC program which allows aged people to maintain some independence. It is not wrong to have a HACC program. The problem is that the Government is currently blinkered with what has been its HACC program and is refusing to address the demands in electorates such as mine for an expansion of additional hostels and nursing home facilities. The honourable member for Richmond put it well when he said that the term HACC could well stand for hopelessly and completely confused.

In my State of South Australia-the State of the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett), who is at the table-the aged have, in a sense, been penalised because the performance of groups supporting them in the past has been so good. Nowhere is this better illustrated than in the town of Burra in my electorate within the CURB boundaries established by the State Government. Because Burra sits in a CURB boundary, people presume that there are sufficient beds for aged care. I acknowledge that the Minister for Community Services and Health has been very receptive when I have spoken to him of what is happening in the Burra community. He recognises the geographic isolation of Burra and the fact that the CURB boundary area unfairly penalises the people of Burra. In fact, two years ago, he was realistic enough to indicate that he was prepared to exercise some discretion in funding an additional aged care facility in the Burra area. Unfortunately, an election intervened.

I now find myself standing here grieving on behalf of the Burra community because people there are still denied the nursing home beds and the hostel facilities that they need and that they proposed as part of hospital redevelopment in Burra. They are still a football between State and Federal governments, and the answer is still unresolved. Still we wait for the South Australian Health Commission to make a decision.

If that were not bad enough, I take honourable members from Burra, an isolated community in my electorate, to Gawler, South Australia's oldest country town, and the major growth area in my electorate. Only last week I had representatives from Mr Max Powell, the proprietor of the James Martin Village in Gawler. He came to me with a dilemma he faces as he endeavours to address the demands of the aged in that area. By any standard anywhere across our nation James Martin Village is a modern, reputable, sought after retirement area. The James Martin Village combines both hostel and nursing home facilities on one site. In fact, there are retirement village independent units on the site as well. Mr Powell discovered that the cost of separating individual operations in one village between the retirement village, the hostel and the nursing home is becoming a nightmare. He has no flexibility and has been shown no tolerance by the Department of Community Services and Health. His plea over many months has been for the Department simply to lay down some guidelines for the way in which a multi-facet facility such as his should operate. I propose to put some questions on notice to the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples) later this week to illustrate the absurdity of what is happening to villages such as James Martin.

I am using this grievance debate to highlight what has been Mr Powell's frustration with the Department. He has sought from it, over a long period, nothing more than a response to reasonable correspondence that he has submitted on behalf of the people who reside in his village. It started on 11 July of this year when he wrote. He wrote again on 19 July and on 8 August he followed up with another letter. All of those letters sought a response to his original request for a review of the way in which the James Martin village currently goes about funding and meeting the demands of its residents. There was still no reply in August and on 22 August he was forced to add:
Under the circumstances I have no alternative but to seek a personal interview with an officer of your Department at the Adelaide Office within this current business week.

It is now November and still there is no response from the Department. Well might Minister Staples come to terms with what is happening in his Department and what is happening to the disadvantage of aged people in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McHugh Ms J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in the grievance debate today to alert the Australian public to some very disturbing news that has been coming out of the United States (US) in recent weeks. The public is about to be subjected again to a campaign to convince it that nuclear power is safe. That campaign arises because worldwide concern about the consequences of the greenhouse effect is demanding that we consider alternatives to the current means of producing energy throughout the world. People are starting to say, `Why not turn to nuclear power?' Because, I suppose, it is a few years since the Chernobyl accident and the subject of nuclear safety has simply been off the front pages, the public has begun to accept that everything must have been sorted out, that the nuclear industry has at last solved the problems and that we had better accept the assurances of the industry. There is a general unease about nuclear power-that is not contested-but people are unfortunately not often in possession of the facts. Let me then take this opportunity to alert the public to some of the facts, because nuclear power is no alternative.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite repeated claims by the industry that serious accidents are unlikely to happen, information now escaping into the public arena in the United States shows that accidents are occurring within the nuclear industry, and have been over the past three decades. There has been a massive cover-up by successive US administrations and the industry to make sure that the public did not find out. In spite of their efforts to deceive the public, accidents are being uncovered and in many instances they are being uncovered by congressional committees and government officials and as a result of workers in the industry going on strike for better safety conditions. Let me instance some of them that have been revealed recently in Australian newspapers.

Thousands of tonnes of radioactive uranium waste have been released into the environment over the decades by a nuclear weapons plant in Ohio. Government officials have admitted that they did nothing about all the dangerous waste which got into the water supplies and into the Great Miami River. How was this discovered? By testimonials before a Congress energy and commerce subcommittee. According to reports published in the New York Times, several congressional committees are now scrambling to expose the problems of America's nuclear weapons industry. The question needs to be asked: Why have the industry and the government turned a blind eye to these problems rather than revealed them to the public? Some alarming facts are now being revealed: shoddy equipment, poor maintenance, human error and hushed-up accidents. All of these are disclosures from congressional testimony. And the workers in the industry are now taking the matter of safety very seriously indeed.

At the Fernald plant in Ohio, 600 workers went on strike demanding better wages and safer working conditions. At the Savannah River plant in South Carolina, where the Energy Department claimed there had been no significant accidents in the plant's 30-year history, it has now been revealed in documents released by the company which operated the plant, that there had indeed been 30 serious accidents since the 1950s, including one that involved partial fuel meltdown.

There is in Fernald a plant called the Feed Material Production Centre, which most locals thought made cattle fodder or cat food, but in fact it has been processing uranium for the last 30 years. Because of faulty exhaust air filters, this same plant had allowed the release of more than 200,000 pounds of radioactive oxide dust into the atmosphere over three decades. It is of no surprise to those who have the facts that residents in the area have very high incidences of cancer and other diseases.

Amid all these recent disclosures about mismanagement, safety violations, accidents and environmental contamination, a search has begun, authorised by Congress, to find the American victims of the atomic bomb-that is, those people who lived around the Hanford reservation where uranium was first turned into plutonium in 1944. It has been revealed recently that Hanford managers have allowed radioactive emissions to be released from the stacks and they let this happen for two decades. During their experiments over the years, huge doses of radioactive iodine were released; in fact, in all, 530,000 curies. The practice was well documented but kept secret and became public only when an environmental group forced the Government to release 19,000 pages of documentation under the Freedom of Information Act.

According to neighbours who live east of the Hanford Reservation bomb factory, of the 108 people who lived in 28 homes within a mile of the highway, 23 men, women and children have become ill or have died from cancer since the mid-1950s. Seven other children in the area died as infants or are handicapped. Further east, there are higher than normal incidences of thyroid diseases, well documented and well acknowledged by the locals.

In Britain it was revealed in the Wise magazine of January 1988 that after 30 years we are only now learning the truth about the fire at the Windscale nuclear complex in 1957. Official documents now released reveal that fire broke out in atomic piles used to produce weapons grade plutonium. The cloud of smoke coming from the fire that raged for 16 hours contaminated large areas of Britain and Ireland and contained 600 times more radioactive iodine than the Three Mile Island disaster. Since the fire dozens of people who lived, worked or who were holidaying at the time have died or are dying of leukaemia and other cancers.

Why did the Government keep the true extent of the accident a secret? Could it be that if the public were made aware of the facts they might make sure no more nuclear plants would be built? There has been widespread alarm in the public worldwide since Chernobyl about the whole of the nuclear industry. The public must continue to demand greater accountability from the industry and from the Government; but it is no use if it is too late.

Now, despite all these problems, there are people who are wanting to expand the world's nuclear power program to solve the problems with the greenhouse effect. It is no solution, certainly not in the long term. Uranium, after all, is a non-renewable resource. What happens when it eventually runs out? In any event, why offer as an alternative to the problem we have, a procedure which has so many unresolved problems of its own, problems that probably will never be solved, such as the problem of waste? That is something that we are leaving with the world for the next several hundred thousand years. No-one knows what to do with it.

Then there is the problem of nuclear proliferation. Why go into an alternative power source which has inextricable links with the nuclear weapons industry and which could give the world the nuclear winter certainly comparable to the greenhouse effect in terms of disaster? What about the cost of nuclear power? It is by far the most expensive form of power, even if it worked efficiently and safely, even if there were no messes, no accidents to clean up. Then there is the issue of safety, the one about which we are given all the reassurances.

There is in this morning's Australian Financial Review a letter by David Hamer, who described safety in the nuclear industry comparatively. He says that it has had a bad press since Three Mile Island and Chernobyl; that if there was an accident in a coal mine killing 30 miners and a hydro-electric dam collapsed killing 1,000 people they would be regarded as unfortunate accidents; but if one person was killed in a uranium mine there would be mass demonstrations in the streets. The point is that around a nuclear power station people are at risk.

Safety in nuclear power just does not mean safety amongst the workers at the stations. It means the safety of an entire community. Surely Chernobyl taught us that. What these recent revelations show is that we cannot accept the reassurances of the industry because we do not always get the truth. Who in Australia would want a nuclear power plant in his or her neighbourhood? If nuclear power is even to be suggested as an alternative to coal-fired power stations, that means here in Australia too because the greenhouse effect is a worldwide problem. It requires international cooperation. It means nuclear power stations in Australia.

So the debate here will no longer be about whether to expand or restrict the mining and export of uranium; it will be about whether the Australian public can be convinced to adopt nuclear power and to have facilities built near them. With the continuing dishonest record of the industry, particularly in the United States, as revealed recently, I am sure I know what the response of the Australian public would be to that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prosser Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, our laws are fraught with inconsistencies and anomalies, none more so than our taxation laws. Indeed, I have already presented a private member's Bill to this House to correct an anomaly in the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act 1935. There is another inconsistency which should be acted upon, this time contained within the Bank Accounts Debits Tax Administration Act 1982; but I am, of course, prevented from doing so by standing order 293, which preserves financial initiatives of the Crown. Essentially, this principle ensures that the Government, and no-one else, should be in charge of the purse strings. The principle behind this stems from section 55 of the Constitution.

SPEECH.PARA: Nonetheless, I am certain that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) will accept that this anomaly does exist in the debits tax and, hopefully, he will take steps to abolish it. The bank accounts debits (BAD) tax took effect on 1 April 1983. It was no April fool's joke, and remains with us today, albeit under an abbreviated title of debits tax. It is a tax which generally imposes a small financial burden each time it is imposed but which, in aggregate, represents a significant cost to the community. This financial year it is expected that $360m will be raised from the debits tax collections. Perhaps the old acronym of BAD for the tax really is a more appropriate title. That represents virtually a 100 per cent increase compared with the first full year's revenue from the BAD tax of 1983-84.

This has more than a little to do with the fact that on 1 December 1986 the Government increased most BAD tax rates by 50 per cent. Of course, it is not the only example of the Government's greed for higher taxes and levels of taxation. Indeed, this Government's reputation as the highest taxing government in Australia's history-the government which has made the average Australian $56 a week worse off-is firmly on record.

I want to concentrate now on the debits tax anomaly itself. Generally, people think the debits tax is a tax on withdrawals from bank accounts. Certainly, that is what the original name of bank accounts debits tax suggests. But the relevant legislation was opened up last year to snare withdrawals from accounts held by other financial institutions, particularly building societies and credit unions, and hence the slight name change. Although the banks and building societies are both caught up, under the legislation, their treatment at the hands of the Australian Taxation Office differs.

As a result of last year's legislative change, subsection 3 (1) of the Bank Accounts Debits Tax Administration Act now contains a two-part definition describing the type of account to which the debits tax applies. The second part, which was a completely new addition to the Act, refers to accounts operated by non-bank financial institutions, which involves the use of payment orders. I quote:

An account kept with a non-bank financial institution . . . being an account to which payments, by the institution in respect of payment orders drawn on the institution by the account holder . . . or by one or more of the account holders . . . may be debited.

At the time of these amendments, it was thought the building societies would make extensive use of payment orders. These were a new financial instrument intended to operate in much the same way as bank cheques, except that they would be drawn against accounts with non-bank financial institutions. The debits tax would then be charged against the value of each payment order used by the customer; in fact, building societies have not followed this course, as had been expected. Although many societies offer cheque facilities, these cheques are operated via a third party, that third party being the bank. The first part of the definition of `taxable accounts' refers to bank accounts with cheque facilities:

An account kept with a bank . . . being an account to which payments by the bank in respect of cheques drawn on the bank by the account holder . . . or by any one or more of the account holders . . . may be debited.

So in the case of banks, debits tax applies to withdrawals of money from cheque accounts. In the case of building societies, it impacts on withdrawals from accounts involving payment orders. It follows that building societies which, instead of using payment orders, operate cheque accounts for their customers, via a bank, incur debits tax at the point each cheque is presented to the bank for payment. In today's competitive environment, financial institutions must pull out all stops to attract customers. This has included the provision of multi-access accounts, which are savings accounts that can be operated in a number of ways.

Separate cheque and savings accounts are not the only option today, as more and more banks and building society customers opt for multi-access accounts. Indeed, it is now commonplace for savings accounts to involve the use of cheques and plastic cards. In 1983, when the BAD tax became a reality, the use of plastic cards and automatic teller machines was not the commonplace occurrence that it is today. As these combined accounts became increasingly popular, a discrepancy in the BAD tax law reared its head. Consider two people: one has a building society savings account with a cheque facility and a plastic card; the other has a bank savings account with similar multi-access facilities. When the building society customer uses his plastic card to withdraw money, debits tax does not apply. After all, he is not withdrawing money from an account which incorporates the use of payment orders. As such, his account falls outside the definition of taxable accounts held by non-bank financial institutions spelled out in the Bank Accounts Debits Tax Administration Act.

However, the account used by the bank customer is a different kettle of fish; that being a bank account, the legislation provides for it to be subject to the tax if there is a cheque facility attached to the account. As our customer has a multi-use account, including a chequebook, all his withdrawals, not just the cheque, will attract debits tax. Our two customers could be on opposite sides of the same street using their respective automatic teller machines to withdraw money. One will pay tax; the other will not. Clearly this is an unfair anomaly.

However, it can be easily resolved in one of two ways. The legislation could be extended to cover all withdrawals from building society accounts which have cheque facilities, including non-cheque withdrawals. Alternatively, debits tax could be abolished in respect of non-cheque withdrawals from bank accounts. Clearly, the original intention of the BAD tax was to levy cheque debits. As I have explained, it is merely a matter of historical development in the retail banking market that has caught non-cheque debits as well. The present situation clearly was not the original intention of Parliament. Indeed, during the second reading speech of the legislation, the Treasurer at the time stated:

Debits resulting from cheques drawn on an account . . . as well as other debits made to an account . . . such as for periodical transfer payments and for the charging of interest to bank accounts . . . will be subject to the tax. Debits to current accounts held with trading banks will be the primary subject of the tax.

The multi-facility accounts I have discussed are, of course, savings accounts. To correct this anomaly fairly, it is necessary to relieve bank customers of the need to pay debits tax on non-cheque withdrawals. Two methods of achieving this objective are possible. Firstly, the legal definition of `exempt debit' could be extended, quite simply, to ensure that only debits made to multi-access bank accounts by cheque were subject to the tax. Alternatively, a new regulation, issued under section 62 of the Bank Accounts Debits Tax Administration Act, would provide swifter relief to bank customers.

Unfortunately, correcting this anomaly will not dent the massive reduction in living standards imposed by this Government. However, it will provide some relief to the thousands of bank customers, especially low income earners and pensioners. To many of these people every cent in every dollar, carefully accounted for, makes a difference. Earlier this week the Australian provided us with a sharp reminder when an anonymous author-a pensioner-wrote that he could not even afford to buy margarine to spread on his bread. Quite frankly, Mr Deputy Speaker, Australians deserve better than this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleeland Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have heard two interesting speeches so far in this debate this afternoon from members of the Opposition. The honourable member for Forrest (Mr Prosser) calls for a further reduction in Commonwealth revenues of $360m. Add that to the abolition of the capital gains tax, the fringe benefits tax substantiation and immediate tax cuts to pay as you earn taxpayers and the revenue base of the Commonwealth goes down by a couple of billion dollars at the least. On the other hand, we heard the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) make an impassioned plea for increased benefits to the aged of this country, a call which I totally support. I wonder what the honourable member for Wakefield, the honourable member for Forrest and those other members opposite who keep calling for tax cuts do when they get into their party room and try to match their rhetoric with the demand for increased expenditure.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian people should never forget that this is the Opposition which in the last election called for a $16 billion cut in Commonwealth expenditure but, despite being asked, refused to give any detail of where that $16 billion should be cut. Honourable members opposite would not say, for example, that the aged and the frail would not suffer massive dislocation of benefits being currently paid to them. Yet the honourable member for Forrest and other members opposite call for massive tax cuts. The question that the honourable member for Wakefield must surely ask is: Where is the money coming from to pay for the sort of increased benefit he calls for for members of the aged sector?

Interestingly, my particular concern and grievance today concerns the aged and the frail in our community, particularly those aged and frail people who for all of their working life have paid moneys into the private health insurance system of this country, and particularly those who have paid moneys into the Health Benefits Association (HBA) of Victoria. At a time in their life when they need recoupment from the private funds to which they have contributed all of their life, the health funds are now saying in Victoria, `Bad luck; because you are now a drain on our investments we no longer want to pay the money out, and instead the Commonwealth Government now should pick up the tab despite the fact that you have paid for private insurance all of your life'.

This is a very recent occurrence in Victoria. In particular, in my electorate it concerns two bush nursing hospitals, the Euroa Hospital and the Nagambie Bush Nursing Hospital. Bush nursing hospitals are unique institutions in the world. Bush nursing hospitals are those necessary facilities which exist in rural Australia and which, very largely, have been built by capital contributions from the rural dwellers themselves. Bush nursing hospitals have made very little demand upon capital from State or Commonwealth governments to provide those facilities. As any honourable member who has anything to do with rural Australia well knows, they are financially supported very strongly by the people in the communities where they are.

Bush nursing hospitals fulfil a multitude of purposes in rural Australia. They provide an immediate refuge for those who are ill and need immediate patient care, be they aged or young. All bush nursing hospitals in my electorate provide acute beds for particularly acute caring need aged patients. If the honourable member for Wakefield is fair dinkum he will go into his party room and knock the nonsense on the head of getting tax cuts and call for increased tax, probably, in order to provide the sort of benefits he wants to see the aged get in this country.

I support him on that because there is no doubt that in our rural areas our aged are suffering. It is also true that no Commonwealth Government is going to have the financial capacity necessary to ensure that all of our frail aged in rural Victoria in particular, or in rural Australia, are going to have the kind of capital expenditure incurred in those areas to build the number of nursing home beds that this country will want. That is what makes it so damning on the private health funds for the actions they are now taking.

I draw the attention of the House to a particular constituent of mine who is presently in an acute bed in the Nagambie Bush Nursing Hospital. She is now 90 and a full quadriplegic, requiring drip feed to maintain life and 24-hour acute nursing care. She has paid into HBA for over 30 years of her life. I am told by the hospital that she has never been in hospital before in her life. Under current rules of the private funds after 35 days in an acute bed, if the patient is an aged person, he or she belongs in a nursing home.

The reality is that in country areas we are never going to have nursing homes in every rural town. That means aged people in rural areas have the option of being sent many miles away from the areas where they have lived all of their lives and where their friends and relatives are presently living, to a home where they are strangers, surrounded by strangers and where they are no longer part of the community in which they have long grown up.

Bush nursing hospitals, traditionally in Victoria, including my electorate, provide acute beds for those frail aged to spend the rest of their lives at least in the area where they have always lived. But now the Hospital Benefits Association says it will not pay. It will not pay at all. Despite the fact of 30 years contribution to the private fund it will not pick up the tab. The Commonwealth Government is going to have to pick up the tab. What is to be done with a 90-year-old quadriplegic woman requiring drip feeding and 24-hour acute accommodation in an acute bed, be it in a bush nursing hospital or any nursing home? Does it really matter? Is it not more important that that person remains in the community where she has lived all of her life? Is it not equally important that if you have paid into a private health insurance fund for your life, at the time when you require a return on that investment the health funds should, in fact, pick up that cost?

I find it criminal and alarming that the health funds now in Victoria are taking the view that if you are young and if you are healthy they will provide health insurance for you. We all know that those aged over 50 use the majority of medical health services in this country. The situation is arising in this country, with our private health funds, that when you are young and are an actuarial risk you will not require any withdrawal from the insurance fund you are paying into; it will give you cover. At the time of life when you are starting to demand medical services at an increasing rate and you have contributed to one of those private funds, it will dump you.

The House should well be aware that private health insurance contracts are for a 12-month duration only. In other words, the private health funds have the option upon themselves, at the end of each 12-month cycle, of saying they will no longer insure you. I wonder how honourable members opposite who give calls to help our aged and who also support user pay principles on medical health care relate that to their calls for increased assistance to the aged. I wonder how those on the other side who want to get rid of Medicare equate that with the actions of the private health funds in Australia. I wonder if, in fact, the Opposition members really understand what is occurring in rural Australia with services that the aged in rural Australia are increasingly requiring and in this country should automatically get.

I quite frankly would like to see the day when there are no longer any private health funds because they are only distorting the health system. They do not care about the aged, they do not care about providing universal health services. They are concerned primarily with profit. Why should they not be concerned with profit, because they are profit motive organisations?

TALK.START.PARA: —You can't be serious.

—If the honourable member opposite who is interrupting had listened to me earlier, perhaps he could explain to the 90-year-old woman who has paid private health care cover for 30 years of her life why, when she is in an acute bed in a bush nursing hospital, the funds says, `We are not paying for you because you are now a permanent care patient. The Commonwealth picks up the tab'. Perhaps he can explain to that 90-year-old woman what has been making that contribution for 30 years of her life and has never gone into hospital before. What is the value then of the private health system? Perhaps he can explain that, not just to my constituent but to young Australians who believe that by paying for private health insurance they will be covered. He cannot explain that to them because he knows the health funds are interested in profit and profit only, not in providing proper health care services to the people of this country.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, may I say that I am pleased that the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples) when this was drawn to his attention made an unequivocal promise to the people in bush nursing hospitals in Victoria who are being hit by the private health funds in this way that they need have no concern, that whatever happens this Government will pick up their costs and will ensure that the proper care and attention they need in acute nursing homes or in acute bush nursing hospital accommodation will be covered. I am proud of that action by this Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia is a modern industrial nation with the potential to develop into a leading technologically advanced society with enhanced economic, social and cultural prospects for all its citizens. However, this progress will not occur automatically. Neither is there unlimited time for its pursuit and successful achievement. Australia's future prosperity will depend on our willingness to push back the frontiers of knowledge, to exploit new alternatives, to experiment with new solutions and to adopt proven advancements. But economic advancement is not enough.

SPEECH.PARA: The extent to which we use our prosperity to widen and deepen our culture and to improve the quality of our lives will depend greatly on our capacity to provide our youth with a sound liberal education both at school level and beyond. A strong, dynamic, expanding and forward looking higher education system is therefore central to Australia's chances of realising its proper destiny into the twenty-first century.

Mr Deputy Speaker, higher education in Australia in 1988 is at the crossroads. In terms of a broader national interest, such an educational system should contribute to our economic development through growth of exploitable knowledge, stimulation of imagination, innovation, entrepreneurship and industry. It should contribute to our social development by helping to nurture mutual respect amongst free individuals, to safeguard personal freedoms, to promote tolerance and to champion excellence in human endeavour. Finally, it should contribute to our cultural enrichment through the study of our intellectual and artistic heritage and the advancement of knowledge and achievement in the humanities, the arts, the sciences and the technologies.

Furthermore, for the higher education system to meet these expectations, it must enjoy the confidence of its students, the academic staff and the community as a whole. It must also have assured sources of funds for expansion where appropriate and for continuing improvements in quality. Additionally, each institution should have sufficient freedom to determine its own direction and goals subject to reasonable systems of public accountability for the use of taxpayers' funds.

In the secondary schools since 1982, the proportion of students who go through to form 12 has leaped from 36 per cent to about 53 per cent. While parents have encouraged children to stay at school to qualify for jobs in a competitive market, the additional students who complete form 12 now confront a new bottleneck. This year perhaps 20,000 students could not find a place in higher education. In Queensland the disappointment was especially high.

Since 1945 the number of students in higher education has risen from about 50,000 to 400,000. This massive industry, with its sizeable bureaucracy, costs the taxpayers about $2.8 billion a year. It is therefore sensible to ask whether the money is well spent. Clearly, our nation's economic circumstances call for a revitalised system of higher education. In my view we should be concentrating on our greatest natural resource-our young people.

A more effective higher education system is central to efforts to innovate industry, to raise work force abilities and to guarantee rising living standards in the future. Higher education must provide an environment of expanding opportunity, to satisfy the demands of young people and others seeking to enhance their careers and to broaden their knowledge. The great challenge is to expand the capacity and to improve the quality. In recent years, difficulties have emerged. There have been insufficient places to meet the demand of otherwise qualified students. Without access to sources of funds other than those provided by the already sorely pressed taxpayer, institutions have not only been incapable of meeting demand but have also developed serious capital works and maintenance backlogs.

The low rate of growth in the system has not provided adequate career opportunities for existing and prospective academic staff and has not generated sufficient funds for research activities. Inflexibility in academic remuneration has led to severe shortages of suitably qualified staff in areas of greatest demand and a loss of gifted academics to other employment in Australia and overseas.

Finally, the capacity of institutions to respond flexibly to change in the external environment and to upgrade their standards of academic and administrative performance has been reduced by inappropriate internal structures and excessive governmental regulation. The Government's solution lies principally in what some have referred to as the iron fist in the velvet glove approach of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) wherein public tertiary institutions will be invited-and I use that word cautiously-to join a new unified system which will largely remove the distinction between colleges and universities and wherein all public institutions are invited to submit educational profiles setting out their broad objectives plus a whole range of details on student loads and intakes, teaching duties and a willingness to achieve national priorities including equity.

If the Dawkins proposals are accepted in toto we will have: firstly, an even greater weight of central government regulation on the system; secondly, under the unified national system the government will require institutions to negotiate for funds directly with the Department of Employment, Education and Training in Canberra and, in effect, institutions will compete with each other for favours from the government; thirdly, the forcing of amalgamation between institutions without adequate regard to the economic or educational benefits of that amalgamation; fourthly, the Government has also moved to take more direct control over research and higher education by earmarking an increasing proportion of research funds for projects decided by government to be in the national interest; and, fifthly, the Government is attempting to introduce a higher education contribution scheme, the so-called graduate tax, which fails to take adequate account of such matters as part time students in employment, the scheme's failure to return tax collected to higher education institutions and the probability of confusion and/or abuse of the system.

Predictably, there is a plethora of views on the Dawkins proposals. I support some, although I reject his principal philosophical thrust towards further centralisation of political and bureaucratic power in Canberra. We already have far too much of both. The Vice-Chancellor of Melbourne University, Professor David Penington, is fearful about the intrusive and over-regulatory implications. In a recent speech he described the White Paper as heralding `the imposition on Australian universities and Australian science of a period of unprecedented political interference and central regulatory control virtually unknown elsewhere in the Western world'. The Minister for Education, Youth and Sport in Queensland, Mr Littleproud, had described the Dawkins changes as giving increased purse strings power to Canberra and the unified national system as a big brother club with which institutions must conform or they do not become members.

There seem to be four major objectives in the higher education package put forward by the Minister. The first one is that there should be substantial growth; secondly, that there should be improved equity of access; thirdly, that there should be resources for the growth that is expected; and, fourthly, that the institutions should be made more accountable for the public money they spend. They are all very reasonable and laudable objectives. However, I believe there is a major contradiction in the Government's package.

Currently there is a charge of $263 a year for students entering universities and colleges of advanced education. That $263 annual charge is now to be replaced by an $1,800 annual charge. Nowhere is there any analysis whatsoever of the disincentive effect of applying the $1,800 a year charge on students. In other words, there is an objective of expanding higher education, of making it more readily available and of improving equity and access to a higher education, yet the annual charge for the student is to be increased dramatically.

I do not believe that higher education is the preserve of the relatively privileged in Australia. It has been possible, over the years, for people of relatively modest incomes to enter higher education. By what stretch of the imagination could a massive increase in costs to students be said to improve the access of the underprivileged? Without an adequate answer to this question the whole package is flawed.

I believe that the so-called graduate tax is objectionable philosophically, that it provides a significant financial disincentive for students from low and disadvantaged families and from a practical perspective is unworkable administratively. Like John Ward, the Vice-Chancellor of the University of Sydney, I also oppose moves in the educational sphere that result in-I use his description-`strangulation by regulation'. On the other hand, I welcome aspects of the Dawkins proposals which will bring higher education in Australia into a more modern era.

I favour any higher educational system that will restore a sound funding basis and that will give State governments greater responsibility for planning future development in our States. Much that Minister Dawkins wants to achieve in higher education is sensible and a good deal of what he proposes will help. However, there is a serious danger that his cure will be more painful than the disease and may even kill the patient. The issues are therefore both practical and philosophical. I hope that in introducing the Higher Education Funding Bill later today in this place, the Minister will provide comfort to the many thousands of students and academics with whom his proposals do not sit easily at present.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtice Mr B.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to bring to the attention of the House a case in relation to a tendering contract involving Lloyd Aviation Group, which is based in Gladstone in my electorate. The Group believes it has been unfairly treated in a contract with the Queensland Department of Harbours and Marine. It feels that the Department ignored quoted prices and has shown favouritism to a company called Helispray. On 19 September Lloyd received from the Department of Harbours and Marine an invitation to quote on providing a helicopter service for the transfer of marine pilots at the port of Gladstone. The quote had to be received by the Department of Harbours and Marine by 5 p.m. on 23 September 1988.

SPEECH.PARA: Lloyd prepared a submission and hand delivered it to the offices of Harbours and Marine on the 22nd Floor, 41 George Street, Brisbane, before 6 p.m. on 23 September. The submission was placed in the tender box indicated by the receptionist as the correct place for the submission. On 26 September the managing director of the Lloyd Group contacted a senior officer of the Department to ascertain the result of the submission. He was told by the officer that the contract had been given to Helispray because the Lloyd Group had not submitted a quotation.

The Group understandably objected to this description of the sequence of events. It was then informed that the Department did have the quotation and that it was substantially lower than the other one submitted, but because Helispray had already been advised by telephone of its winning bid, the Department said it was too late to do anything about it. The Lloyd Group appealed against this and a request to have the quotation considered was denied. This is the second time the Group believes it has been unfairly discriminated against by the Queensland Government.

In 1985 it successfully tendered for providing a helicopter service for the transfer of marine pilots at the port of Gladstone and Hay Point. After being advised of its successful bid, and before the commencement date of the contract, Lloyd was advised that the Hay Point section of its contract was taken from it and given to Helispray, which was one of the unsuccessful tenderers. According to information presented to me, the manager of Helispray boasted at the time that he had contacts in the Department of Harbours and Marine and that it would eventually give him the Gladstone contract.

I do not know whether the gentleman has a crystal ball or just has wonderful foresight, but the Helispray company was subsequently given the contract. According to the information available to me, the Helispray company could not comply with the commencement date of the contract on 1 October. The Lloyd Group was then asked by the Department to fill in for it until it was ready. Lloyd was told that this was to be two weeks. I am also advised that Helispray was unable to abide by its commitments to the Hay Point contract for six months. I would like to call on the Queensland Minister for Water Resources and Maritime Services, Mr Neal, to launch an immediate inquiry into the letting of both of these contracts.

I have referred the matter to members of the Public Accounts Committee which has recently been established in Queensland. It appears that the tradition of jobs for the boys, established by the Bjelke-Petersen Government with government contracts, is alive and well under the Ahern Government, if the information is correct.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is shameful.

—As the honourable member for Bowman says, it is shameful and it is a sad indictment of the Government in Queensland. My colleague the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) was hounded by the Police Commissioner, Mr Lewis, under the Bjelke-Petersen Government when he released information about a contract on the Stanwell power station. I do not expect the same reaction to this disclosure because members of the clique who were hounding the honourable member for Capricornia have either resigned in disgrace or have had their deeds exposed in the Fitzgerald inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: The Queensland Government certainly needs to look at its tendering process. How is it that a company which has the lowest tender misses out on a contract? How is it that having won a contract fair and square the Lloyd Group has part of that contract removed from it by a company which could not handle the contract for six months? How is it that even in this latest contract scandal the group is advised that its submission is lost only to resurface when it is too late to do anything about it?

The people who are the real losers out of this are not only the Lloyd Group and its employees and their families; they are the Queensland taxpayers. Because more taxpayer funds have to be allocated to this project, there is less money to spend on other services for Queensland families. In central Queensland there is less government money for basic services like education and health; there is less money to provide adequate medical staff. At the mining town of Moura in my electorate-everyone knows the dangers of the coal mining industry-there has been difficulty attracting adequate medical staff.

All schools throughout central Queensland suffer lack of adequate support staff and it places great pressure on parents and citizens. The Boyne Island and Tannum Sands region needs a high school. The shonky tendering arrangements in Queensland departments mean that parents and children in areas like Boyne Island and Tannum Sands have to wait while enough funds are appropriated for them. As I said, the letting of this contract has occurred under the Ahern Government.

It appears that the Ahern Government is permitting the use of the sleaze factor when it comes to the letting of contracts. It is up to the Queensland Minister to investigate fully these contracts and ensure that justice has been done. The efficiency of letting contracts is crucial to achieving efficiency in government as a whole. It is incredible but true that after 20 years in State Parliament, eight of them as a Cabinet Minister holding senior portfolios, Mr Ahern had no economic strategy to roll with when he became Premier. Nothing happened until March, when Mr Ahern announced he was spending $400,000 of public funds to buy a strategy from private consultants.

All other State governments have come up with their own economic development strategies from their own resources and have put them into effect. Mr Ahern has had a run around the State offering a $400,000 reward to discover a strategy and he still has not been able to track it down. In the meantime, Queensland's economic performance is crying out for a comprehensive and coordinated strategy. Mr Ahern and his Government need look no further than contract letting suffered by the Lloyd Group to understand why decent businesses will not touch his Government with a barge pole and as a consequence the Queensland economy is suffering.

We need a clear signal that from now on all contracts will be weighed on their merits. There should not be a wink and a nod to mates. One should not need a National Party membership dangling out of the pocket to pick up contracts. A stamp of decency can be placed on government dealings by reviewing the contract arrangements in the Lloyd case. The matter should be investigated immediately.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise in these few minutes the question of the New Zealand participation in the Anzac frigate project which has had some publicity today. For some time New Zealand has been backing and filling on this particular project and we see more in reports from New Zealand today where Mr Lange has reportedly warned his Cabinet that Australia is at last getting tough with New Zealand about its participation in this project. It is high time that Australia took a much tougher line with New Zealand on this project.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the reasons that New Zealand has been soft and will not make up its mind, will not indicate whether it will be there, is that every time it hesitates the Australian Government and the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) in particular say, `Do not worry about it; we will sweeten the pot. We will ensure that you get a preferential deal. We may delay payments. We may offer you no interest payments. We will meet the development costs'. So it goes on and on. If one is sitting in New Zealand and every time one hesitates the Australian Government offers a better deal, of course one will sit back and keep on sitting back and sitting back until finally one might hope that the Australian Government will give the frigates to New Zealand.

This is not an acceptable position for this country to be in. The Government should have been much tougher over recent years with New Zealand and told New Zealand that since the days when it opted out of its ANZUS responsibility it simply has not been pulling its weight. It has cost Australia a great deal of money because New Zealand has failed to meet its responsibilities.

We have to exercise separately with New Zealand because obviously some of the old ANZUS exercises are not possible. New Zealand has opted out of that and of course America will not exercise with New Zealand. We now have to process information separately so that some of that information that comes to us is reprocessed and then sent to New Zealand. So it already has cost us a great deal of money. New Zealand has opted out of ANZUS virtually without penalty and this is the problem because the present Government in New Zealand has said, `Look what we have done. We have taken this view on nuclear or nuclear capable warships visiting this country. We have given away our ANZUS responsibilities, but we have done it without penalty. Australia has picked up the tab'.

It is not just a matter of exercising separately with New Zealand and the extra associated cost. If New Zealand will not meet its ANZUS responsibilities it throws a greater burden on us in Australia to do our share; for example, patrolling in the south-west Pacific. Whichever way one looks at it, the New Zealand failure to meet its responsibilities is costing Australia more and more. Plus the fact that in due course if we are ever in a tight spot in this part of the world, New Zealand under its present Government is regarded as an unreliable ally.

I think it is time to speak very frankly to the New Zealanders. It is time to say to them, `You have got to measure up, you have got to bear your own responsibilities'. I find it very sad, as someone who has served in two theatres of operations with New Zealanders, to have to get up in this Parliament and say, `You are not pulling your weight'. I did not think that we would come to this situation with our oldest and closest ally. I do not believe that the majority of New Zealanders agree with the particular approach that the New Zealand Government is taking. I think it is high time, it is beyond time, that the Australian Government said quite clearly to New Zealand, `We are prepared to help to a degree. We want you in this Anzac frigate project and we are prepared to help to a degree'. It is very important that we maintain the closest relationship with New Zealand for the security of both countries.

The Government should be saying to New Zealand, `If you keep going down this neutralist, pacifist line, if you will not bear your proper responsibilities, if you will not come into this Anzac frigate project, as proud partners pulling your weight, there is a limit to our patience and our tolerance and there is certainly a limit to the amount of money that Australia is prepared to contribute to subsidise New Zealand in this project'. It is a pity those sorts of words had not been said some time ago and if they had been spoken frankly by the present Australian Government three or four years ago, telling New Zealanders where it stands, we would not be in the mess that we are in today and New Zealand, in particular, would have known that when it opts out of its responsibilities there are penalties involved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sciacca Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to make today a bash Queensland day, or at least bash the National Party in Queensland day, but unfortunately the shenanigans that the National Party State Government gets up to at every available opportunity never cease to amaze me. My grievance today concerns the use by the Queensland State Government and, in particular, its Health Minister, Mrs Leisha Harvey, of Federal funds under the home and community care (HACC) program for blatant, cheap, political propaganda purposes. I see the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) at the table. If he cares to listen he will see that it is not only the Labor Party members and the Federal Labor Government which has been shafted, but also the Liberal Party State members in Queensland. So I would suggest that he listen very closely.

SPEECH.PARA: I am disgusted at the sleazy tactics being used by Queensland Health Minister Harvey in the distribution of funds which are provided jointly by the Commonwealth and State governments for the purpose of home care of the aged and disabled. The home and community care program was set up by this Labor Government in July 1985 to help the more frail elderly people and younger disabled people to stay at home instead of going into residential or nursing care. Funds are provided to the State government departments and authorities, local councils and community organisations to pay for the services.

These include home help and personal care, home maintenance or modification, food services-for example, the Meals on Wheels organisation-community respite services and transport services. Since its inception I understand that some $700m has been provided by the Commonwealth under the program and no-one would question the obvious worth and benefit of this excellent scheme. However, as has been the case for many years in my State of Queensland, the National Party State Government, presently embroiled in controversy over allegations made at the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct, is using the program to protect its own discredited political hide.

A recent Auditor-General's report found that in Queensland apparent inconsistencies occurred in the way the State Government approved projects against the recommendation of the Federal department. As a result, big grants went to projects and electorates held by, guess who, none other than Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen, now no longer holding the seat of Barambah but still around the place I understand, and, of course, his big cohort, Mr Russ Hinze. So moneys were being spent in these areas for obvious cheap political purposes.

Mr Deputy Speaker, after the startling allegations by the Auditor-General and, more importantly, after the cronyism exposed at the highest level of the Queensland State Government by virtue of recent revelations at the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct and, in particular, the famous Lewis diaries, one would think that Mr Ahern and his Ministers would have learned something. But no, they have learned absolutely nothing. The reality is that the present Ahern Government in Queensland is no different from the Bjelke-Petersen Government, and no amount of rhetoric by Premier Ahern can ever dissociate him from a government of which he and most of his present Ministers formed an integral part. The honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice), the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Lavarch) and the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Johns)-all my Queensland colleagues-know exactly what I am talking about.

The actions of Queensland's Health Minister Harvey in this matter lay testimony to what I am saying. In the 1987-88 year, 60 per cent of all funds spent in Queensland under this program were contributed by the Federal Government. The State Government administers the program on behalf of the Commonwealth, and the State Health Department in Queensland has the job of forwarding the payments quarterly to the respective recipients. Until recently, the usual procedure was for bureaucrats in the State Health Department to issue organisations with their yearly allocations of funds on a quarterly basis. This, of course, is the proper way of doing business. Now this situation has been reversed.

If an organisation exists in an electorate held by a Labor member or a Liberal member, it receives the quarterly payments from the State Health Department; but if the organisation concerned is in a National Party electorate, its local National Party member gets to big note himself and hand the cheque over, usually in front of the publicity machine that he has organised. That is disgraceful.

Sometimes an oblique reference is made that part of the funds comes from the Commonwealth Government, but in more cases than not no reference to the fact that more than one-half of the funds come from the Federal Government is made. The idea, of course, is to deceive the recipient organisation, its members and its clients that the Queensland State Government is the sole benefactor. This is political sleaze of the worst kind. It is outrageous and it is typical of the way the Queensland State Government has done business in the past, continues to do business at the present and, if allowed, will continue to do in the future.

Health Minister Harvey has obviously directed her Department not to forward quarterly cheques to anyone other than National Party members. The cheques are presented quarterly, so that every member in a State National Party electorate gets four opportunities per year per organisation to get his pickie in the paper handing out our dough. To emphasise my point my own electorate of Bowman is in exactly that position. Thankfully, I have only one State National Party member in my electorate; the others are good Labor blokes. The Attorney-General, Mr Clauson, is in fact that National Party member. In three months his face has been appearing in my local newspaper handing out HACC moneys on seven different occasions. I have all the details here. He appeared on 30 August 1988, 6 September, 6 September again-he had two bites at the cherry on that day-30 September, 30 September again, 20 September and 26 October. In the case of one particular recipient--

TALK.START.PARA: —You should be glad that the money is going into your electorate.

—The honourable member for Maranoa should know all about this, because he is part of that show up there. In one particular case, obviously the Queensland Attorney-General's media machine mucked it up, because he actually got two stories about the same $83,000 to the one nursing service. I have all the details here. One article says, `Money for meals-a little extra soup'. It is absolutely unbelievable stuff, and frankly, Mr Deputy Speaker, the Queensland State National Party should be absolutely ashamed.

SPEECH.PARA: What concerns me most is that the continual publicity will cause harm to the fund raising activities of these organisations. The public perception will be that there is no need to buy the raffle tickets or to attend fund raising activities, because they are being well looked after. Not only are the State Government and Mrs Harvey being less than honest, they are harming the organisations simply to pick up a few lousy votes and a lot of unwarranted kudos. The members involved in this charade ought to be ashamed of themselves.

I am sick of National Party members in Queensland continually kicking this Federal Labor Government on the flimsiest of excuses and then deliberately using our funds to mislead the community. I am sick of seeing this accident prone and incompetent Minister and her cronies playing Santa Claus with our money. I am particularly concerned that her actions in the administration of funds under the HACC program and in turning this very worthwhile program of helping our aged community and young disabled people into a cynical political exercise simply to gain votes could jeopardise future Commonwealth and State cooperative health funding arrangements. I think that is the sad part of all of this.

I have discussed this matter with the Minister for Housing and Aged Care, Mr Peter Staples, who knows that that is going on. He tells me that unless we receive some complaints from the local organisations, under the agreement he has no power to do anything about it at this stage. I can say that I am not going to allow it to proceed. I will be very vigilant in seeing that she does not continue. I call on her to stop this seedy practice immediately and to cease using the elderly, the frail and the disabled as mere political tools in some sort of cynical public relations exercise.

I might just say in conclusion that if we are to look at that recent decision by a judge of the Supreme Court or one of the courts in New South Wales that nobody who gives out these cheques can be eligible to sit in a House of parliament, it would seem to me that there would not be one National Party State member in Queensland who would be entitled to hold a seat. The honourable member for Maranoa ought to take note of this, because a constitutional crisis is exactly what he would be looking at. I say to the Queensland Health Minister again, `Do something about stopping this terrible exercise, because all you are doing is making an absolute idiot of yourself and you are using moneys that belong to the Federal Government for purposes for which they were not intended'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bilney Mr G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to commend the Federal Government's adviser on the acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS), Professor Tony Basten, and the National Health and Medical Research Council for their recommendation to relevant State Ministers for a radical trial program to provide heroin on prescription to selected intravenous drug users. Under that plan heroin would be given to users in single-use syringes in a program to combat the spread of AIDS. This is a radical but, in my view, well conceived measure which is bound to create great interest worldwide.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members will know that intravenous drug users are the main bridge between those groups which are known to be at high risk of contracting AIDS and the general community. Blocking that bridge is therefore a key measure to reduce the risk to ordinary people of becoming infected with the AIDS virus. In New York it is the case that something like 85 per cent of intravenous drug users are AIDS infected. Contrast that with a group of intravenous drug users in Liverpool who recently went through a somewhat similar heroin prescription program where AIDS infection remained at levels of only one per cent of those involved. If we in Australia get to the same stage as New York, increasingly the AIDS virus will pass from intravenous drug users to their sexual partners, including their heterosexual partners, and from them into the general community so that ordinary people who have had no direct contact with the drug scene or with other high risk groups will be affected.

In this country we have a year, maybe two years at the most, to find a way to stop that happening. It is not a case of prevention being better than cure; there is no cure, so prevention is all we have got. If this program also leads the way to taking the profits of hard drug distribution, it is a good thing too.

Fine, I am not a member of the League of Rights but if there is to be an inquiry into the League of Rights, what about an inquiry into the Seamen's Union, which has ruined Tasmania? What about an inquiry into some of these left wing unions? We should fight harder on this issue. We have allowed the honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Griffiths) to institute an inquiry into the League of Rights. I do not know anything about it; I am not a member of it. Yes, I am right wing and I am proud of it but I am not one of them. But why not an inquiry into the Seamen's Union?

SPEECH.PARA: Why not an inquiry into some of the Socialist Left unions that predominate in Australia today and have ruined Tasmania? They have made our freight not affordable. Why not? We should say, `Right, you are going to institute an inquiry into them, why not an inquiry into some of the socialist organisations, the left wing organisations, that predominate in Australia today?'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise a matter which is of concern to me and my electorate. Perhaps I could suggest to the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) who just sat down that he might remember that his Party started an inquiry into the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, and look what happened to the Western Australian branch of the Liberal Party.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to raise problems of funding of the methadone program in the Geelong area. A number of persons would wish to participate in that program. Unfortunately, there are very few pharmacists who have been prepared to cooperate or become involved. My understanding is that the administration of the program in that area is less than satisfactory. My major concern, however, is that funds are not available in the area at the same levels for treatment as they are in metropolitan areas.

I want to raise in this House the need for provincial cities to be considered when these programs are being advanced. Certainly, the four pharmacists who have taken part in the program in a city the size of Geelong are overworked and overloaded and are not prepared to expand the program. I think it is urgent that action be taken to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to continue my complaints against Telecom and also against this Labor Government which has forced Telecom to take out commercial interest rates and has therefore delayed our installation of STD telephones. There are hundreds of subscribers in the electorate of Maranoa who still do not have an STD telephone. Most of that is to do with the fact that this Labor Government has forced Telecom on to commercial interest rates. Of course, commercial interest rates are now running at record levels and it is an absolute scandal.
—Order! It being 2 p.m., in accordance with sessional order 106a, the time for members' statements has concluded.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I refer the Minister to his statement last night on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's 7.30 Report that he had sacked eight Aboriginal Development Commission commissioners to ensure a tightening up of the ADC's decision-making. Is it not a fact that the new commissioners he appointed decided to provide new funding packages for at least two of the three most disastrous ventures of their predecessors and that this was done at the Minister's request?
—I think you had better resign, Gerry.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hand The Hon G.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Never. The question leads to whether I was involved, I guess, in decisions made by the new commissioners, and I take it that the honourable member was referring to the three now famous cases of the Woden Town Club, the Oasis Hotel and the Nardoola pastoral property. I think my position on the Woden Town Club is well and truly known. I should point out for the benefit of the House that the offer, and the documentation of the offer that has been alluded to in the media via the Senate Estimates Committee, has never formally been sent to that organisation. The offer has now been withdrawn and the matter will be reconsidered at the next meeting of the commissioners. In terms of Nardoola and the Oasis Hotel, because of the speculation around the building I will take the time of the House to address briefly both of these matters together, if I may, and the implication in the question about my interference.

ANSWER.PARA: During the early part of this year I travelled widely around Australia on what is now known as the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) consultations. Following each of those meetings there would be discussions with community groups, which is the normal practice for Ministers in my portfolio. At a big meeting at Moree-about 200 or 300 people-a reference was made to Nardoola. At Walgett, a reference was made to the Oasis Hotel at the main meeting but there was no discussion about it, because the purpose of the meeting was to discuss ATSIC. Afterwards I met with a large delegation of people. On my return I met with the chairperson of the ADC, Shirley McPherson. That meeting took place at 7 p.m. on 16 March 1988. At that meeting I relayed to her the views that were put to me by both of those groups. On 14 June I wrote to the chairperson, addressing her as `Dear Shirley', raising again the question of Nardoola at Moree and the Oasis Hotel at Walgett. In that letter I said:
On my return to Canberra I met with you and outlined the concerns of the community and asked you if the Commissioners would review their decision.
Just for the record, I make the point that at my meeting with Mrs McPherson I asked her what was happening about the Oasis Hotel. The response was:

We can't give it to the Barwon community because of their creditors. As soon as we give it to them the creditors will pounce. We are looking at putting it out to lease until Barwon get their house in order.
We have asked for it to come up again . . . was originally opposed to it.
Mrs McPherson named the person but, for the record, I will not use the person's name-
We will probably give it to the Land Council.

The reason I have said these things is that a flood of material is beginning to circulate around the place, obviously with the aim of embarrassing me, Mrs McPherson, the old commissioners or the new commissioners. I am not quite sure whom it is intended to embarrass, but someone is attempting to embarrass somebody. It is not uncommon for Ministers in my position to relay-in fact, I hope all previous members who have held this portfolio did this-to the relevant authority, department or statutory body the concerns expressed to them by the Aboriginal community which they are charged with servicing. In my letter I draw attention to the need for economic management to be adhered to and to the need to examine critically the performance of the enterprises, et cetera.

TALK.START.PARA: —But that was the reason they were proposed.

—Just a moment. The fact is that, in terms of the Oasis Hotel, I met with Mrs McPherson on the 27th-I think that was the day after the Estimates committee meeting, last Thursday-and she confirmed our discussion of 16 March. I met with the commissioners on the Monday of this week. Again, she confirmed our discussions. I draw to the attention of the House the fact that an implication has been made by a particular individual that I somehow influenced the change of decision. My letter--
—You wrote them a letter.
—The honourable member should listen to what I have to say. My letter to the commissioners is dated 14 June. The decision by the new Board was made on 23 May. That decision was:

ANSWER.PARA: At the Commission meeting it was resolved that no further action be taken regarding the disposal of this property until the matter was discussed in full at the next meeting.

I do not back away from representing the views of my constituency to the appropriate statutory authority. If honourable members care to examine other letters I have written in the same vein, with no authority to interfere in the individual decisions being considered, they will note that those matters have been responded to by the Commission, whether they concerned a house someone was trying to purchase, someone's inability to get a loan, a question of rent arrears, et cetera. I refer those matters to the relevant authorities. It is interesting to see that the honourable member for Gwydir, who has an interest in this area, was reported in yesterday's press as having said that the new arrangements concerning the Oasis Hotel are much better than what was in place before.

TALK.START.PARA: —Makes the best of a mess.
—The honourable member agrees. The fact of the matter is--

—If honourable members opposite want to ask these questions, I think it is fair that I get the chance to answer them. The point is that, in respect of my raising the question of the Oasis Hotel with the commissioners in recent times, there was a decision to hand over to a particular community, but that decision depended on certain things; namely, a lease arrangement to a proper management body. I queried with the commissioners whether that proposed lease time was sufficient to ensure that adequate management, the best management, was brought in. The position I put was agreed to by the commissioners and has now been relayed to the relevant group that is dealing with the ADC. There is nothing improper about that, and I make no apology for it. The honourable member for Gwydir quite rightly has shown a very substantial interest in both these properties. I do not depart from my earlier position that both of these proposals have been a financial mess. They have been. But one goes back to 1982--
—So is the Labor Government.
—It was not a Labor government, so let us not try to score too many points about whose fault these things were.
—You always become bipartisan when you are in a jam.

—Mr Acting Speaker, I can assure you that I am not in any jam at all. That will be reflected in the examination of the ADC by the Auditor-General. I have no fear from my point of view about the Auditor-General's inquiry into the ADC.

ANSWER.PARA: In terms of the Oasis Hotel, again there has been a long, sordid and bad history. What we are trying to do here, and what the ADC has been trying to do, is to rectify that. I think the discussions that the honourable member for Gwydir had with his constituents yesterday are an example of how we are trying to address these things in a proper way.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister will be aware of the very considerable concern throughout the world about the damage to the ozone layer that is creating the greenhouse effect.
