Like most of us, he will be better informed after the fascinating dissertation on the subject on Tuesday by his colleague the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business. Whilst I commend the Government on its initiative in sponsoring an Australia-wide conference on the potentially disastrous impact of the greenhouse effect, I am sure that he will agree that any action Australia may take will have minimal effect unless the whole world is involved. In view of this Government's proud environment record, will the Prime Minister give consideration to sponsoring a worldwide conference in which academics, the business community, politicians, conservationists and the general public can be involved?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I can assure him, as I think he knows is the case, that the Government attaches a great deal of importance to obtaining a better understanding of the greenhouse effect. I take the opportunity of informing him and the House that the Government has initiated a review to find out exactly what the range of existing research is in this country and the potential in the light of that review for further research. I give the honourable member an unqualified undertaking that if out of that review of what is being done and the potential for further research it appears that more funds should be made available to enhance that research, that will be done. I think the honourable member will also be aware that the Commission for the Future has organised a series of Greenhouse 88 conferences around Australia, which are being held this month.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable member may also be aware that at the recent meeting of the South Pacific Forum I made the offer, which was gratefully accepted by the Forum island countries, to finance a study of the greenhouse effect in the region and, in the light of the outcome of that study, to finance the establishment of monitoring stations in some of these countries which, as the honourable member will appreciate, may be particularly susceptible to the effect of rising ocean levels. I made an offer not only to establish those stations but also to undertake the training of people from those Forum island countries actually to man those stations and to analyse data that would be obtained from them. I think the honourable member can see that Australia is therefore taking a prominent leadership role in the region. It is a role which, as I say, has been appreciated by the Forum island countries.

I can say to the honourable member that the Government would be willing to consider any proposal that may come from any international organisations to promote further cooperation and understanding of the greenhouse effect and, if possible, responses that would be appropriate to that effect. I say to the honourable member that his proposal for an international conference in Australia has merit but it would need to be considered in the context of the overall efforts to which I have referred and to other possible options for work on the greenhouse effect. I think the honourable member will appreciate that it is quite possible that the impact, and therefore the responses, may be different for countries in the Northern Hemisphere from those in the Southern Hemisphere. I can say to him-and I think he will appreciate this point-that obviously we will be in a better position to consider the merits of hosting an international conference in the light of the review that I indicated I have initiated. I repeat that that review is calculated to give the Government the clearest possible understanding of the range of work that is currently being done, whether in private or in academic or government sponsored institutions. Once I have a clear picture of the actual research and the potential for further work, we will be in a better position, I suggest, to consider the proposal that has been put forward by the honourable member. I thank the honourable member for his proposal. I can assure him that I will keep it in mind in light of the review that I am having undertaken at present.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. The Minister will be aware that in a written response which has now been received from a question on notice asked in Senate Estimates Committee E, it appears that none of the acting commissioners of the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) appointed by him, including the Secretary to his Department, has lodged the obligatory declaration of pecuniary interest. The Minister will also be aware that in an answer to another question asked before the Senate Estimates Committee it appears that the Secretary to his Department, quite apart from being the Chairman of the ADC-funded Woden Club, is apparently also a director of another club in Canberra, the City Club, a club which was involved in selling poker machines to the ADC-funded Woden Club. A few moments ago the Minister advised the House of the reliance he is placing on the inquiry into his Department by the Department of Finance and the Commonwealth Auditor- General. In the circumstances of the obvious doubts as to the integrity of the Secretary to his Department in view of the facts to which I have referred, will the Minister now require the Secretary to his Department to stand aside so that there can be no doubts as to the integrity of that inquiry? And if not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hand The Hon G.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the right honourable member's question is no.
—At this stage?

—No. I will make an additional comment, if I may. A series of accusations and innuendos has been levelled against a whole lot of people. I want to draw the House's attention to yet another. In the Katherine Advertiser--
—Just answer the question.
—Order!
—The Katherine Advertiser stated:

ANSWER.PARA: Katherine's Aboriginal Affairs Department has been labelled corrupt in `several areas' CLP Senator Grant Tambling said this week.
Speaking in Canberra Senator Tambling also linked the Barunga Aboriginal Festival with Cuba and Nicaragua.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Speaker, I take a point of order. We are most anxious to see relevance maintained in this place.
—Order! Is the honourable member for O'Connor drawing my attention to a standing order?
—The Minister is referring to a matter that has nothing to do--
—Order! There is no point of order. The honourable member for O'Connor will resume his seat. I call the Minister.
—If you refer to Katherine- Mr ACTING SPEAKER-The Leader of the National Party will cease interjecting.
—I will address the question of pecuniary interests. I will make inquiries and I will inform the right honourable member about that issue in the very near future.
—You do not have to make inquiries.
—Order! I warn the honourable member for O'Connor.

—But I want to stress one point: many accusations have been made about individuals publicly and in the Senate Estimates Committee. Here is another one where the whole of a group of people working in our office have been branded as being corrupt. People have accused the whole of the work force in the Department of being corrupt. I have said, and I will say again, that if an example is brought forward of where corruption has occurred that matter will be dealt with, whether or not it concerns the last person put on the payroll or the Secretary. I will say again: any person who has evidence of corruption, malpractice or any other of these wild accusations should put up or shut up. On the question of pecuniary interest--
—We have put up.
—Order! The Leader of the National Party will cease interjecting.
—I will address that question and report to the House.
—My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. What is the Government doing to ensure that the high quality and effective work of the Public Service receives full recognition and support?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I hope that the view that I express on this matter will be shared by all honourable members. I think it is a fact that the Government has been singularly well served by the professionalism, dedication and sheer hard work of the Australian Public Service. The honourable member knows as well as anyone-I have at times had to persuade him of the absolute necessity of some of the things we have had to do-that tight budgetary restraint has been an essential element in the restructuring of the Australian economy. In this period of restraint, it should be obvious to everyone, the task of the Public Service has been made much harder. It has had to do much more and it has to do it with less. It is a fact that in the last financial year, 1987-88, we reduced staffing in the Public Service by 1 1/2 per cent while at the same time providing extra resources in priority areas, such as cracking down on welfare fraud and enforcing the tax laws of this country. The efficiency scrutiny process alone, under the magnificent leadership of David Block, led to the introduction of reforms worth a total of some $100m in savings in a full year.

ANSWER.PARA: I take great pride-and I hope that this is shared by all honourable members-in the fact that the very significant reforms we have made to the structure and the practices of the Australian Public Service have improved its accountability, enhanced its professionalism, led to greater equity within the Public Service, and provided maximum scope for individual initiative. The aim of all these things has been to ensure that the Public Service becomes increasingly an effective instrument for the achievement of the broad economy-wide changes that are necessary in the interests of enhanced economic prosperity and greater fairness in Australian society.

There is no doubt that the Public Service of this country-I am talking particularly of that area under our direct control, the Federal Public Service-has responded magnificently to the challenge of working more effectively, more efficiently and more productively. As I said last week in the Garran Oration, we are all singularly fortunate at this time, when the challenge of change is before all of us, that we have a Public Service which has both the character and the capacity to assist us in rising to that challenge.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Prime Minister. I remind him of the remark just made by his Minister for Aboriginal Affairs that any person who says he can produce evidence should put up or shut up. I refer the Prime Minister to his answer to the Parliament last Tuesday when he said that `there was no cover up' of the evidence of `serious allegations of maladministration which may lead to criminal prosecution' referred to in the reports of the inquiry of the Standing Committee on Expenditure into the Aboriginal Development Commission. Given that standing order 340 provides that matters not reported to the House shall not be published by any person unless authorised by the House, how did the Prime Minister arrive at that conclusion without having seen the evidence? Further, how can the Prime Minister keep his promise made on AM the other morning in regard to this matter when he said, `There will be a full investigation of all allegations made', when yesterday his Government defeated on party lines the Opposition motion to authorise disclosure of this information to the Minister and his investigators?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to the first part of the question, I was able to give that answer because the simple fact is that the attitude and the policy of this Government have been from day one, and will continue to be for the very long time that we will be in government, that we do not need to cover up anything.

—That attracts the giggle response of the Leader of the Opposition, which is all he is capable of these days. Just keep giggling, John. That will do us fine. It will make sure that he stays on the other side of the House, even if not in the position of leading the Opposition. In regard to the question of full investigation, I have nothing to add to what I have said before. The fact is that there will be--
—There will not be a full investigation.
—The Leader of the National Party will cease interjecting.
—Well, there will not be.
—I warn the Leader of the National Party.

—The fact is, as will be quite apparent from everything that transpires from this point, that there will be a full investigation of every allegation that is made. The fact that the people on the other side of the House express their prejudices in a particular form is no substitute for evidence or proof. If they delude themselves that some propositions that they may include in some resolution will determine the way in which proper, fair and full investigations are conducted, they have another thing coming. We do not need to learn from them anything about integrity or the conduct of government business. We have had the opportunity of looking back on seven years of their performance in government. Whether we look at questions of integrity, questions of incompetence or questions of relevance, they get zilch out of 10 on every phenomena that we might apply.

ANSWER.PARA: We will stand on our record. Our record shows, as I have said, no cover-up and no attempt to cover up in any area of the administration of this Government. The fact is that all the issues in question will be investigated. If any action has to be taken, it will be taken. We will do that on our own resources and without any assistance from the bunch of incompetents opposite.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy aware of the serious drought situation in the Eyre Peninsula and the far west of South Australia? Can the Minister advise the House of the Commonwealth's response to the deprivation and suffering of the people affected by the drought?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Grey for his question. Both he and the South Australian Government, particularly through Mr Kym Mayes, the Minister of Agriculture, quite regularly bring this matter to my attention and that of Senator Walsh. There is a very bad drought in that area, just as there has been a very bad drought problem in some of the marginal wheat areas of Western Australia over recent years. Just as in some parts of Western Australia farmers have had only three crops in 10 years, in some parts of the Eyre Peninsula and the far west coast of South Australia farmers have had only two crops in the past eight years. Parts of Queensland have also been enduring a very bad drought, but not so much in crop growing areas. It is a very serious problem. There is not much chance for diversification. There are no permanent water supplies. Infrastructure costs, by definition, are quite high in that area. With such a drought record, existing mechanisms, quite frankly, cannot cope with the situation and threshold decisions have to be taken as to just how much public money should be expended.

ANSWER.PARA: At present, parts of the Eyre Peninsula and the far west coast are experiencing one of their worst seasons on record. That has had a very severe impact on a number of families, from both financial and social points of view. People might not like my using the word `marginal', but I do that in a geographic context. Where farms at the margin have no utilisation for agriculture, by definition they are marginal, but that is not to say that many of these areas have not had very good crop records in the past.

The Commonwealth Government provides assistance for drought relief under the natural disaster relief arrangements once State expenditure on approved measures reaches a certain level. In South Australia's case it is $8.12m. The approved measures include subsidies for carry on loans and stock and fodder transport. The South Australian Government has decided to use the money available to it under the upgraded rural adjustment scheme that the Commonwealth announced last May to provide long term assistance to viable farmers to improve their operations and to non-viable farmers who decide to leave their farms. Under that new rural adjustment scheme from 1 January there will be additional measures that will help, that will give the State rural adjustment authorities a lot more flexibility. For example, instead of using simple debt restructuring they will be able to enter into capital restructuring of some of the badly affected farms. The South Australian Government has also announced a number of other initiatives, including the waiving of stamp duty on the purchase of non-viable farms, meetings with banks to develop joint strategies, and the provision of emergency household assistance. This represents a comprehensive, innovative package of initiatives by the South Australian Government in keeping with its well-deserved reputation for innovation in the rural assistance area.

The Commonwealth is also helping, through the announcement last week of a grant of $33,000 for the far-west rural support group under the rural counselling program. Some of the measures under that scheme will include debt mediation and will give people the chance to get together to see what they can do on their own behalf. I acknowledge the representations by the honourable member for Grey in support of this grant. I also acknowledge the honourable member's representations on behalf of his constituents seeking an upgraded water supply west of Ceduna, through my colleague Senator Cook and the Federal water resources assistance program. My portfolio colleague, Senator Cook, is planning to visit the area to discuss this issue with the local community. It is clear from all these initiatives that the Australian Labor Party, both at the State and Commonwealth levels, is prepared to act in the long term interests of the honourable member's constituents and he deserves a great deal of credit for ensuring that outcome.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is supplementary to that asked by the honourable member for O'Connor. I ask the Prime Minister: How can the Parliament believe his assurance that there will be a full investigation into the Aboriginal Development Commission matter when his Government is clearly unwilling to look at some of the relevant evidence?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is up to the Leader of the Opposition and those behind him as to what they believe and do not believe. I must say to him that it is a matter of supreme indifference to me what he and his bunch of irrelevants believe. They are characterised by prejudice and irrelevance. What they think or do not think matters not one iota to me or to those behind me. What does matter is that the people of this country can have absolute confidence in the fact that this Government will, as it has said through the Minister and me, conduct every inquiry that needs to be undertaken to investigate all the allegations. That is followed by the undertaking that, whatever comes out of those investigations, whatever action needs to be taken will be taken without fear or favour.

ANSWER.PARA: That will distinguish this Government from the previous Government. The previous Government set up a royal commission. What did it do with the results of that royal commission? It had the Prime Minister getting up in here, with its full support, and rubbishing the royal commissioner when he indicated that what should have been done was for one of its Ministers to be sacked. It appointed a royal commissioner and then abused him, to protect its own Minister. It was the greatest cover-up in the Federal history of this country. That is what the former Government did: it set up a royal commission and abused the royal commissioner. As distinct from those on the other side of the House, we will investigate the matter and if action is required it will be taken.

TALK.START.PARA: —I preface my question to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training by noting, with pleasure, that the Minister will be opening stage 5 of the Mount Druitt Technical and Further Education (TAFE) College in my electorate in western Sydney tomorrow. I ask the Minister whether he is aware of recent reports that the Government will extend the higher education contribution scheme to cover students at TAFE institutions. Can the Minister clarify the Government's position on this matter in the context of its overall policy approach to TAFE and training? Can the Minister inform the House of any recent contributions to the development of policy in this area?

—Mr Acting Speaker, I raise a point of order. I draw your attention to standing order 144 (b), secondly occurring, which relates to the announcement of government policy. Clearly, the honourable member for Chifley has referred to the development of government policy. He is asking for an announcement of that policy on a new development. He should be ruled out of order.
—Order! The honourable member for Chifley was also asking the Minister a question about the TAFE in western Sydney. The Minister can answer the question as it relates to matters of fact.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr ACTING SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Deakin will cease interjecting.

INTERJECT.PARA: Mr Beale interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I warn the honourable member for Deakin.

—It is true that tomorrow I will join with the State Minister for Education in the opening of the new part of the Mount Druitt TAFE. I congratulate the honourable member for his close interest in this project. Of course, this is an example of the Government's policy in action of improving and extending the TAFE system throughout Australia. The honourable member asked me about some suggestions of the extension of the higher education contribution scheme to TAFE. That was a deliberately misleading suggestion by the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Deakin. He knows that it is wrong. He knows that the Government has specifically ruled out any extension of the higher education contribution scheme to TAFE.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable member also asked me whether there have been any contributions to the debate about TAFE policy. I can refer to one contribution which emerged yesterday. After a year of inaction and four shadow Ministers, we have been promised a frenzy of policy development on the other side of the House. Indeed, yesterday a TAFE policy was produced. It seemed to me to be a little familiar, so I went back to the TAFE policy that emerged 12 months ago. Let me read from the first sentence in the policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Speaker, I take a point of order. You will recall that when you called the Minister to respond you referred to the fact that he might answer the question so far as it related to a matter of fact.
—And not to matters of announcing government policy.
—That is correct. The Minister is not now referring to government policy!
—The Minister is--
—He cannot be referring to it per se.

—Order! As the Leader of the National Party knows, the Standing Orders say that Ministers should not use Question Time to announce government policy. If the Leader of the National Party listens, I think he will find that the Minister is talking about the Opposition's point of view and contrasting it with his.
—I am surprised that the Opposition does not want me to read out its own policy, but let me proceed. The first sentence of its policy of a year ago was:

ANSWER.PARA: Australia is entering an exciting period of challenge and change.
So I went to the first sentence of the new policy and found:
Australia is entering an exciting period of challenge and change.

It may be that it has passed the Opposition by, but we have had at least 12 months of excitement and change in the area of TAFE policy. That was not the only similarity in the policy. In fact, it is identical in every significant respect. I underlined all the bits that were a dead pinch from the policy of a year ago and as honourable members can see, the entire document is underlined. It is perfectly true that the only thing that was overworked on the Opposition's side in terms of producing this policy was the photocopier. Indeed, I understand that the policy adviser of the honourable member for Deakin is nicknamed Xerox. The point is that not only is this policy purported to be a new one and therefore is at the best misleading and at the worst fraudulent, but it is a reproduction of last year's policy. Because of that it is riddled with the most extraordinary errors. It just has not taken account of the blistering pace of change in which this Government has been involved over the last 12 months.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Speaker, on a point of order: The Minister was asked a question of fact and a question about government policy. We are happy to debate policy at any time--
—Order! The honourable member for North Sydney has a point of order?
—Yes, I have--
—What is the point of order?
—and I would like to come to it. We are happy to debate policy at any time--
—What is the point of order?
—The Minister is using Question Time for the purposes of abusing--
—Order! I warn the honourable member for North Sydney to get to his point of order.
—It is a straightforward abuse and you know it.
—There is no point of order.
—You will not sit him down- Mr ACTING SPEAKER-The honourable member for North Sydney will resume his seat.
—because you do not have the courage to do so.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr ACTING SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I name the honourable member for North Sydney.

INTERJECT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Beazley) put:
That the honourable member for North Sydney be suspended from the service of the House.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr ACTING SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for North Sydney is suspended from the service of the House for 24 hours.

INTERJECT.PARA: The honourable member for North Sydney thereupon withdrew from the chamber.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Sinclair) agreed to:
That so much of the Standing and Sessional Orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the National Party of Australia moving forthwith:
That the Acting Speaker no longer enjoys the confidence of the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Acting Speaker no longer enjoys the confidence of the House.

In what is an extraordinary event, for the second time in only a few weeks I have moved that this House no longer has confidence in you, Mr Acting Speaker, in the role you temporarily occupy. We all recall that during Question Time today a number of rulings have been given by you. You have sought to ensure that members on this side of the House do not intercede. While that is properly your responsibility, we believe that it should be done only if the same rule is applied to both sides of the House. That demonstrably is not so. When you, Mr Acting Speaker, called on the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins), who was answering a question at the time my colleague the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) interceded, you will recall, you said specifically to him, `You may answer the question so far as it relates to matters of fact'. The Minister then totally abused the responsibilities that were his. You, Mr Acting Speaker, permitted him to do this in the course of answering the question by allowing him to give a long peroration about policy. Mr Acting Speaker, we believe that the admonition we gave you the other day needs to be very much in your mind when you look not only at your behaviour then--
Opposition members-He is not listening again.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Leader of the National Party to continue.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Speaker. Let me repeat that we on this side of the House believe that the admonition that we gave you the other day resulted temporarily in a preparedness by you to show that you were prepared to lift your game. You might recall that in the editorial of the Canberra Times on Tuesday, 25 October it was properly said that it was necessary that you did so. I will refer to that editorial and its contents in a moment.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Acting Speaker, our complaint is threefold. First, you have consistently allowed Ministers to respond, in what must only be seen as a considerable extension of the unwritten rules and the Sessional Orders of this place, to dorothy dix questions, to give answers that relate to policy and to provide answers that should be given by way of statement. Our Standing Orders are clear: statements should be made as statements.
Opposition members-He is not listening.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Leader of the National Party to proceed.

—Honourable members can see what I mean. This is the third occasion on which the Acting Speaker has seen fit not even to bother to listen to the motion of censure. Mr Acting Speaker, I can tell you that we are serious.
—I am listening.

—This is not a matter at which you should laugh. It is an extraordinarily serious matter that you have blown it. You blew it on Tuesday when the Treasurer rose and you properly told him to conclude his answer. We have cited a series of references. Mr Acting Speaker is now speaking to the Clerk. I will let him find out what he has to do first.
—For the information of the Leader of the National Party, I was attempting to get some advice to assist him.
—That would be a very good idea, Mr Acting Speaker. You get your advice, and I will wait. Let me know when you are ready.
—The Leader of the National Party can continue when he is of a mind to.
—Mr Acting Speaker, I will wait until you have taken advice. It is you whom I am censuring.
—I most certainly do not need any advice--
—Get on with it.
—I am censuring the Acting Speaker and if you do not understand it, it is the man in that chair who has a responsibility to listen when I am censuring him.

—Order! The Leader of the National Party and the Leader of the House will not interject across the chamber. As the Leader of the National Party might well know, I do not need assistance to assist him.
—Mr Acting Speaker, I well understand. I am allowing you to get that assistance.
—The Leader of the National Party might get on with his contribution.

—Mr Acting Speaker, this matter arose because you took action against one side of the House-namely, the Opposition-and ignored totally your responsibility to take similar action against honourable members on the other side of the House. As far as the Government is concerned, the last occasion that I rose to speak on this issue was because you failed, after five successive affronts to your position by the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown), as Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support, to terminate his answer and to stop interdicting in a manner that suggested that he did not have proper respect for the Chair. On Wednesday this week the Treasurer (Mr Keating) refused to accept your direction to terminate his answer. Mr Acting Speaker, you had it made on Wednesday. If you had been prepared to take action against the Treasurer we would have known what it was all about. However, the reality is that you did not. Having told the Treasurer to terminate his answer, you allowed him to continue speaking in a way that was really a matter for ordinary debate in this place and not the subject of a question without notice.
—He is frightened of getting bounced again.
—As my colleague said, the Acting Speaker is frightened of getting bounced. That really brings us to the point of this censure motion today.
—You have got only 15 minutes to go.

—The Leader of the House need not worry; he probably is not subject to Mr Vaughan in the way the Acting Speaker is. We all know that Bryan Vaughan happens to be chairman of the New South Wales ALP credentials committee-the ALP star chamber. He is sitting up in the gallery today. The whole performance today was to show him that the laws of the New South Wales Right apply in this Parliament in the same abusive way as they did in New South Wales until Mr Unsworth and his ilk were properly thrown into opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Acting Speaker, the point is that there have been successive occasions when you were properly able to exercise the responsibilities that are yours. I said to you the other day that you alone hold responsibility for maintaining the status of this Parliament. You alone can ensure, by the dispassionate exercise of your responsibilities, that we on this side of the House accept your rulings, that we follow the Standing Orders and the Sessional Orders. We will accept that only if you apply your admonitions equally and impartially to both sides of the chamber. The problem is that you have blown every chance you have had. We understand that, of course, there are occasions when you need to discipline honourable members. We are not saying that there should not be occasions when honourable members are suspended. What we are saying is that we will not accept, as the proper exercise of your responsibilities, your allowing Ministers such as the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, as he did a moment ago, to make statements in this place which should be properly made as statements instead of as answers to questions without notice.

Mr Acting Speaker, we will not accept that you are properly exercising your responsibilities when you allow the Treasurer to attempt to protect the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand), who is under a great deal of suspicion-largely because his colleague the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding) apparently made such an absolutely disastrous mess of that portfolio that he was sacked not only from it but also from the portfolio of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs.

Mr Acting Speaker, in not admonishing the Treasurer on Wednesday and telling him to sit down, you blew what chance you had of picking up what the Canberra Times simply described as the `Referees' lifting `their game'. I will refer for a moment to that article because I think it is important. In this new chamber for the first time we have about 1,000 people watching every Question Time. We have an audience out there around the country listening to the radio, albeit a reduced audience at the directions of the Chairman of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. Be that as it may, the Canberra Times editorial stated:

The Treasurer, Mr Keating, was reported in 1986 to have verbally `bounced' the Deputy Speaker, Mr Leo McLeay, `around the walls' for not affording Mr Keating enough protection during a debate in the House of Representatives.

Mr Acting Speaker, was that the reason you did not take action against the Treasurer on Wednesday? Was that the reason you were prepared today to take action against the honourable member for North Sydney? Was that the reason you were not required to call on the Treasurer to sit down? Was that the reason you did not call on the honourable member for Charlton to sit down, as you should have? Is that the reason you did not name him? Is that the reason you did not name the Treasurer? Are you sitting up there and saying, `I do not have to name members of the Government because if I name members of the Government I am either going to be verbally bounced around by the Treasurer or I am going to have Mr Vaughan, the chairman of the ALP credentials committee saying, ``Leo, you are not good enough''.'. Mr Acting Speaker, we do not worry about your preselection. We really do not worry if you are prepared dispassionately to exercise your responsibilities in respect of members on either side of the House. However, by suspending the honourable member for North Sydney today and failing to suspend the Treasurer on Tuesday and the honourable member for Charlton a couple of weeks ago, you have shown that you are not a fit and proper person to be sitting as Acting Speaker in this place. These are not matters that can be taken lightly, for as the Canberra Times said:
The `referee' of Parliament must be just that.
As with schoolchildren, warnings are no good unless carried out.
Of course, they have to be carried out against both sides of the Parliament. The article continued:
If the occupant of the chair warns a member then threatens expulsion if the warning is not heeded, that expulsion must come quickly and cleanly if the member transgresses again.

The honourable member for Charlton was warned five times. What happened? He went back and sat down when he was ready. What happened to the Treasurer? He was told to sit down. He just continued on. In fact, not only did he continue; he extended and distorted his response to make sure that it was purely a political debate and nothing to do with answering a question without notice. Frankly, this is not good enough. Above all what we need, as the Canberra Times said, is a `week's worth of consistent treatment'. That is what it is all about. Be consistent; be prepared if you need to be to act swiftly and firmly; but it must be done dispassionately.

We on this side of the House do not accept that it is appropriate that you would name the honourable member for North Sydney and allow the Minister for Employment, Education and Training to persist in refusing to accept that he should answer the question in the way you put to him. We do not accept that it is proper for him to use questions without notice to make statements and we certainly do not accept the manner in which you allowed the Treasurer on Wednesday, and the honourable member for Charlton a couple of weeks ago, to behave without requiring them too to be expelled from this House.

The point is that there is a problem in this Parliament. More than ever, we feel that the status and dignity of this place have been prejudiced by the manner in which the Government conducts Question Time. Question Time, more and more, is the vehicle by which people see the atmosphere of this place. They understand where the Government is up to. What is happening is that we have been having fewer questions. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and his colleagues are quite prepared to give long and extended responses in a way that should properly be a matter for statements before the House. Why? Merely to try to protect the flank of some of their weaker colleagues.

This is a particularly important week. We all know that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs is under pressure. It is quite apparent. Every time we listen to a news bulletin and every time we see him try to answer a question in here, he runs for cover. He is trying to cover up. He is trying in some way to ensure that the proper and full inquiry that we seek just is not undertaken. He is trying to ensure that the Secretary to his Department is covered from any criticism. In that climate it is even more important that you allow questions without notice to be conducted in a proper way. I know the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) will get up here and say that we on this side of the House always make a great noise. I can tell him that the noise we on this side of the House make is proportionate to the degree to which there is an impartial jurisdictional attitude taken by you as the--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Leader of the National Party might address his remarks to the Chair rather than the rear of the chamber.

—I am addressing you, Mr Acting Speaker. I would be delighted if you used exactly the same admonition to the Prime Minister. During Question Time today he turned around over here and my colleague the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), said that he could not hear him. Did you call on him to address the Chair? You did not. That, in itself, is another indication that you are prepared to be partisan in your rulings.

—The Leader of the National Party took some time before to tell me that this was an important motion that he was moving against me. So he might take the common courtesy to address me about this motion.

—I would be delighted to look you in the eye, Mr Acting Speaker, but I hope that you, having made that ruling, will understand that you failed to take an identical position when called on to do so by my colleague the Deputy Leader of the Opposition during Question Time. The Prime Minister, in an attempt again to cover up for the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, deliberately turned away and spoke to his colleagues, and nobody over here could hear what was going on. You did not tell him to address the microphone, or to address you.
—I do not think that he was moving a no confidence motion in me.
—I have no doubt, the way you are going at the moment, that he will.
—Well, let us get on with it.
—Mr Acting Speaker, I find it incredible--

—Mr Acting Speaker, I raise a point of order. Since when has it been the prerogative of someone in the chair to interject on someone who is speaking in the way that you just did? If you cannot conduct yourself with a little bit of proprietary, why do you not go out and have a Bex and a lie down?

—As honourable members would be aware, a no confidence motion is an important motion and particularly the person who is having that motion moved against him should be able to understand what the motion is about. I want to be able to hear what the Leader of the National Party is saying.

—Mr Acting Speaker, I raise a point of order. It is supplementary to the point of order raised by the honourable member for Curtin. My point of order concerns the position of the Chair when a censure motion of this nature has been moved against the Chair. Can I say, with respect- Mr ACTING SPEAKER-Will you get to your point of order?

—My point of order is that you are in the position of being subject to the debate in the House. The question of your participation in the debate raises great matters of principle. I suggest that you should not participate in this debate on a matter of principle.
—Order! There is no point of order. The honourable member for Higgins will resume his seat. I call the Leader of the National Party.

—Mr Acting Speaker, let us go over the facts again: it was in the week beginning 24 October that the last censure was moved against you. We are all concerned that Madam Speaker is not able to be back in this place. Mr Acting Speaker, you have a unique responsibility. You had a golden chance this week. During this week's proceedings on Wednesday you-for the first time, as I recall-told the Treasurer to terminate his remarks during Question Time. We accept-if you tell somebody on that side of the House to behave, we will do the same thing. But if you do not tell them to sit down or to terminate their remarks or, as is more often the case, you ignore them altogether, you cannot expect us on this side of the House to sit impassively by and say that you are properly exercising your responsibilities.

SPEECH.PARA: We all saw the other day some remarks by a visiting member of the House of Commons who commented that he found it very disappointing to find that a person sitting in your position was not quite obviously apolitical. This is an important subject. I find it quite incredible that, having failed to admonish the honourable member for Charlton, having this week finally summoned up the courage to tell the Treasurer to terminate his remarks, today you take the course of action you have. The question to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, having been queried by my colleague the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), he put to you a question on whether or not it was a question on policy. You said that, provided he answered with respect to fact, he could answer the question. The next we hear is a long diatribe about coalition policy on technical and further education colleges. Mr Acting Speaker, it would have been proper for you to say to the Minister, `The honourable gentleman will draw his answer to a close'; or alternatively, `The honourable gentleman will answer in accordance with Standing Orders'. It would at least have been proper for you to have told him, after he continued in a way which we saw as grossly abusive of the responsibilities of a Minister at a time of answering questions without notice, to respond to the general climate of our Standing and Sessional Orders. You did not do so. What you did, when the honourable member for North Sydney tried to turn your attention to the concerns we had about the matter of the answer, was immediately to warn him, name him and expel him from the House.

We accept discipline if it is applied equitably; we do not accept it if it is applied inequitably. I say to you, `Today you did not apply discipline to the honourable member for North Sydney equitably'. Not only that, but sadly we have had that other instance on Wednesday when frankly I felt very disappointed in you and in the way in which you could have brought together again the responsibilities of this Parliament. On Wednesday, for the first time, you had summoned up courage to tell the Treasurer what a lot us felt you should have done ages ago; that is, tell him to terminate his remarks. I know it is difficult and I know that you might have pressures out there. I know the Australian Labor Party star chamber tells you from time to time, `You have got to be strong, Leo'. I know they tell you, `We want you to be a fit and proper member of the right wing machine'. But it is more important for you to be Speaker. You are the Acting Speaker in this place. You are the person to whom we turn. You are the person who must ensure that in the exercise of your responsibilities you apply them equitably. Sure, we make a noise on this side of the House occasionally, and so do those opposite. The point, Mr Acting Speaker, is that, if you censure us, you censure them. We do not accept that, in the course of your behaviour today, on Wednesday and in respect to the honourable member for Charlton, you have exercised your responsibilities properly.

Mr Acting Speaker, I do not intend to go on. In my view it is extraordinarily serious that you understand the responsibilities that you exercise. It is extraordinarily serious for the status of this place. We are in a new building; we are in a new climate. We are in a position where we expect you to maintain the dignity of the Parliament, and I trust you do so in future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The right honourable member's time has expired. Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion. A record unfortunately was established today in that we have seen the first member ejected from these new premises. Another record is that you, Mr Acting Speaker, are the first Speaker in history to have a censure motion moved against him twice. There is a good reason for that: you have been grossly unfair and unreasonable in your umpiring of this House. The Opposition is very concerned that it must constantly criticise you for the way you look after the rules in this chamber. If one checks the record, it is interesting that on Tuesday in this place the Government generally played to the rules. It answered questions which were asked in brief, and generally answered factually. Only one point of order was taken, when a question should obviously have been put to another Minister. The Minister for Primary industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) should not be called upon to answer matters relating to taxation in this place. But again, you ruled that the matter was in order. More importantly, there were practically no interjections, there was practically no noise, because the Government was playing the game. Admittedly, that made it easy for you.

SPEECH.PARA: Later on this week, of course, things started to change. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) felt that having the teeth of rhetoric withdrawn from the Government put it in a bad light. Historically, we find that on all of these occasions your Ministers start to look very average, as does the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) and another Minister sitting in this place-the Minister for non-answers. The reality is that matters get out of hand in this place when the Government breaks the rules and you allow them to do it. In the light of today's exercise, in the light of your decision to name the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender), let me read to you from the record. The Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support (Mr Robert Brown) was answering a question and received an interjection:

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Lloyd

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you compare the first three years of the Hawke Government with the last three years?

INTERJECT.PARA: Not a very insulting interjection. The Hansard record reads:

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member is a lunatic.
—Order!
—That fellow down there is mad.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr ACTING SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister will withdraw that remark.

INTERJECT.PARA: Now let us note the defiance of the Chair and the remark to which you failed to respond:

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I say that he is certifiable?
—Order! The Minister will withdraw both of those words.
—Unbalanced?
—I will withdraw that and just say that he has a couple of kangaroos loose in the top paddock.

SPEECH.PARA: There was not even a response from you to his previous defiance of your ruling. The record continues:

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr ACTING SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister will withdraw unqualifiedly-

INTERJECT.PARA: your back started to stiffen up, Mr Acting Speaker-

TALK.START.PARA: —I will withdraw and say that if they persist in that way they should be chained up.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr ACTING SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister will withdraw unqualifiedly.

INTERJECT.PARA: Opposition members then started to interject. Was that surprising after you had allowed that situation to progress to that level? I go on:

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member on my left will resume his seat. The Minister will withdraw the remark . . .
—I take a point of order, Mr Acting Speaker. You are being completely insulted by this Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: I thought that I should help you on the matter. Apparently you had such a thick hide that you did not know the extent to which an honourable member of this place-qualified specifically, of course, as a Minister of your Government-was completely defying your ruling and denigrating this place to a degree that you would not tolerate minutes ago from the honourable member for North Sydney. Hansard goes on:

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry; I have not finished-

SPEECH.PARA: you were about to stop me talking because I am a member of the Opposition-

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the honourable member have a point of order?
—If you were to name him and if these people were to support you, it would be the first time in the history of this place.

SPEECH.PARA: You nod your head, and I am not surprised.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was bowing to the honourable member who left the chamber.
—The debate goes on. We are now up to the third typed page of Hansard and we still have no warning from you:
—Do not intimidate me!

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr ACTING SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister will withdraw . . .

INTERJECT.PARA: And the Minister withdrew. But there was no warning-nothing. Compare that to the very proper point of order made by the honourable member for North Sydney today. His point of order was that the Minister was not being relevant to the question. Standing order 145 says simply that answers shall be relevant. More importantly, the reason he said that the Minister was not being relevant is that the Minister was talking about Opposition policy. Under the Standing Orders there is considerable doubt as to whether that is allowed. Furthermore, there is an excellent authority on that. On 9 September 1981, as recorded on page 1063 of Hansard, Mrs Child, then a backbencher in this place, said to then Speaker Snedden:
I raise a point of order, Mr Speaker, I draw you attention to the Hansard of 27 August. You ruled:
The Minister will answer the question and not engage in irrelevancies, such as contrasting the Government and the Labor Party.
In reply Speaker Snedden said:
I think it was a very sound decision. I ask the right honourable gentleman--
meaning the Minister-
to draw his answer to a conclusion.

Compare today with how the place was run under a real Speaker. There is further evidence that that Speaker had the support and the confidence of his colleagues. Shortly, we will be hearing in your defence from this very new Leader of the House (Mr Beazley). When we do, I would like him to be a little bit more specific and advise the House categorically that the first time you do name somebody from his side of politics in this place-and please remember that also will not exactly be a record-and he moves a motion that that honourable member be removed from the House, that will be a record. Only Speaker Cope, having had a Minister of the Crown say to him, `I don't give a damn what you think' had the temerity, as a Labor Speaker, to name somebody of the Government side. Your Prime Minister of the day, Mr Whitlam, stopped the then Leader of the the House, Mr Daly, from even moving the motion. Fifty-nine members of the Labor Party, including the present Speaker, Mrs Child, came in and voted the Speaker down. I know that is your fear; I sympathise with you. But it does not remove your responsibility, as the Canberra Times said, to lift your game.

The Opposition has time and time again demonstrated in this session that it will ask questions seeking information and wherever possible the questions will generally be brief. The Government keeps breaking the rules with your assistance. It has to stop. You will find this place almost boring but I recommend that you try it because it is in the interests of good government. I remind you the other day of the third component. When this Leader of the House gets on his high horse of rhetoric very shortly, he too might address some of his thoughts to that other side of this Australian political scene, namely, the Australian people. There is a lot more to this place than having personal victories between the Government and the Opposition. We are unfortunately too often judged for our theatrics.

Forty-five minutes are allocated to Question Time each day-not for the Government to lord over the Opposition; not for the Opposition to try to trap the Government. It is a time when the Australian people should get some information and evidence of how this Government is administering their affairs. We are presently doing that. We are saying to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs that it would appear that many millions of dollars are being wasted. It is interesting that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) today almost verged on suggesting that such an inquiry was racist. The traditional insult went right up to the wire. I will bring it to your attention in a minute.

The Acting Speaker was the chairman of the committee that is significant in this debate. I will tell the Leader of the House that the Acting Speaker was equally bad and unprincipled during the chairing of that committee. That is one of the reasons why the Government has the problems it now has. It commenced a cover-up of a committee through the then chairman, Mr McLeay, now the Acting Speaker. It commenced a cover-up of a severe embarrassment four years ago. Consequently it has denied itself, as a government, the opportunity to stop the waste of many millions of dollars. The Government heard the people of Toomelah. They sent you the message and said, `We do not want the hire cars, we do not want the million dollar hotel; we would just like some houses please. We are living 20 to a house with dirt floors and bits of tin'. To quote the radio interviewer, the particular place is worse.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Speaker, I raise a point of order. The motion before the House is a censure motion on the Chair; it has nothing to do with the Aboriginal community, and the honourable member should be referring to the--

—Order! The honourable member for McMillan will resume his seat. A censure motion is usually a wide-ranging motion. The honourable member for O'Connor might get back to censuring the Chair rather than mentioning other matters before the House today.

—I apologise to the Government Whip for so embarrassing him with the evidence of the foul administration of his Government in terms of Aboriginal people and the millions of dollars the Government has wasted and has allowed to be wasted. The Minister, in his role at that time, organised a cover-up of evidence to ensure that the Government was not embarrassed by promoting the then Chairman of the Aboriginal Development Commission to Secretary to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, in fact putting Dracula in charge of the blood bank.

SPEECH.PARA: The reality, Mr Acting Speaker, is that you have done your job very badly because you have been unfair and, to quote that member of the House of Commons, you are not impartial. That is what we are about here today. The only person in this place who can guarantee good order is the Speaker. There is a view on your side of politics that you are going to achieve that by bullying people. You took a decision last night-I do not know whether you were involved in the discussions, but the Press Gallery was well aware of them this morning-that you were going to get tough with the Opposition. Let me tell you that you can also lead by example. You conduct this place fairly, you convince these people opposite that there is more to government than talk, that questions can be properly answered, and I will tell you what will happen: you will get the full cooperation and support of this side of the House, as we have demonstrated in recent times on the days that you have let it happen.

I remind you again of what happened on Tuesday. You may recollect that it was a perfectly quiet and proper day. Why? Because the Government in particular played the game. Yesterday the Treasurer (Mr Keating) completely defied, not for the first time, your timid request-made only once-to bring his answer to a close. Of course I will not tolerate the excuse that might be made that there is something wrong with the Standing Orders. I remind you again that 45 questions were answered in an hour in the Canadian Parliament under practically the same Standing Orders. There is no time limit on questions there. But the Speaker, of course, ensures that the questions are in order and that the answers are in order. No possible objection can be sustained. We are not altogether political fools; we know that we will be castigated if we do not maintain a reasonable standard. But you leave us no solution. We have not got the numbers to vote you down; we can only make a noise if you will not play the game, and it is time you did. The authorities are there. Your boss, your Speaker, when she was a back bencher, felt it necessary to remind the Speaker that it is not the role of government to be spending all its time on Opposition policy. Let me tell you that the Australian people are not too worried about the history of the other day. They are very worried about the present and they are extremely worried about their future. They would like to know whether the Government is going to give them some tax cuts. They would like a few little factual things like that instead of the talk that we are about to get from the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley).

The reality is, Sir, that you deserve this censure. I hope you will demonstrate to us in the future that you can be fair and you will be the first Labor Speaker to put out a Labor Government member when he is wrong. I suggest to you that the evidence I have given you today is ample evidence for doing that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BEAZLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the House)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Speaker, you do not deserve this motion being moved against you, and nor do you deserve the strictures that have been given to your chairmanship in the course of this. What is more, the Opposition knows that you do not deserve it. The Opposition also knows, though the public outside, listening to this debate may not know, that in the course of a censure motion on the Chair, the Chair is not able to defend himself or herself in his place; that must be done by other people in this place. So it is no doubt galling for you to have to sit in the chair and hear the unctuous nonsense delivered by the two chief perpetrators of disorder in this House over the last couple of weeks as they hector you for doing your duty.

SPEECH.PARA: But it is to your credit, Mr Acting Speaker, that in all the 35 minutes of unctuous, hectoring, spurious nonsense that has come from the Opposition in censuring you, there has not been an argument against your actions that produced this censure motion, and that was whether your decision to warn and then name the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) was correct. That is, after all, the act in this House that has brought on this censure motion. In the 35 minutes of smarting, semi-tearful waffle from the Opposition, there has not been one word of criticism offered for your actions in that regard. There has been a schoolboy smarting, the reactions of small boys dragged kicking and screaming from the tart shop after they have had a rap over their knuckles. That is what the reaction of the Opposition has been here. The Opposition has come in here and behaved on this matter like a rabble of worthless schoolchildren.

What we have had from the schoolboys opposite is not a criticism of your actions in this place. They have just said, `You should have said something about what so and so did or something else about what someone else did. It is terribly unfair that you should come into this place and assert some form of order. We will go back through the activities of the Government front bench and say you should have done better', and on that basis you get your second censure motion in the course of the last couple of weeks. The reality is, in addition to that childish smarting of an Opposition that is totally unable to restrain itself in this place, that its gall and its galling behaviour are the product of a strategy frustrated.

Indeed, since the Opposition is so keen on commenting on press comment on the state of disorder which has occasionally arisen in this House over the last couple of weeks, I will go to some press comment on the last time that an attempt was made to censure you in this place-unsuccessfully as it turned out-because the circumstances are very close to these circumstances. And I suggest that the same sort of article will be written about this tomorrow. It says:
How we reached that result-
that is, the censure motion-
is probably best explained as the culmination of a tactical line adopted by the Opposition some weeks ago.
The Liberal and National parties decided to attempt to destabilise the Government by disrupting Parliament at its most visible point, Question Time.
It had become clear that the Opposition front bench was being regularly defeated on a man-for-man basis in almost every portfolio area . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday and today and Garry Punch--
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will cease interjecting.
—The article continues:

SPEECH.PARA: The theory behind the new approach was to divert attention from this fact.
Mr Tuckey interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I warn the honourable member for O'Connor.
—This is a very accurate observation, I am afraid to say:

SPEECH.PARA: After all, out there the Government probably gets at least as much blame as the Opposition for mayhem in Parliament, and the tactic could just rattle a Government that was seen to be going through a rough patch.

The honourable member for O'Connor, the Uriah Heep of this Parliament, comes in here in his quiet, sulky, smarting, modulated tones says, `Oo-ee; I'm ever so good, ever so 'umble. All I want to do is get up in here and ask a little question to elicit a little information. That is all I want. Me, the poor innocent victim of brutal activity by the Government front bench-all I want to do is to get in a little question.'. He did a little dance with it as he asked it. What we get is what we get from the Opposition spokesman-the Uriah Heep of this Parliament. The fact of the matter is that what he is pursuing in this place-and everybody knows it-is a deliberate strategy to disrupt the proceedings of this House. In that, he has been assisted by the Leader of the National Party, who moved this motion. Nobody around this place is fooled. Indeed, we saw the Leader of the National Party continue that hectoring attitude when he made his speech to you, Mr Acting Speaker.

Mr Acting Speaker, you called on the assistance of the Clerk, a normal thing for a Speaker to do in any circumstances. It was a totally appropriate action on the part of the Clerk to come forward on request and give advice to the Acting Speaker. The Leader of the National Party decided that he would have a portentous pause in his peroration. The Edmund Burke of the contemporary Australian Parliament felt that this was so significant that he could not possibly proceed with his remarks until the Acting Speaker had ceased taking advice from the Clerk. What unctuous rubbish! That act by the Leader of the National Party is simply a further example of the deliberate Opposition strategy in this place of trying to disrupt proceedings.

The action which ultimately produced the suspension from this place of the honourable member for North Sydney was, of course, a culmination of that Opposition tactic, because he, along with the two people I have been discussing, has been one of the most prominent in his efforts to disrupt this House. I go to another article on this matter which was published today. It deals with the behaviour yesterday of the honourable member for North Sydney, which was almost identical to the circumstances which caused him to be suspended. The article says:

Even the Boys' Own Buccaneer (BOB), the one who simultaneously affects a swagger and a limp, was relatively subdued in pursuit of tactical objectives. Unfortunately Mr Spender, like BOB, finds rules like the Standing Orders little more than an irritant when applied to himself. Thus the Acting Speaker, Mr Leo McLeay, officially warned him for something he has been doing consistently for months-
not just the last couple of days when you, Mr Acting Speaker, have been in the chair; it is something he has been doing consistently for months-
. . . speaking on deliberately and provocatively after being ordered to resume his seat.
The article continued:
When he was once again told to sit down, he turned from the dispatch box and said, sotto voce to Mr McLeay: ``Because he put you there, that's why''.

That has been the consistent pattern of behaviour of the honourable member for North Sydney over the last several months-in fact, for the life of this Parliament. He has been tolerated, to this point, by the occupants of the Chair, and the reward for that tolerance is that when discipline is finally exerted in this place we get this smarting schoolboy performance from the frustrated Opposition.

Honourable members opposite fear that if there is discipline in this place they will have to find some other means of not having policy debates in this House and of not having information given in answer to questions. There will have to be some other way in which to organise disruption. After all, we had the perfect example of why they need to do that in the question which produced the circumstances which ultimately produced this motion; that is, when the Opposition brings out policy and says, `behold, all things are new' and we discover indeed that it is 12 months old. We find that nothing has been learned; nothing has been affirmed; nothing of relevance has been put forward in a major policy area. There is simply a reiteration of what happened 12 months ago. That is the way policy is being dealt with by the Opposition at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Speaker, I raise a point of order.
—I call the honourable member for O'Connor, on a point of order.
—You will resume your seat. Sit down, fat boy!
—Order! I call the honourable member for O'Connor on a point of order.
—Mr Acting Speaker, there were several points of order as to the relevance of my remarks. The Minister is now running all over the place.
—The honourable member for O'Connor will resume his seat.

—This really illustrates the point. The honourable member for O'Connor has been doing this persistently. I have not been replying to his heckling in the course of this speech, because it would merely put his trivia in Hansard. But he has been constantly heckling in the course of my speech, which illustrates the attitude of honourable members opposite to the seriousness of this debate.
—The seriousness of your defence.
—The Leader of the House is defending the Acting Speaker on a censure motion which honourable members opposite tell us--
—Order! I call the Minister to order for a moment. The honourable member for Mayo is interjecting. Other members have interjected--
—I'm not; I'm going to sleep.

—And the member for Franklin has interjected and has been called to order. When a censure motion is being moved on the Chair, it puts the Chair in an extremely invidious position to exert some discipline in the House against those members who persistently interject. But I will say to members on both my left and right that if there are any more persistent interjections in the debate I will deal with the people who make them.

—The point about the unfairness of those interjections is that in making this speech I am mounting the defence of the Acting Speaker in this supposedly portentous and terribly serious debate. One gets an understanding of the Opposition's attitude when one reviews the fact that honourable members opposite are prepared to sit here and persistently heckle me. Well they might, because this matter is regarded with exactly the same seriousness by them as all their other wretched parliamentary tactics over the course of the last three weeks-no seriousness at all. As I said, it is concealing policy.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for O'Connor, who was the seconder of this motion of censure of you, Mr Acting Speaker, is doing what he is doing at the moment largely because he has been deprived of policy responsibility. He made a thundering mess of the development of health policy, so he has been shifted aside from any area of sensible responsibility that an alternative Minister might be prepared to contemplate and he has been put in as a sort of deputy chief rabblerouser in this House. That is all that the Opposition regards him as fit for. Unfortunately for you, Mr Acting Speaker, as a result of that, you and others who are responsible for order in this place will be largely the subject of the attention of the honourable member for O'Connor.

The people who will not be the subject of the attention of the honourable member for O'Connor are those responsible for devising and detailing policy in this House. The people who also will not be the object of the attention of the honourable member for O'Connor-no matter what his unctuous pretensions are here as he comes in with knitted eyebrows and hectors us-are the people of Australia, because the people of Australia expect several things. They expect policy from government; they expect that policy to be implemented; they expect reasonable criticism from opposition of that policy; they expect the development of alternative policies by opposition; and they expect order in the House from both government and opposition. That is what the people of Australia expect. They do not expect Uriah Heep performances from Opposition spokesmen coming in here smarting because discipline has been exerted in this House.

Honourable members opposite have said in debate that somehow or other all this is a product of the last couple of weeks. It is not. If one gives simple attention to the way in which points or order have been raised in Question Time in the life of this Government-not just in the last few weeks-one sees ample evidence of the fact that honourable members opposite have set a course of disruption in a way no other Opposition has done but fully reflective of the fact that, unlike any other opposition, this one has no policy alternatives to offer the Government. Honourable members opposite are contemptible. This motion is totally contemptible. It will be rejected by this House and should be discussed no further. I move:
That the question be now put.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question put.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Speaker, I rise under standing order 152 and the convention laid down by Speaker Snedden to ask you a question with regard to your administration.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—This is a deadly serious matter. It is certainly very serious for those of us who are prone to suffer from skin cancer and those of us who have to sit under the magnified direct sunrays through the dome above us.
—Wear a hat.

—In accordance with Pettifer's House of Representatives Practice, I might well wear a hat next week. Honourable members are entitled to wear hats into this chamber. Mr Acting Speaker, I ask that you have this matter reviewed because of the magnification which is occurring. It is all right for the Clerks to wear wigs. I do not propose to wear a wig, but would you have the matter examined and report to the House?
—I will examine the matter and report back to the House.

—Mr Acting Speaker, I seek your indulgence to ask you for an opinion about the parliamentary broadcasts. It has been brought to my attention that, during the grievance debate today and, I presume, during the 90-second statements, the proceedings of this House were not broadcast. It has also been brought to my attention that it is not possible for Canberra residents to discover the program for parliamentary broadcasts because there is no list of parliamentary broadcasts in the Canberra newspapers. I wonder whether you could inquire as to the broadcast procedure and report to the House.
—I will arrange for that to be done.
—Mr Acting Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—It has been brought to my attention that twice this week the honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Pratt) has continued his series of gratuitous personal attacks on me, during which he has grievously misrepresented me at least twice. On Tuesday night he claimed that I had once said, `Why should pensioners get special treatment?' I have never said this.
—It is in the Hansard.

—An examination of the Hansard of 30 August this year indicates that I said, by way of interjection to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock), `Why should they have special treatment?' The `they' referred to the group to which the Deputy Leader had just referred himself; namely, the 33,000 people who the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) had said would be affected by changes to the guidelines for assessment for social security. I was asking why that 2 per cent of pensioners should be treated differently from the other 98 per cent and was in no way reflecting, as the honourable member for Adelaide has implied, on pensioners in general.
—The honourable member might get to where she was misrepresented by the honourable member for Adelaide.

—That is how I was misrepresented, Mr Acting Speaker. The honourable member implied that I was referring to pensioners in general. Last night the honourable member for Adelaide implied that I had been remiss in my handling of petitions from my electorate. I see it as my duty to submit to Parliament any bona fide petitions which are given to me, and I have always done this. I do not, however, see it as my duty to pervert the petition process by initiating petitions for my own purposes and then hawking them around my electorate.
—Mr Acting Speaker, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—In answer to a dorothy dix question in Question Time today, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) tried to imply that the Opposition's technical and further education (TAFE) policy, released yesterday, was unchanged. That is not so. It is not unchanged. Of course, parts of it reflect our 1987 policy, which was a very good one.
—The honourable member will get to where he was misrepresented.
—The Minister said that our policy was unchanged. It is not unchanged. Parts of it reflect the mess that the mob opposite have made with TAFE, with still-
—Order! The honourable member for Deakin will not debate the matter. He will tell the House where he was misrepresented.

—Mr Acting Speaker, I am not debating the matter. I am saying that I was misrepresented when the Minister said that our policy was unchanged. It has been changed. It has been changed to reflect the mess that the mob opposite made of it. The Minister cannot read. He should go back to his school--
—I think the honourable member has made his point as to where he was misrepresented, and he will resume his seat.
