DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The devastating effect on low income families caused by interest rate increases.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is a government of excuses-a government which has an excuse, usually levelled at the international community, for everything that has gone wrong with the management or our economy: our balance of payments crisis is the fault of foreigners; our increased inflation rate is the fault of foreigners and our declining living standards are, apparently, the fault of foreigners. The Government's response is to blame others and to exercise the use of only one very blunt policy instrument and that is the instrument of tightening monetary policy. By tightening monetary policy, as it has been doing particularly since the Oxley by-election, it is increasing interest rates.

SPEECH.PARA: Increased interest rates have a deleterious effect on the living standards of ordinary Australians and place undue hardship on the living standards of low income Australians. If the Government had taken the initiative and moved towards economic reform, if it had deregulated the industrial relations and wages system, if it had instituted real spending cuts at the Commonwealth level-not just at the State level-and if it had provided tax relief for ordinary Australians, it would not have been necessary to pursue the blunt instrument policy of increasing interest rates. By increasing interest rates the Government is simply destroying the living standards of our low income families-not the families of Warren Anderson or Kerry Packer but of the thousands upon thousands of Australians who simply cannot afford the increasing costs brought about by high interest rates. Without any doubt at all, those affected the most are low income people who are simply unable to afford housing now. In our society housing is as basic to people as food and something to drink. With this Government's single policy of high interest rates it is the low income people who are being crippled by rising interest rates.

In the last couple of weeks the National Australia Bank Ltd, the Advance Bank, Citibank Ltd, the State Bank of South Australia and two banks in Queensland have increased their home loan interest rates. The opportunities that leaves people with, particularly young families, to buy their own homes are very few. Unless those young families are very wealthy they are out of the home ownership stakes. That is a disaster for those families; it is bad for the social structure of the country; it is bad for our stability; and it is bad for people's morale. The Government has broken the dreams of thousands of families by pursuing a high interest rate policy. When one looks at the recent statistics produced by, for example, the Housing Industry Association and the Commonwealth Bank, one sees how low income families are being driven out of the dream of home ownership. Looking at those figures, which were based on a 14 1/2 per cent home loan interest rate-honourable members must remember that the rate has now gone up to 15 per cent-one sees that home affordability in Australia has reached its lowest level since records were kept. That means that thousands upon thousands of people who might otherwise have been able to afford homes cannot do so now because of the high interest rates that this Government has imposed on them.

What is the Government's response to this problem? We have a Minister for housing-many people may wonder who the Minister for housing is-whose silence is deafening. We never hear of him. He never puts out a press release to explain the Government's policy or position. He does not have a word to say. One has to prod him to see whether he is alive. In the last few weeks he has been like a kangaroo stunned into inertia by the headlights of a passing car. He will soon be flattened by the fast moving high interest rate policy of the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is the Minister?
—Who indeed is the Minister for housing? Even as the shadow Minister for housing, I find it hard to remember who that man of silence is.
—Seriously, what is his name?

—The honourable member for Kooyong seriously wants to know. The answer is that Mr Staples is the Minister for Housing and Aged Care. That is incredible, is it not? No-one knows who he is. The man who does all the talking on housing is not the Minister for Housing but Senator Walsh. He says some pretty rough, callous and insensitive things. He does all the talking on housing because the Minister for Housing is completely invisible. That Minister has allowed policy to drift and he has done less and less for low income families. While the costs of housing and interest rates have continued to rise, what have the Minister for Housing and the Labor Government done to help low income families afford their own home? In 1984-85 the Government spent over $300m helping first home owners buy their own home. This year the figure will be slightly over half that. In 1984-85 the first home owners scheme covered about 11 per cent of the price of the average family home. Now it covers 5 per cent. What the Government is doing is reducing, as a proportion of its Budget, the amount of money made available to people to purchase their own home. The consequence is that, with higher interest rates and higher housing costs, fewer and fewer people are able to buy their own home.

SPEECH.PARA: However, the Australian Labor Party has never cared about home ownership for low income families. It has not really cared about the 50,000 people who just last night had to sleep without shelter or the 200,000 people who are on waiting lists for public housing. Whenever it has been said that there is a housing crisis in Australia in the last couple of weeks, the response, as I pointed out, has come from Senator Walsh. His response has been that the housing crisis is a beat-up-those are his words-by real estate agents. Senator Walsh should go and tell the 50,000 people without shelter, the 200,000 on waiting lists for public housing and the 600,000 who do not own their own home that this is a beat-up. Those people know that it is not a beat-up. They know that Senator Walsh is a man who is callous and has complete disregard for the falling living standards of low income families.

Let us look at what is happening in the political heartland of the Labor Party-the northern and western suburbs of Melbourne. Labor holds all the seats in the western suburbs of Melbourne and, I think I am right in saying, the seats in the northern suburbs. Who holds those seats? The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) holds one; the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business, the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones), who is responsible for the housing industry, holds another; the so-called Minister for Housing and Aged Care represents another; and the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) holds another. Those people represent seats in the western and northern suburbs of Melbourne. Let me repeat what people in those suburbs are saying. The Sunshine Council Community Services Manager said last week:
The whole housing area is a disaster.

That man was talking about part of the electorate of the Minister responsible for the housing industry, Mr Jones. A St Albans community housing program worker said recently that, during the last month, her agency had turned away 101 people seeking emergency accommodation. She went on to say:

On one day we received five calls from families-involving 18 people . . . In those situations, people will end up sleeping in a car or, if they haven't a car, they'll go to the railway station, or post office, or anywhere there is shelter.

Those comments are from people on the ground, who know what is happening, who are in touch. Members of the Labor Government, such as Senator Walsh, who are out of touch, are going around saying, `This is a beat-up by real estate agents' when people have nowhere to sleep and when thousands upon thousands of people are facing what the Sunshine Council describes as a housing disaster. Those are the people who are in touch. The Government is calling that a beat-up. It is simply disgraceful that a government should so callously disregard such fundamental problems.

On top of that, with interest rates rising, we all know that more and more people are being pushed onto the public housing waiting list. It is something of a scandal that fewer than 15 per cent of low income families have any access to public housing, and it is a scandal because so many people in public housing can afford to buy their own home. For example, in New South Wales 22,0000 families living in public housing earn more than $500 a week. As we well know, two people who are in this category are Senator Dunn from New South Wales and Senator Devlin from Tasmania, a member of the Labor Party, which professes to have so much compassion. These people who are living in public housing are taking places away from those low income families who have no chance whatsoever of buying their own home because of the Government's interest rate policies. They cannot get into public housing either because, for example, in New South Wales 22,000 families earning more than $500 a week are taking up those places.

We could blame the Wran Government or the Unsworth Government for doing nothing about that situation. I am glad to say that the Greiner Government is trying to do something about it. The fact is that the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement makes it very hard for any State government to do anything about it. The Commonwealth does not want Housing Commission or Housing Trust tenants to buy their own homes. It wants to keep high income people in public housing. It is compounding the housing crisis that it caused by the Government's high interest rate policies. The simple fact is that under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement the Federal Government demands that public housing be sold, if it is sold at all, at replacement cost. For example, in my electorate a couple who live in a Housing Trust house had the house valued at a market price of $55,000. The Commonwealth is insisting, under its agreement, that the State government sell that house for nothing less than $77,000. That is a complete rip-off. Why should that couple buy it? That is one of the reasons why I say that the Government is compounding this housing crisis through stupid policies, policies that do not make sense and that need to be changed.

The Government does not care about the effects of its high interest rate policies on the living standards of low income families. It does no care about the housing crisis that that has caused. What better evidence is there to use than the words of Senator John Button on Melbourne radio 3AR last Wednesday? Whatever honourable members may think of Senator Button, from time to time he does come out with these rather revealing and truthful statements about the heart of the Government. He said that home ownership was not a priority for the Government. That is rather revealing. He went on:
Even if first homes are becoming out of reach of ordinary Australians, there's little the Government can do.

The Government does not care; it will not do anything. It does not matter to the Government that low income families are suffering. That is just too bad. As long as it can remain in office, nothing else matters.

However, Senator Maguire-a senior senator in the Labor Party from South Australia-has said it all. In the Adelaide Advertiser, which is not often read by non-South Australian members of this place, he was reported on 2 November as saying that the Government had been ignoring the housing crisis that was confronting ordinary Australians. He said more than that. Effectively, he said that the housing Minister, who few of us can remember, should resign. According to the journalist who wrote the story Senator Maguire `believed the housing portfolio should again be handled by a senior Minister to ensure it was given priority treatment within the Government'. In effect, Senator Maguire is saying that the present Minister is no good, that he has done nothing to help low income families and that we should get rid of him. I agree. Let us get rid of him. Let us get a Minister and a government who have some decent initiatives which will help low income families and will help government overall to reduce the interest rate burden.

We need macro-economic policy changes to address issues such as a deregulated industrial relations and wages system. We need macro-economic policies that will reduce government spending and provide tax relief. Those things will lower interest rates and make housing, and indeed many other things, more affordable to low income families. We need a bigger proportion of Federal funding for housing to be directed towards helping first home owners. We need policies that will provide for more urban consolidation in our capital cities and more persuasion, particularly, of local and State governments, to follow that path. We need substantial reform of public housing programs in this country to ensure that public housing is directed to people who need it and not to Senators Devlin and Dunn and the 22,000 New South Wales families who can afford to own their own homes. This Government has a long and sorry record of condemning low income families to greater and greater poverty and it ought to be ashamed of itself.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe Mr N.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today's discussion focuses on the question of the living standards of low income families, and particularly interest rates. I will come to interest rates shortly. I want to focus on the humbug, cant and hypocrisy of the approach that has been purveyed in this place today by the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer). Firstly, we ought to look at the situation as it exists and the approach that has been taken by the Government to take account of it. We all know that Australia has been through a difficult period of adjustment. During such a period of adjustment when a country loses, as we did, over $8 billion of its national income, changes have to occur and the belt has to be pulled in. Australia has done that.

SPEECH.PARA: In these circumstances a government-a Federal government in particular-has a responsibility to negotiate a very delicate path to ensure that those who are least able and least protected from these shifts can protect themselves. Let us look at the priorities of the Government as we have gone down this path. The first priority for any government concerned with the living standards of low income families has to be employment and jobs. The simple fact is that, whether interest rates are 5 per cent or 15 per cent, if one does not have a job one cannot pay for anything. The first priority has been to turn around a situation where a million Australians were unemployed and get the country back to work.

As you know, Mr Deputy Speaker, Australia was in a crisis where ordinary families were hurting the most. There was unemployment and the problem of low income as a result of a lack of opportunity. One of the very big factors in the strategic approach taken by the Government has been to increase the opportunities for families to earn a second income, and particularly to increase the opportunities for women to enter the work force. While it may not be usual in a debate like this to focus on the substantial emphasis on providing assistance in an area such as child-care-which might not seem related, on a superficial look as put forward by the Opposition-the increased emphasis on child-care places enabled many women in Australia to have the choice of re-entering the work force and thereby assisting their families in both acquiring their homes and bridging the savings gap.

Another major step has been taken in the reform of the taxation system. This is something I want to talk about before I come to the interest rate crisis. As we all know, no country can survive if its people do not have confidence that everyone is paying his or her fair share. The honourable member for Mayo talks about the contribution that ought to be made by the Federal Government in the public housing sector via the first home owners scheme and in other ways. Of course a Federal government has a responsibility in those areas. But the first thing it has to do is find the funds to pay for these things. When a government inherits an economy that is $9.5 million in the red because it has a tax system that is being rorted out of this world under a Liberal-National Party administration, one of the key priorities is to turn that system around. It is the turning around of that system that now guarantees that in the Federal Government's Budget provision can be made for the sorts of things that are now occurring in public housing funding, in the first home owners scheme and elsewhere.

Every single penny or cent and every single item of revenue raised through the introduction of measures such as the capital gains tax, the fringe benefits tax and the increases in corporate tax raising have been directed back to the living standards of those who most needed protection. As a Federal government, we have to look at a safety net. We have to look particularly at low income families who would otherwise be less protected. We have to ensure that there is a safety net in place for those people. We have to look a measures such as increasing the rent assistance program. We have all seen a dramatic increase in rents. We cannot just leave people paying rent needing to find the money from somewhere. Government has a responsibility to increase rent assistance. That has been a substantial part of the safety net program implemented by this Government.

No discussion such as this can go by without a reference to the Federal Government's family allowance supplement program. An amount of $600m was provided directly in the last Budget to assist the very families that the honourable member for Mayo comes in here and purports to be talking about. We have spoken about people in the safety net such as pensioners. When we came to office the leaders of the pensioners' groups around Australia were pressing for pensions to be increased to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. As we know, at that time under the previous Liberal Government pensions were less than 20 per cent of average weekly earnings. They are now 24.7 per cent of average weekly earnings. That has a very direct effect on the capacity of these people to maintain pace with inflation and with general increases in the cost of living which otherwise they would not be prepared for or protected from. In recognition of that, the pensioner groups are looking at changing their policy priority, pressing for pensions set at 30 per cent of average weekly earnings. I do not have any problems with that increase being part of their policy. They now recognise that we have almost reached the 25 per cent target and can now look further ahead.

Let me say that there can be no question that the Government, in the manner in which it has addressed these issues, has not had the interests of low income families, particularly in regard to providing a safety net for them, as its key priority. Let me signal now as we progress to the wage-tax trade-off that the negotiations that will take place over the next few months about tax cuts and wage increases-all the targeting-will be directed specifically at ordinary families, lower and middle income families, the families which need the assistance. There will not be tax cuts for the high fliers, as honourable members opposite have called for. There will be a direct emphasis on the interests of ordinary families.

Let us turn now to interest rates and public housing. Of course, interest rates are a key element in this regard but I think we ought to face up to the issue honestly. When I was working in the banking and finance sector, before being elected to this House, interest rates in our economy were around 14 and 15 per cent. The housing interest rate at the time was jammed up against a ceiling of 12.5 per cent. Honourable members opposite were then planning to deregulate the housing mortgage rate ceiling so that the banks and other lending institutions could lift the housing interest rate. Not once in these past eight years have honourable members come into this House and accepted that the Government has been right in demanding that that ceiling on housing interest rates remain. They have not accepted that once. They have skirted around it. They have not been prepared to change their policy that the ceiling be scrapped completely. They do not care about the banks being disciplined. With all this cant about interest rates, when have we seen members of the Opposition come in here and complain about the Bankcard interest rate of 22 per cent and small business interest rates at 16 and 18 per cent? When have honourable members opposite come in here and seriously addressed the interest rate problem?

TALK.START.PARA: —Or any problem?

—Or any problem, as the Minister says. The fact of the matter is that honourable members opposite are not into addressing these things. They are soft at the edges when it comes to facing up to the banks and the attitude they have taken to the ordinary Australian.

SPEECH.PARA: I very much welcome the announcement in the press today of the arrangement negotiated between the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) and the State Bank of Victoria which will mean that Australia-wide trade union members, ordinary workers with families, will now get discounted banking rates through the buying strength of the trade union movement. I welcome that initiative. This is a case where the ACTU has had to step in to try to improve the buying power of ordinary families. What will be the reaction of honourable members opposite? We will hear honourable members such as the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron) complaining about trade unions bullying the banks. That is the reaction we will get. That is all honourable members opposite care about. All honourable members opposite care about are the profit sector and the high fliers while we are interested in low income families. Honourable members should not come in here with their cant and nonsense.

Let us look at the housing industry. When we came to office the housing industry had been subjected to a total boom-bust cycle during all the Fraser years. It was a case of fine if it is flying but who cares if it is in a bust cycle. By 1982 the housing industry was reduced to 92,000 new home starts in Australia. This year the figure will be 160,000 new home starts, almost double the number of new homes built in Australia in 1982. That was the situation we inherited. This increase has come about through a very carefully managed policy using the first home buyers scheme, emphasis on savings programs and, most importantly, monitoring an industry which is at the heart of the Australian economy-monitoring it in a way that takes out the booms and the busts because it manages the growth in the industry.

I say to honourable members opposite that I live in an electorate which is experiencing substantial growth. Everywhere I go people complain to me that they cannot get a builder anywhere. This is because we have an overheated industry. This is one of the problems we have. When we reduce interest rates we enable people at the lower end of the market, people with lower incomes, to borrow and get into the housing market. That is very desirable provided the housing industry has some capacity to handle it. If it has not got the capacity to handle it, what happens? Prices get jacked up and the inflation cycle starts all over again. This is the very inflation cycle that those honourable members opposite were not able to contain or do anything about. The very people who make a quid out of that are the real estate agents and the property speculators who depend on inflation in the building industry. These are the very people honourable members opposite cite here today. We must have a managed policy and we do have a managed policy.

This discussion cannot end without reference to the issue of public housing expenditure. Last year, just before the Federal election, the Opposition prepared a secret plan of action that was to be its election manifesto. It was published on the front page of the Australian Financial Review and listed a number of cuts that the Opposition would make if it were elected to office. The policy stated also that the document was to be kept secret because no-one was to know about it. Some of the issues listed in that document included a complete scrapping of the commitment to public sector housing; scrapping the first home buyers scheme; and scrapping Medicare. It was the whole box and dice. Everything assisting low income families was to be scrapped under this secret plan.

The Opposition has proposed a matter of public importance today because it purports to care about low income families. It is cant. It is drivel. The fact of the matter is that the people of Australia understand where the priorities of this Government are. These are the priorities of the safety net and managing the economy in such a way that we ease our way through to the light at the end of the tunnel. In the process we will ensure that we have a safety net for the very people that this debate is about-the low income families of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr I.M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I assure the House that we on this side certainly are concerned about the low income earners in Australia and that is why we have brought forward this matter of public importance for debate today; namely, the devastating effect the Labor Government policy is having on the poor and needy families throughout Australia. I am very pleased to be talking on the matter of public importance today because it is the first in my eight years in Parliament-and I hope it is not the last.
—Haven't you cracked a draw yet?

—I think two or three pulled out before I was asked again to do it today. I am not exactly a full bottle on housing, but I am a full bottle on interest rates in general. Mr Deputy Speaker, you know too well what this Government is doing to your interest rates: not just in the lower housing sector but right across the board, because of the policies of the Treasurer (Mr Keating), we see a substantial increase in interest rates yet again. We are seeing record levels of borrowing and record trade deficits. The Treasurer told us in August that we had a $5 billion surplus. He told us that interest rates would fall. What happened? Interest rates fell all right. But for how long? For about three weeks interest rates came down 2 per cent and 3 per cent. What have we seen since then? We have seen a skyrocketing rate of interest. Yet this Treasurer and this Government have taken $5 billion out of the economy. They tell us that they have not been borrowing the sort of money that they have borrowed in previous years to finance their massive Budget deficits. This Government has been borrowing huge sums of money overseas. This country now owes up to $9 billion to the nations from which we borrow money.

SPEECH.PARA: This Treasurer came into the House and said that housing interest rates and other interest rates would fall. That just has not happened. As I said, it happened for two or three weeks and now we see this increase-over and above the 13 1/2 per cent level. As we know, previous governments fixed first home buyers' interest rates at 13 1/2 per cent; they have been fixed for many years. But when this Government came to office, the great freer of all things, the Treasurer, the freer marketeer and the Minister for housing, who is not in here today, which is a great pity-

TALK.START.PARA: —There isn't a Minister for housing.

—There is not one specifically, but there is meant to be a Minister looking after a range of portfolios, and he is not in the chamber. I wonder where he is. We have the Minister for Employment and Education Services (Mr Duncan) and a backbencher sitting on the Government side. It is a disgrace. That just goes to show how concerned the Government is when it comes to these people. It has no concern at all. It is a disgrace.

SPEECH.PARA: As honourable members know, the financial grants to the States were cut by this Treasurer by $650m last year. We have seen a $676m cut this year. Of course, those funds are used to help in the State's housing programs and to help the needy into housing. We in Australia have always believed that housing is one of our rights. We have a huge land and we have plenty of room to build on. We have always felt it was one of our rights to own a house on a block of land. Yet every day that goes by this Government makes it harder and harder for people to put their funds aside and to build their dream home and set up families. There is no help for the family. It is only this side of politics that really supports the family unit. We have been doing this for many years; we are really strong on the family unit. To have a good family unit there has to be a good home. When a couple get married the first thing they do is build a home and then start raising a family. This Government is making it very difficult for those people to do that. People who want to build a house today have to borrow $50,000; that is the figure that is required today, because interest rates are not the only thing adding to inflation. The Treasurer again came in here on Budget night and said, `We are going to have a 4 1/2 per cent inflation rate for Australia for the next 12 months'.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a joke.

—What a lot of nonsense. Within two months the inflation rate is already running at nearly 7 1/2 per cent, and that is based on city prices. In electorates like Maranoa, which I represent, there is an indexed excise charge on fuel and fuel prices are going up every six months and people have to cart every bit of timber and all the products with which to build their homes from the capital city, where it is manufactured, out into rural Australia; and this makes building costs astronomical and prices go through the roof.
—The index is well above the 7 1/2 per cent.

—As the honourable member for Dawson says, it is well above the 7 1/2 per cent. But we have these horrific freight costs on top of the average city building cost. The consumer price index increases are based on capital city prices. But rural Australia is really slugged with the extra burden of having to build homes in isolated areas.

SPEECH.PARA: The previous speaker, the honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe), mentioned the great revamp of the tax system. What have we seen this Government do? We have seen it introduce the fringe benefits tax. But what did that do? It drove up the price of houses. Companies in inland Australia and isolated mining communities were prepared to give their workers subsidised housing. But what did this Government do? It introduced a fringe benefits tax. Now these workers have to pay absolutely astronomical prices for their housing compared with what they were paying before. It has been suggested that the capital gains tax has helped. What a lot of hogwash. The family home has been exempted from capital gains tax. What have we seen happen to the price of housing throughout Australia? Not only have prices for flash houses around Sydney Harbour gone through the roof, but every home in Australia has increased in value because this Government has introduced a capital gains tax. I would put it to the Treasurer, if he were here, that the first thing he should do to bring down the price of housing is to withdraw that capital gains tax. It is an absolutely iniquitous tax to have on a young country such as Australia. We should not be paying a capital gains tax. The people who are really being hit, because the family home is exempt, are those who are trying to build their first homes. Right across the board, in any suburb that we like to go to, we are seeing housing costs and prices of houses at auction sales go through the roof. The reason in may cases is that the family home has been exempted from capital gains tax.

This Government, since it has been in office, has done absolutely nothing to help the family home buyer. I think it is an absolute disgrace that the Treasurer is using monetary policy. Because there is no incentive in this country to produce, because there are write-offs on depreciation, because $1 billion of support has been taken out of primary industry and we are depending practically solely on primary industry to boost our exports and bring down our balance of trade, we are seeing the Treasurer again using monetary policy and high interest rates. We have to have the highest interest rate in the world to attract funds into this country to balance our balance of payments. It is a disgrace. Our dollar is held up artificially high by the Reserve Bank of Australia. The Reserve Bank made a $2 billion profit the year before last and it made a profit last year by wheeling and dealing in currency so that our dollar and our interest rates would be held up.

If those on the other side of the House do not believe me, they should tell me why interest rates are now creeping up again to record high levels. What is the reason? There is no reason other than the fact that this Government, the Labor Government, has allowed this country to deteriorate into a banana republic, as stated by the Treasurer. It is an absolute disgrace to think that in this day and age we have allowed our trade balance to get into this position. We are losing $1 billion a month on our trade. That is what these high interest rates are about. It is the workers that are paying. They are being forced to pay 15 per cent in interest rates today. First home buyers and anybody wishing to build or buy a house have to pay at least 15 per cent. A lot of the loans would be higher than that, but 15 per cent is the starting point. Mr Deputy Speaker, you would know how difficult it is to purchase a home. Paying even 5 per cent is hard enough, but to have to pay these very exorbitant rates of interest that are being brought to bear by the Treasurer, by the responsible Minister and by this Labor Government is an absolute disgrace.

Before concluding, I wish the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) well but, if it enters into anything like the previous business arrangements that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was involved in when he was the President of the ACTU, I just wonder how it will offer lower interest rates and subsidies to these people. It seems to me that it has had to get involved with its own Labor Government to help it out of the mess it is in and, as was reported in the paper today, is offering a scheme. I wish it well but, if it is anything like the previous scheme, it will go broke.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price Mr L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members may be surprised to learn that the matter of public importance we are debating today is:

SPEECH.PARA: The devastating effect on low income families caused by interest rate increases.

The honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron) makes a unique contribution to this House. He certainly takes himself seriously: I doubt whether many other people do. This is a very important matter raised by the Opposition. It is the second matter of public importance on interest rates. The Opposition has posed the question: Where is the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples)? He is in the House. Because this concerns interest rates, I ask: Where is the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock); and the shadow Minister for Finance, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson)? Neither of them is in this place.
We are talking about housing statistics. I was very interested to listen to the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer). I quote from this morning's Australian Financial Review:
Housing approvals continued to climb in September to a 15-year high, but the building boom shows signs of peaking.
It goes on to say:

Yesterday's figures gave the Government's principal housing advisory body, the Indicative Planning Council for the Housing Industry, no reason to revise its recent forecasts for housing starts of between 158,000 to 162,000 in 1988-89.

The point I make is this: housing starts are at a record level. Does the honourable member for Mayo believe that these are phantom houses and that people do not move into them; that they are somehow ghost houses and people do not live in them? If the honourable member for Mayo is concerned about this level of activity, does he believe that the figure should be crunched up to 170,000, 180,000 or 190,000? At no stage during his contribution did the honourable member for Mayo refer to the extraordinary record 15-year high level of housing activity. The Government is a little concerned about it because we do not want the troughs and peaks which occurred during the seven years of the Fraser Government. We inherited 105,000 housing starts when we came to government in 1983. We need a sustainable level of construction in the housing industry. It appears that this latent built-up demand for housing will flatten out at a sustainable level.

The honourable member for Mayo also selectively quoted, I believe, from a Ross Gittins article in the Sydney Morning Herald. He pointed out that in New South Wales some 22,000 people in housing commission homes are currently earning more than $500 a week. He made the point that Senator Irina Dunn is one of those people. The real thrust of Gittins's article was that the State conservative Government in New South Wales has now entrenched the right of those people to stay in those houses, provided they pay market rates. What is the position of the honourable member for Mayo? Does he support Minister Schipp's action to entrench those rights of people to stay in them, or is he arguing that he disagrees and that those people should move out? I have a high level of housing commission tenants in my electorate. I am very pleased to have them and I am proud of them.

We in the Labor Party often get into debates about the rights of tenants to purchase their housing commission homes-I happen to favour this-as opposed to an equally valid contrary view that the stock of public housing commission homes available for tenants should be preserved. It is a very difficult and sensitive question of public policy. I say this about the housing commission areas in my electorate: when the honourable member for Mayo is developing his policies and when the State Government is looking at its policies, they should not create man made problems, the planner design problems, that we have had in Mount Druitt. I welcome the initiative of, for example, Frank Walker, who brought privately built housing in private estates and made them available for housing commission tenants. I strongly believe in what is usually called integrated communities where people with different experience and different financial backgrounds blend in to make one community.

The honourable member for Mayo talked about the affordability of homes and the plight of the unemployed in relation to housing. Let me confess to a real frustration I think many members on this side of the House have in relation to the activities of State housing Ministers; that is, every time we grant a pension increase, State governments immediately increase the rent paid by public housing tenants.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is more the State Treasurers.

—Yes, it really is a cause of frustration. When one talks to pensioners one often wonders whether it is really worth while increasing the pension. What is the real issue about public housing and housing for low income earners at the moment? It is this: it is well and truly within the State government corner. A pent-up blatant demand which has built up over the years is causing this current burst of activity. We also have a serious deficit on the supply side of housing lots available. If the honourable member for Mayo wanted to make any constructive contribution, he would be looking at what State governments can do to make more building blocks available so that people can purchase their homes and land prices can be stabilised and even dropped.

SPEECH.PARA: I summarise by saying that it was unfortunate that the honourable member for Mayo selectively quoted the Gittins article. In effect, the New South Wales State Government has entrenched the rights-this seems to be totally opposite to what he is saying-of income earners of $500 or more a week to remain as tenants in public housing. My colleague the honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe) made the point that we did not hear anything on policy from the honourable member for Mayo, the shadow Minister. During the last Federal election important schemes that had proved themselves to allow low income earners to move into housing-for example, the first home owners scheme-were going to be scrapped by the Opposition.

Let me tell the House a little bit about that scheme. Some 298,000 Australian families have been assisted under this scheme since 1983. This Federal Government has spent about $1.3 billion on the first home owners scheme. In my electorate there are some 3,422 families who have benefited from the scheme and who are now in their own homes because of the scheme. The value of the first home owners scheme to those families has been some $15.139m. What would the honourable member for Mayo and the Opposition do? They would scrap it. It is regrettable that we have not heard more from the honourable member for Mayo about policy. He talked about the need to provide tax cuts to low income earners and said that this was a macro-economic policy that we had to follow. What a lot of garbage! Who believes that the Liberal Party would provide tax cuts for low income earners? He talked about the need in macro-economic policy to move on industrial relations.

If one reads the letter of the shadow Minister for finance to the Australian Financial Review on 5 October, one sees that, paragraph after paragraph, he argues that interest rates should indeed be higher, not lower. Why does the Opposition not come out and tell us what it really believes? The honourable member for Mayo believes that interest rates are too high, yet on 5 October we had a contradiction when the shadow Minister for Finance said publicly that they should be higher.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. The discussion is concluded.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Reference of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WEST
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Bandiana redevelopment, stage 1, Victoria.

The proposal now before the House is the first stage of the redevelopment of the Bandiana military area. This two stage redevelopment will extend for perhaps 10 years or more. The proposal is consistent with the initiatives highlighted in the Government's defence policy information paper of 1987 to rationalise and modernise working facilities and to substantially improve living accommodation.

Bandiana, located four kilometres south-east of Wodonga, is a major defence installation and has contained military logistic and training units since the 1930s. At present it is home to two major logistic units, two major training establishments and three minor units. Of these, the 31st Supply Battalion is one of the Army's more significant supply installations and holds the major proportion of the Army's armoured fighting vehicle stock. The 4th Base Workshop Battalion is the primary repair workshop for these Army vehicles and also conducts ongoing apprentice and trade training. Between them the two major training establishments conduct nearly 100 different courses a year with some 2,700 students last year. The Royal Australian Army Ordnance Corps Centre conducts courses in clerical and store trades and Army management. The Royal Australian Electrical and Mechanical Engineers Training Centre provides highly technical courses such as the repair of radio and electronic equipment and optical systems.

The Bandiana complex now comprises a mix of modern permanent facilities and old temporary structures. Many of these latter facilities do not meet the current standards of accommodation, health and safety codes or advanced requirements of modern equipments, warehousing and repair systems. Further, the availability and suitability of instructional facilities has not kept pace with the requirement for more intensive and lengthy training of personnel to higher skill levels.

The existing Bandiana complex is geographically divided into four distinct areas. However, the existing functional divisions are not consistent with these geographical divisions. Master planning of the Bandiana area is being developed concurrently with this proposal to achieve better functional coordination and more efficient land use, site planning and building design.

The objectives of the proposal now before the House are: to provide the more urgently needed logistic, training and administrative facilities; to provide permanent living accommodation to Department of Defence services' scales and standards of accommodation for both living-in personnel and students; and to provide area physical training and recreational facilities. A second stage of the redevelopment is planned. This stage will include the replacement of upgrading of the remaining facilities to consolidate functions in accordance with the zone plan. The timing of stage 2 will be determined by resource allocation and defence priorities.

The proposed work now before the House will include: new and upgraded administration, training, working and storage facilities; new and upgraded living accommodation and recreational facilities; and associated new and upgraded engineering services, roads and landscaping. These proposed stage 1 works have been grouped into two phases. The phases reflect financial programming restraints and the Army priority for works to meet the immediate objectives of the proposal. The bulk of the administrative, training and accommodation works are in phase A, with phase B consisting primarily of store and maintenance facilities which will form part of a new logistic complex.

The estimated cost of this proposal is $68m at August 1988 prices, comprising: $50m for phase A and $18m for phase B. Subject to parliamentary approval, it is intended to commence construction of the phase A works-that is the $50m component-in mid-1989 and the phase B works in 1992-93. Construction of all the works in the first stage of the redevelopment is planned to be complete by mid-1995. This redevelopment will enhance Defence Force capability by improving Army's logistic and training efficiency and effectiveness. I table selected plans of the proposed work and I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition welcomes this allocation of funding that is going into the Bandiana area. Parts of Bandiana have been very badly neglected in the past. In fact some of the married quarters are probably the worst in the whole of the Australian Defence Force, and that is saying something. Many of them have been condemned by the local authorities, yet service men and women are still living in them, which is some sort of indictment. Without pushing the point, which must be obvious to everyone, there is neglect of servicemen by this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposal also raises the question of the 4th Base Workshop Battalion in the Bandiana area. The 4th Base Workshop Battalion has been in some sort of limbo for probably two or three years, not knowing whether it is going to survive, what its work program is or what its future is. I note with some interest that the honourable member for Indi (Mr Ewen Cameron) and the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) are both going to Bandiana on 17 November as part of their continuing interest in the Defence Force, particularly in that area, to talk to people there and, I think, to talk particularly to the 4th Base Workshop people. The problem is that the 4th Base Workshop would be central to any refurbishment program that the Army wants to undertake in respect of the M113 armoured personnel carriers (APCs). This project has been on again, off again, on again and now it looks as though it is off again because the Government cannot make up its mind just what it wants to do.

One of the reasons it cannot make up its mind is that the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) has another pet project under his bonnet, like flying training in New Zealand, which neither the Royal Australian Air Force nor the New Zealand Air Force wants, or the participation of New Zealand in the frigate project. He has got this bee in his bonnet that what he is going to do with the 2nd Cavalry Regiment, a reconnaissance regiment, is equip it with wheeled APCs before it moves to Darwin, probably by 1992. He is going to buy those wheeled APCs from overseas. We know of no trials going on and there will be nothing in it for Australian industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I remind the honourable member that we have a restricted debate before us and we are dealing with the allocation of money for this development.

—I understand, Mr Deputy Speaker, but can I just explain the point? It is this: If the Minister is going to proceed, of his own volition-and no-one supports him-in buying wheeled APCs from overseas then the future of the 4th Base Workshop, which the Government has promised on and off could refurbish the existing M113 APCs in Australia, looks very grim indeed. Here we are spending all this money in Bandiana, which is very necessary, but at the same time rather than the Government coming to a decision on whether the 4th Base Workshop based in Bandiana is to have a program of work-with the jobs of all the people there depending on it-the Minister is apparently going to buy wheeled APCs from some foreign country. That is the relevance. So I ask the Government to come to some decision on that upgrade for the 113s so that the people who work in this Bandiana area will know whether they have a future. I also ask the Minister to abandon his stupid proposal to go off willy-nilly and buy some wheeled APCs without trials because he thinks they would be good in the north.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr E.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The military establishment in the Bandiana area is in the electorate of Indi, just outside Wodonga. SPEECH.PARA: I welcome the Government's move in this planned expenditure of $68m over the period from mid-1989 to mid-1995. This is a matter that has worried me considerably in recent times and I know it affects this Bandiana area. A great many dedicated Army personnel have been resigning from the forces because of dissatisfaction with working conditions and accommodation. Hopefully, this measure will help stem the tide.

Because I know that a considerable number of people from that area will be listening to us today, I thought it would be interesting to outline briefly and quickly some of the new facilities that will be established. There will be a new district support facility and military police facility, a physical fitness centre, a Royal Australian Electrical and Mechanical Engineers (RAEME) training centre headquarters and a corps training wing. There will be a Royal Australian Army Ordnance Corps (RAAOC) centre headquarters and an instructional wing. There will be a central instruction facility and a RAAOC centre training warehouse. There will be a new fire station, a receipts and issues and access control facility and a production control facility. There will be a distribution centre and a self-serve warehouse. There will be a RAEME training centre, electronics and electrical training wing and upgraded rank and file accommodation. That is very welcome. There will be a RAAOC centre Q store and vehicle compound, and a RAAOC officers and senior non-commissioned officers mess-once again, very welcome. I am sure the honourable member for Farrer and I will be invited along when it is completed. There will be upgraded accommodation, new accommodation, an ancillary trades workshop and a vehicle repair workshop. There will be a B vehicle workshop and an access control and duty room. Just before sitting down, I would like to support the comment by the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) on the attitude of the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) towards the refurbishment of the M113 personnel carrier, because that was to be a vital part of the retention of this very efficient 4th Base Workshop in the Bandiana area, which employs not only a large number of Army personnel but also a large number of civilians. They do the maintenance of the Leopard tank, and a very high standard of workmanship is carried out at the 4th Base Workshop. The M113 personnel carrier has been for quite a while the backbone of the infantry. It would be a great shame if it were abandoned. These machines can be refurbished very satisfactorily. It would be a great shame if that program were not carried out. I would like to support the honourable member for McPherson in his appeal to the Minister to reconsider his attitude towards this program.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to add but two things to the excellent comments made by my colleagues the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) and the honourable member for Indi (Mr Ewen Cameron). Firstly, the fact that this motion is before this House at all is due in part to the breakthrough achieved under the previous coalition Government when the honourable member for Hume (Mr Fife) and the Cabinet Ministers at the time saw fit to upgrade the whole of the Albury- Wodonga military area and to bring about some transfers of key units from Melbourne to a decentralised location at Albury-Wodonga.

SPEECH.PARA: I welcome the fact that the Government is now building on that progress with these capital structural changes and improvements to the value of some $68m. The second thing I would like to say is that, in fact, this program represents one of two big breakthroughs along the border area. This program applies to the area just over the border in the electorate of my colleague the honourable member for Indi. The second one is, of course, at Mulwala. I refer to the REFA project, in which the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West), who is at the table, has also been involved.

This project is classic decentralisation at its best, at a time when the word `decentralisation' is out of favour. I tell the House and the nation that combined with, and not unrelated to, this work there is an $80m Rationalisation of Explosives Factories Australia (REFA) project going ahead at Mulwala which will see the transfer of the explosives factory at Albion in Melbourne to Mulwala, just north of the Murray River in the electorate of Farrer. There will be a construction force of some 200 people over three years and subsequently a permanent boost of some 75 people to the work force at the huge, efficient Mulwala explosives factory.

So along the border-Murray Valley area, in a quite heavy industrial sense and in a key defence sense, much progress has been made. I acknowledge the role of the Government in that regard. PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 2 November.
Clauses 1 to 101-by leave-taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 58, page 35, after subclause (4) add the following subclause:
``(5) Application may be made to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal by a complainant for review of a decision of the Commissioner that the complainant is not entitled to compensation or expenses.''.
(2) Page 36, after clause 63 insert the following new clause in Division 4:
Action for breach of privacy
``63a. An interference with the privacy of an individual taking place after the commencement of this Act shall give rise to an action at the suit of the individual for breach of privacy.''.
(3) Page 36, after proposed clause 63a insert the following new clause in Division 4:
Action may be brought against agency or tax file recipient or both
``63b. An action for breach of privacy may be brought against an agency or a tax file recipient or both.''.
(4) Page 36, after proposed clause 63b insert the following new clause in Division 4:
Court may award damages, grant injunction etc.
``63c. In any action under section 63a or 63b, the Court may:
(a) award damages;
(b) grant an injunction;
(c) order the defendant to deliver up to the plaintiff any document brought into existence in the course of the interference with the privacy of the plaintiff; or
(d) make any other order as to the Court seems just.''.
(5) Page 36, after proposed clause 63c insert the following new clause in Division 4:
Right of action not in derogation of any other right etc.

``63d. The right of action conferred by this Act shall be in addition to and not in derogation of either any right conferred by this Act to make a complaint to the Privacy Commissioner or any other procedure in the course of which the privacy of an individual may be examined.''.

I was about to say I will move two amendments. The technicalities being what they are, there are in fact more than two. But, in substance, there are two amendments that I wish to make to the Privacy Bill. The first amendment, as can be seen, seeks to give an additional right of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal from proceedings before the Privacy Commissioner. Honourable members will recall that this Bill establishes a Privacy Commissioner, and amongst the several functions of the Privacy Commissioner is to investigate complaints concerning interference with privacy. Clause 58, in effect, provides an appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for review of a decision of the Privacy Commissioner must include the determination of two things. So the appeal may take place, firstly, if the Privacy Commissioner decides to award compensation to the complainant for loss or damage that he has suffered as a result of the interference with his privacy and, secondly, if the Privacy Commissioner awards compensation for expenses which the complainant has suffered.

In those two cases there may be, in effect, an appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. But, as I understand it, there is no right of appeal or right of review to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal where the complainant, the citizen if you like, has been unsuccessful. In other words, a citizen who is not awarded compensation and expenses that he has incurred does not have the right of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, even though he may have won in terms of his complaints about interference with privacy that he has taken before the Privacy Commissioner. That seems to be a very odd situation which, in our submission, should be rectified by this amendment to the Bill.

If the Government-and this is in substance what the position will be-has a right of appeal to try to cancel compensation and expenses that have been awarded so that it does not have to pay up, to put it bluntly, surely it follows that the unsuccessful citizen should have the right to appeal if he misses out as a result of his proceedings before the Privacy Commissioner. So, in our submission, it would seem only fair that the Bill should be amended in this way.

I also notice-and perhaps it is relevant to mention this here-that that right of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal in any event is governed by the provision at the beginning of division 3 which is to the effect, when one reads all of the clauses together, that the appeal procedure exists only in those cases where there is a breach of the information privacy principles. That is to say, it would seem, on my reading, that it does not apply to a breach or an interference with privacy that arises because of a matter concerned with the tax file number. So it seems to be limited to that extent. But in any event, the main point is that if it is good enough for the Government to appeal where compensation and expenses have been awarded, in our submission it is good enough for the citizen to have the right of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

The amendment proposes that there should be an action for breach of privacy. As I have already said, and we all know, where there is an interference with privacy the complainant, the person whose privacy has been interfered with, may go off to the Privacy Commissioner and pursue his or her complaint there. Compensation and expenses may be awarded, and that is fair enough. I have already complimented the Government on that procedure. But there is no right to sue in the courts. There is a right in some cases to apply for an injunction in the Federal Court. But there is no right to sue for damages. We would have thought that this was appropriate. Indeed, there would be additional incentive to people, governments and others, not to engage in acts that might invade other people's privacy because if they did they would face the prospect of being on the wrong end of a writ for an invasion of privacy.

We have proposed this amendment which creates an action for breach of privacy. The amendment provides that an action for breach of privacy may be brought against an agency-that is, in effect, a government body-and also against a tax file recipient or against both. The amendment also provides that the court may award damages if a case is made out and an injunction may be granted. The amendment also enables the court to order that documents that have been brought into existence be delivered up to the plaintiff. Documents will be brought into existence when an invasion of privacy takes place. The amendment also gives the court power to make any other order which seems to it to be just. It also makes clear that this right that it seeks to confer is in addition to and not in limitation of the rights that people have to make complaints to the Privacy Commissioner and have them pursued.

I hope that the Government accepts this amendment. It will not do any damage to its Bill. The amendment gives additional rights to people, and surely we should start off with a presumption that that is desirable. Really, it is very difficult to see why there should not be a cause of action of this sort. This provision will give people extended rights and it will keep government departments, agencies and others on their toes. We are sailing into uncharted waters in regard to the tax file number system. Because the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) was not here yesterday, I repeat that we have come a long way in amending this Bill as a result of agreements. I say without any qualification that officers of the Attorney-General's Department should be congratulated and complimented on the professional work that they have done. That should be said without any qualification. But we can take this extra step and add this additional benefit to the legislation which is now about to be passed.

The Attorney-General has a reputation for robust commonsense and goodwill. I hope he demonstrates those qualities on this occasion. In fact, since he has taken to tripping around the world signing extradition treaties his reputation is international. He can put an additional gloss on to his reputation by agreeing to this amendment which will expand people's rights but which will not do any damage to the Bill. He can look upon this, if he wishes, as a bicentennial monument and achievement. He can even call it the Bowen cause of action if he wants to. But whether we are looking at this matter from the point of view of history or from the point of view of simply providing the machinery for people to enforce their rights and further protect their privacy, there is in our belief a case for having such a cause of action. I trust that the Government will accept this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr LIONEL BOWEN
TALKER.ROLE: Attorney-General)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to thank the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown) for his contribution, particularly the praise that he properly gave to officers of the Attorney-General's Department. I thank him for that on their behalf. It is not often that the Department's hard- working officers are recognised.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable gentleman was quite correct in saying that this is an interesting piece of legislation. He said that we are going into new waters which perhaps are a little uncharted. Nevertheless, the privacy issue that we are talking about relates to matters that basically come under the area of human rights-namely, sex discrimination and race discrimination. Certainly, privacy seems to fit into that area. These two forms of discrimination are determined by conciliation and arbitration. Of course, an award can be made in this respect.

In terms of the honourable member's views about the amendment to clause 58, we do not want to depart too much from the procedure that applies now in respect of the two matters that I have mentioned which are concerned with human rights-namely, race or sex discrimination. The honourable member properly identified a reference in clause 52 to the fact that a declaration can be made that a complainant is entitled to a specified amount by way of compensation. But this sort of thing has never been done before. The amendment seeks to provide a new remedy for any damage in respect of privacy principles.

The honourable member is also correct in saying that clause 52 (3) relates the question of a complainant being entitled to costs. This assumes, of course, that the complainant at that stage has had a win. The Government would face a difficulty if the award were of an amount that was deemed to be excessive by the appropriate Minister. Only with the consent or leave of the Minister would an agency be entitled to say, `We want that amount reviewed. We are not looking at the issue'. We do not want to provide for a general review of the situation. Ministers who might give leave in this matter would be subject to parliamentary accountability. A review would be sought only on the basis of quantum and only from the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, which would provide a quick method of dealing with the matter. We are not anxious to provide a different form of procedure from that which operates under the Sex Discrimination Act and the Racial Discrimination Act.

I am also reminded that an unsuccessful complainant can use the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act to challenge a decision on a question of law. The honourable gentleman himself adverted to the fact that people are also given the opportunity, in clause 98, to go to the Federal Court to obtain an injunction to prevent a breach. I make the point that an agency is given the opportunity to seek a review of an award because of the extraordinary width of the Privacy Commissioner's powers, but that can be done only with the leave of the Minister. So whilst the honourable gentleman was anxious to persuade me to agree to this amendment on the basis that it might have my surname in the title, I certainly cannot be persuaded.

I welcome the fact that the honourable member noticed that I have been absent from the Parliament overseas. I remind him that I took 16 flights in 22 days, so I do not think he would think I was not working. On that point we are ad idem. That was the only part of his speech that I can agree with at this stage. The honourable member then went on to talk about providing for an action for breach of privacy, which was the subject of his second amendment, his third amendment being supplementary to the second and consequential on it. I cannot accept the amendment because, if we are going to provide for an action for breach of privacy, I do not see why, with the greatest respect to the honourable gentleman, we should be going through the process of appointing a Privacy Commissioner, with all the actions he can take. If a complainant feels that he would rather go to court and take action by way of suit, that would be having a second bite and would create further difficulties. He might well use the Privacy Commissioner and then decide to take action, using the Commissioner as one of his witnesses.

We are trying to establish a system whereby people can have matters looked at legitimately in the same way as an Ombudsman does. We do not want to encourage litigation which would be outside the control of the Privacy Commissioner. As I said, he could well be a witness. In fact, any evidence he might have got could then be used to further a particular action. I acknowledge that there ought to be a remedy for damages. I think the remedy provided in the legislation is adequate. We think remedies are already provided through the Privacy Commissioner. The rights for people to get injunctions and to recover damages for a breach of privacy are major reforms. This method provides a remedy, and we do not want to widen it. We hope that the appointment of the Privacy Commissioner will lead to a resolution of the problem.

The honourable gentleman suggested that clause 58 did not relate to the tax file number. It does not; it relates to the privacy principles. The tax file number legislation is a separate Bill. If, as suggested, an action for breach of privacy were to encompass the lot, it could mean that a small employer who is duty bound to keep all sorts of records relating to tax file numbers would have the further difficulty of being sued for breach of privacy because somebody else had got hold of the tax file numbers and matters of that nature. We would be opening up that whole area. For those reasons, we are unable to agree to the honourable gentlemen's amendments. Whilst we can see merit in them, we think they are premature at this stage.

The honourable gentleman at one stage asked whether there might be a tort for privacy. I noticed that that was the subject of the Law Reform Commission's considerations. It said in its report that it was not persuaded that it was appropriate to create a tort. I am not saying that the honourable member suggested that there be a tort, but an action for breach could well relate to that. That was acknowledged in the Younger report, the report of the United Kingdom Committee on Privacy. I noticed that the Law Reform Commission referred to that report and supported the majority view of that Committee, which was not persuaded that it was appropriate to have such an action because it could be vague and nebulous, would lead to the courts having to grapple with an extraordinary number of situations, and might well affect the freedom of the press, freedom of speech and freedom of information, and therefore decided against it.

I hope the honourable gentleman can see the merits of what we are about here. It is to give a right of action for breach of privacy. It is novel. It is something that will be used. It also gives this Parliament an opportunity to set the pattern whereby human rights and civil liberties are given recognition. I think the Bill as it now stands adequately meets that charter. I do not think the amendments, while well meaning, would assist. The emphasis is, as I said, on the Privacy Commissioner being able to solve matters, having extraordinary powers in the form of access to all documents and the ability to make determinations. Accordingly, I advise the honourable gentleman and the Committee that the Government is unable to accept the amendments proposed.
Amendments negatived.
Clauses agreed to.
Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken as a whole.
