DEBATE.TITLE: STATES GRANTS (TECHNICAL AND FURTHER EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Dawkins, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DAWKINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The States Grants (Technical and Further Education Assistance) Bill 1988 gives effect to the Government's Budget decisions on Commonwealth assistance for TAFE in 1989 as announced in TAFE 1989 Commonwealth Programs and Priorities which I released on 24 August 1988. The purpose of the Bill is to provide the legislative basis for the distribution of Commonwealth funds for technical and further education in the States and the Northern Territory for 1989.

The Bill provides $313.152m for technical and further education for 1989. The allocation of these resources reaffirms the Government's commitment to the directions set out in Skills for Australia in 1988 and reflects the new agenda for technical and further education and the Government's continued commitment to establish a framework for the future development of TAFE. Against the background of the macro-economic reforms already in place, and the increasing focus on structural adjustment policies, the Government's broad objectives for technical and further education are to achieve: further increases in participation in vocational education and training; improvements in the relevance of TAFE provision; productivity improvements and efficiency gains in the use of existing resources; greater industry involvement in TAFE; and an enhancement of the labour market prospects of the unemployed and other disadvantaged groups.

In 1988 the Government moved from a system of earmarked grants for TAFE to the provision of a general recurrent grant subject to resource agreements with the States. The Commonwealth maintained a substantial infrastructure program, providing around 65 per cent of the total Australian investment in TAFE buildings. The negotiation of resource agreements provides a mechanism for an integrated approach to Commonwealth and State priorities for TAFE, a new flexibility in the use of Commonwealth funding and a new emphasis on performance and outcomes. In 1989 the Government will continue to place a strong emphasis on the national development of TAFE, through both the general recurrent program and the infrastructure program.

Expanding participation in vocational education and training is fundamental to the Government's plans for economic growth and social justice. While TAFE's role as a significant provider of further training, designed to facilitate the development and maintenance of a highly skilled and efficient labour force, will continue, emphasis in 1989 TAFE funding will be given to expanding opportunities for Australians to undertake entry level education and training in pre-vocational, trade, certificate and para-professional courses. The Government will continue to emphasise also the importance of strengthening relationships between industry and TAFE in relation to curricula, staff development, delivery arrangements, equipment and use of facilities. The joint venture equipment initiative introduced in 1988 will be enhanced in 1989 as a means of providing an increased incentive for industry to contribute to the purchase of equipment for TAFE and generally promoting links with industry.

Despite significant developments during the past five years, the access of disadvantaged groups and women, especially sole parents, to education and training remains a problem. In 1989 the Government will, consistent with its other Budget measures, begin an attack on two of the major barriers to the participation in TAFE of Aborigines and women with children, particularly sole parents. During the next three years the Government will commit $10m from the infrastructure program for the construction of facilities directed towards enhancing the participation of Aboriginals in TAFE. The provision of child-care has been identified as one of the barriers to the participation of women in TAFE. Accordingly, the Government will commit $6m from the infrastructure program during the next three years to expand the provision of child-care facilities for TAFE students.

The Government will provide for 1989 an infrastructure program of $186.065m. Within this program the Government will give consideration to projects that meet its priorities for economic and social development, in particular those that: generate additional capacity in areas of strategic economic importance; are directed towards the training of Aboriginals or provide additional child-care facilities; and enhance the capacity of TAFE to respond to the training needs of young Australians, including trainees under the Australian traineeship system. The Commonwealth will continue to provide a level of recurrent funding for TAFE that meets about 9 per cent of the total recurrent expenditure. The Bill provides for a general recurrent program of $120.434m. This includes funds to maintain those courses provided by the New South Wales and Queensland TAFE authorities that were previously funded under higher education arrangements. Special grants for advanced English language courses for migrants will be maintained in real terms at the 1988 level to enable TAFE to continue the provision of courses which migrants will need to develop the more advanced English necessary for occupational purposes or for further study. Grants for adult literacy and for non-government adult education are also maintained in real terms.

The Bill also provides for the subsidies payment provided to non-government business colleges; it gives effect to the phasing out of the scheme as detailed in TAFE 1989: Commonwealth Programs and Priorities and also provides an additional $1.5m to assist colleges in the first half of 1989 to adjust their financial bases following the withdrawal of the subsidies and meet commitments already made to students in respect of 1989. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Beale) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Beazley, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BEAZLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to make an amendment to the Naval Defence Act 1910 to enable persons employed at Garden Island Dockyard to be transferred to Australian Defence Industries Pty Ltd. I announced last August that the Office of Defence Production (ODP) would be converted into a government-owned company in March 1989 in order that the defence production establishments could become more commercially competitive. This step involves the transfer of 10 defence factories and Garden Island Dockyard to the newly established company, Australian Defence Industries.

Over the last two years the Office of Defence Production, as part of an ongoing rationalisation of its operations, has reduced its work force by 25 per cent while increasing productivity by 30 per cent. This does not include the loss of employees resulting from the sale of Williamstown Dockyard and the conversion of the Government Aircraft Factories into a company, Aerospace Technologies of Australia Pty Ltd. The overall aim has been to improve delivery and financial performance. It has been successful in saving the defence budget, and ultimately the taxpayer, about $150m per annum.

The Government's 1987 White Paper on defence emphasised the need for ODP to be as efficient as possible and set out the Government's objectives to use competition as a spur. Implicit in the White Paper was the understanding that ODP would need to be structured in a way that would enable it to compete successfully for defence and other work. The policy of progressively opening up more defence work to competition means that more and more defence orders which once went to ODP will now be open to competitive bids from industry. Unless this organisation is able to adopt more commercial practices it will not survive this competition.

This Bill inserts into the Naval Defence Act a provision to enable the blue collar employees at Garden Island dockyard to be transferred to the new company. The remaining employees of the Defence Establishments are employed under the Supply and Development Act and the Public Service Act, and will be transferred under similar provisions contained in these Acts.

Over the past two years Garden Island Dockyard has undergone a major restructuring of its total work force, in line with industry generally. Improvements in efficiency and productivity were necessary if the dockyard was going to be able to survive as a viable government enterprise. The dockyard has been operating on a full cost recovery basis for some time and considerable effort has been put into restructuring of awards. It was thanks to the dockyard that HMAS Cook was refitted in time for use by the Duke and Duchess of York in the Bicentennial Naval Salute in Sydney. This refit was brought forward for the occasion and was completed on time and on target.
The proposed amendment is not expected to have any significant financial impact. I commend the Bill to honourable members and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Beale) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Howe, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOWE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill contains amendments to the Social Security Act 1947 and the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 to implement several decisions announced in the 1988-89 Budget Speech, to make minor amendments to the Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Act and to revise the social security reciprocal agreement with New Zealand.

This Bill contains the most fundamental restructuring of the system of rent assistance since its introduction for pensioners. For the first time the rent assistance system will acknowledge the additional housing costs of families with children. For the first time that system will acknowledge the additional cost of large families-families with three or more children. There will be parity in levels of rent assistance for pensioners and beneficiaries.

Among low income individuals and families, those who rent in the private market are the least well off. As part of a far-reaching housing assistance package and in special recognition of the plight of families in the private rental market, the maximum rate of rent assistance for people with dependent children is to be increased by a special $5 child add-on. This increase will apply from June 1989 to families who qualify for family allowance supplement or additional pension or benefit payments for their children.

Further rent assistance increases will be introduced in December 1989 and June 1990. In December 1989, beneficiaries without children will receive a $5 increase to bring their entitlement to the same $15 a week level that is payable to pensioners without children-providing parity of treatment for pensioners and beneficiaries. Then, in June 1990, the maximum basic rate of rent assistance payable to all recipients will rise by $5 a week and the child add-on component will be raised to $10 a week where there are three or more dependent children. People without children will then receive a total of $20 a week, those with one or two children will receive $25 a week and families with three or more children will be paid $30 a week. The rent assistance threshold will also rise in June 1989 from $15 to $20 a week. This threshold is the minimum amount of rent a person must pay before becoming eligible for rent assistance. The increase means that more assistance can be given to people in greatest need paying higher rents.

From June 1989, rent assistance eligibility is to be modified to remove an anomaly whereby the payment is currently available to pensioners and beneficiaries in respect of the rented premises that they occupy, although they may also own a home which they do not occupy. Certain home owner groups will remain eligible-people who move into nursing homes or other approved institutions, those who sell their homes and are likely to use the proceeds for re-purchase within 12 months and those who pay for the use of a site or mooring of a mobile home or vessel.

The eligibility of people who acquire a right or interest in a principal home in a retirement village from today may also be affected by this rent assistance modification, depending on how much they pay for their right or interest. They will be ineligible for rent assistance if they pay an entry contribution of more than the difference between the assets test limits for property owners and non-property owners. This is an indexed amount currently standing at $64,000. An acquisition of this type and amount gives a person security of tenure broadly comparable to that of someone living in his or her own home. People paying $64,000 or less will still be eligible for rent assistance. This change removes the incentive for village promoters to deny security of tenure to residents even though they have made substantial investments.

From June 1989, pensioners and beneficiaries who apply for rent assistance in respect of their board and lodging accommodation will have their assessable rent calculated on the basis of two-thirds of their board and lodging costs rather than the full amount. Existing board and lodging rent assistance recipients will be phased into the new arrangements-they will continue to receive the same amount of rent assistance they would have received before June 1989 had the new $20 threshold applied, until they either stop boarding and lodging or become eligible for payment at a higher rate under the new conditions.

These wide ranging amendments will enable a redistribution of rent assistance support to the areas of greatest need. To complete the housing measures and in recognition of their special circumstances, ex-prisoner rent assistance claimants who have no children will have the 26-week waiting period during which they would normally have had to be receiving unemployment benefit reduced by the length of time they have spent in prison.

A cornerstone of this country's social security system is a fair means test. An essential element of a means tested system is an income test with integrity. An environment in which some in the investment industry have developed and marketed products for the purpose of enabling avoidance of the income test requires constant monitoring. This Government has given a clear undertaking that it would act to counter devices or schemes designed to circumvent the income test for pension and benefit eligibility. This Bill closes a significant loophole in the income assessment of certain investment products in the interests of a fair and equitable income test which does not favour one group of investors over another.

Growth on market-linked investments, which is currently assessed on realisation or maturity, will now be assessed on an ongoing basis. From 1 December 1988, pensioners and beneficiaries who, on or after 9 September 1988, invested or invest in institutionally managed market-linked investments which yield capital growth will have a rate of return calculated on their investments and counted as ongoing yearly income. There will be a statutory rate of return on all market-linked investments of 11 per cent or such other lower rate not below zero per cent as is specified by the Minister from time to time. Any such specified rate lower than 11 per cent is to be subject to disallowance by Parliament.

In fairness to investors, the costs necessarily incurred by an investor in establishing and maintaining an investment will be taken into account-by deducting them from the amount determined by applying the rate of return to the amount of the investment. This change from a realisation basis to an accruals basis for the income test removes a significant disincentive for retired people to access their savings, helping to achieve a more rational retirement incomes system. Applying the flat, deemed rate of return is the only point at which the investment is subject to the income test. Investors can be confident that the realisation of their investments will be irrelevant to the operation of the income test: there is to be no double counting of the return on an investment. The fact that the system is based on a flat, deemed rate of income provides a strong incentive for fund managers to improve their products' rate of return to attract investors in this category. Any improved return over the specified rate will not affect the pension or benefit.

The Secretary to the Department of Social Security will be able to decrease the deemed rate of return in respect of particular products either of his own volition or following a written application by the fund manager or a natural person who is an investor in the fund. If satisfied that the rate of return on the particular product is at a lower level than the specified rate, and if that lower level is clearly assessable, the Secretary will determine a new product rate of return for that product. The Secretary will not then, however, be obliged to determine a further variation within a period of three months. The fund manager of a particular fund or a pensioner or beneficiary who has invested in a particular fund will have a right of appeal to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal against the product rate of return deemed appropriate by the Secretary in respect of that product.

The Government recognises the need for certainty in the provisions determining eligibility for pensions and benefits. It also recognises that any system which has gaps in eligibility criteria enabling people to make investments the returns from which avoid the income test before they are cashed in or mature is unfair and, in the longer run, economically irresponsible. The procedures and rules to apply under this Bill have taken account of consultations with pensioner bodies and investment fund associations. The Government will keep in close contact with these groups once the new provisions are in operation.

The procedures and rules should lead to a situation where pensioners, potential pensioners, fund managers and investment advisers will see clearly what the applicable rate of return is for each investment product. Variations in the rate will depend on the performance of the particular product. The Bill will make some amendments to the Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988. These amendments are necessary to correct minor errors which occurred in the drafting of the Act earlier this year and to ensure that the Act, when it comes fully into operation on 1 December, correctly reflects the intentions of Parliament.

This Bill also revises the reciprocal social security agreement with New Zealand. Since 1973, Australia has paid its pensions into New Zealand under domestic law. However, as New Zealand does not pay its benefits into Australia, a financial imbalance developed in the agreement. This imbalance has been exacerbated by recent large increases in the number of people moving from New Zealand to Australia. Following negotiations earlier this year, the New Zealand Government agreed to reimburse Australia for pensions paid to former New Zealand beneficiaries. It will reimburse the cost of all Australian age, invalid, wife's and widow's pensions paid to people in Australia who leave New Zealand on or after 1 April 1989 and who were in receipt of New Zealand national superannuation, invalid's or widow's benefits when they left New Zealand. The reimbursement payment will be made annually in advance between 1 April and 30 June and is estimated at around $A8.8m cumulative per annum. This amount, less a small administrative expense, will represent a direct reduction in future Australian social security expenditure. I commend this Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr McGauran) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: LANDS ACQUISITION (REPEAL AND CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr West, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WEST
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Bill is intended to provide the legal procedures that will apply to government acquisition activities in the transition from the operation of the current Act, the Lands Acquisition Act 1955, and the commencement of the Lands Acquisition Act 1988. Provision is also made in the legislation for amendments to be made to existing Acts where necessary so that the existing powers and functions of authorities under their enabling legislation is not affected. In my second reading speech to Parliament on the Lands Acquisition Bill 1988 I identified significant benefits to individuals that can be expected to occur as a result of the passage into law of the new lands acquisition legislation. Honourable members will be aware that the legislation in general provides for the acquisition process to be more open to public scrutiny; to provide individual landowners rights of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal of the decision to acquire the land; to require that Commonwealth acquiring authorities meet set time limits in carrying out acquisition activities; and to provide landowners recourse to more comprehensive compensation provisions in respect of Commonwealth acquisition activities.

The Lands Acquisition Bill 1988 has the interests of individuals as its primary focus. The Government is concerned that the benefits of the new provisions of that Bill should be applied as soon as possible to landowners affected by Commonwealth acquisition initiatives. This Bill has been drafted to give effect to that intention by applying the provisions of the new Act as much as possible to acquisitions initiated but not completed by the Commonwealth under existing legislation.

I would like to take the opportunity to comment on some provisions of the Bill which most exemplify the Government's intentions in this area. Clauses 7 and 8 are probably the most significant clauses in the Bill. They provide that, where the Commonwealth has initiated action to acquire an interest in land but negotiations have not been concluded and the interest has not been acquired by the time the 1988 Act commences, then those acquisitions will be undertaken according to the 1988 Act. This applies to acquisitions both by agreement and by compulsory process and implies, for example, that the property owners would be issued with a pre-acquisition declaration giving them the right to appeal the decision to acquire their properties.

Clause 8 of the Bill also provides that where an owner's land was compulsorily acquired after 25 May 1988, even if the acquisition had been completed under the Lands Acquisition Act 1955, compensation will be assessed according to the provisions of the 1988 Act. If compensation has already been assessed and paid according to the 1955 Act and the owner would be entitled to a greater amount of compensation under the provisions of the new legislation compared to the amount applicable under the 1955 Act, then this additional amount will be paid to the owner. The specified date in this provision is pertinent because it was on that date that the Lands Acquisition Bill 1988 was introduced into Parliament identifying the proposed new compensation entitlements.

Clause 9 of the Bill provides that persons whose land the Commonwealth had entered onto and/or temporarily occupied in the three-year period prior to repeal of the 1955 Act will be entitled to compensation in accordance with the provisions of the 1988 Act. When the Commonwealth compulsorily acquires property in some instances the former owner is able to remain in possession for a time. This is provided for in a general way in the 1955 Act but the details of any agreement are typically arranged between the Commonwealth and the former owner on an individual case basis. The 1988 Act makes specific provision for this to happen and clause 11 of this Bill provides that persons in possession of such land under an agreement with the Commonwealth immediately before the commencement of the 1988 Act will have extended to them the protection of the more detailed occupancy provisions of section 47 of the 1988 Act.

This Bill also amends several existing Acts. The general intention behind most of those amendments is to retain the status quo in terms of ministerial responsibilities. The need arises because the Lands Acquisition Bill 1988 is far more precise than the 1955 Act in specifying what activities will be bound by it with exceptions having to be precisely identified. In some other instances the amendments substitute a reference to the 1988 Act for a reference to the 1955 Act.

I would like however to make some broad observations about particular categories of legislation and the relationship of those Acts to the Lands Acquisition Act 1988. Honourable members will note that there is a group of Acts being amended by this Bill which deal with Aboriginal communities. These Acts provide to such communities, through Aboriginal councils and land trusts, limited powers to deal in land. In general, amendments to these individual Acts are intended to preserve these powers despite the provisions of the Lands Acquisition Act 1988.

The Government has decided that certain authorities or instrumentalities should be able to operate in a totally commercial environment and so should not be bound by the requirement of the Commonwealth's general land acquisition legislation. Bodies such as the Defence Housing Authority and the Federal Airports Corporation are examples of such organisations. Amendments to the enabling legislation of such organisations are being made to alter references to the 1955 Act to be references to the 1988 Act retaining that commercial independence. I would like honourable members to note that such amendments proposed in this Bill only preserve existing power and do not confer any additional legislative powers to the authorities involved.

Individual amendments to other Acts are varied in nature in terms of the result to be achieved. However, as I have noted earlier, these amendments do not introduce any new policy initiatives by Government and are purely intended to preserve the status quo where the new Lands Acquisition Act 1988 might otherwise introduce change.

This Bill is complementary to, and is a necessary part of, the Lands Acquisition Act 1988 legislative package. Passage of this Bill will allow the new legislation to be implemented without undue delay. I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr McGauran) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Peter Morris, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PETER MORRIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Bill will amend the taxation laws in a number of ways. It will implement several major changes announced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on 25 May 1988 as part of the May economic statement, and on 23 August 1988 as part of the 1988-89 Budget. In particular, it will remove, subject to phasing-in arrangements, the present income tax exemption that applies to income from gold- mining. It will also exclude from assessability under the income tax law up to $200 per year of discounts on shares or rights acquired under certain employee share acquisition schemes. Other 1988 May economic statement income tax measures contained in the Bill will reduce the rate of deduction for investment in Australian films from 120 to 100 per cent, and modify the imputation provisions as they relate to dividends paid before 1 July 1989 by early balancing companies.

Budget measures contained in the Bill will provide a rebate of tax for lump sum payments in arrears of certain kinds of income, and deductability for gifts to the Australian National Gallery Foundation. Other amendments of the income tax law proposed by this Bill will ensure that certain prepaid research and development expenditure will be deductable over the period during which relevant services are provided, and will exempt certain cash grants made under the defence service homes scheme. Some minor amendments are also proposed to the fringe benefits tax law. Finally, the Bill contains measures to clarify the refund provisions of the sales tax law. I turn now to a more detailed discussion of these measures.
Tax Exemption for Goldmining Income

In accordance with the 1988 May economic statement, the Bill will remove the current exemption from taxation of income from goldmining, subject to certain phasing-in arrangements. The Government will honour its commitment to the gold industry by allowing the existing exemption to apply until 1 January 1991. From that date, the Bill will terminate: the tax exemption of income from goldmining; and the exemption for income derived from the sale of gold by the Gold Producers Association Ltd. The impact of these changes will be further eased by allowing certain expenditures incurred prior to 1 January 1991 to be carried forward for deduction after that date. In particular, the Bill contains transitional arrangements to calculate notional deductions for capital expenditure incurred by goldminers prior to 1 January 1991 in order to determine actual deductions for such expenditure from that date for goldminers that continue to be engaged in mining operations. Notional deductions will be calculated either on the basis of write-off rates specified in the mining provisions of the income tax law or the 5/3 accelerated depreciation provisions.

A separate transitional arrangement will apply to exploration expenditure for gold incurred between 25 May 1988 and 1 January 1991 which will be carried forward and deducted against income from 1 January 1991 for up to seven years from the year in which it is incurred. As is the case in relation to claims for deductions for expenses generally, claims by goldminers for deductions allowed under the transitional arrangements will need to be supported by adequate records. The tax exemption for income from the sale of rights to mine for gold by bona fide prospectors will be retained, subject to an amendment to confine the exemption to arm's length transactions, as for other minerals. Also consistent with the existing law, the amount of exploration expenditure carried forward during the transitional period will be appropriately reduced in the event of a tax exempt sale of a mining right before 1 January 1991. In relation to income derived or expenditure incurred from 1 January 1991, goldminers will otherwise be subject to tax on the same basis as other miners. These changes are expected to produce revenue savings of $870m in 1991-1992 and $300m per annum in later income years.
Lump Sum Payments in Arrears

The Bill provides for a rebate of tax to be allowed where certain income accrued in years earlier than the year of receipt is received in a lump sum. The rebate will limit the tax payable on the arrears component of the lump sum to an amount comparable to the tax that would have been payable if the income had been received when it accrued. Lump sum payments of workers' and accident compensation, certain pensions, benefits and allowances and, in limited circumstances, payments of salary or wages will be eligible for the rebate. At present, such lump sums are wholly taxable as income of the year in which they are received and this can result in taxpayers paying a higher amount of tax than if the income had been received in each of the years in which it accrued. The rebate will be available for lump sums received on or after 1 July 1986 where the amount of the accrued income is not less than 10 per cent of the taxpayer's taxable income of the year of receipt, as adjusted for certain kinds of income of an irregular nature.

The kinds of income that will be excluded in applying the eligibility test are those parts of the lump sums that accrued in prior years together with any capital gains, abnormal income or lump sums paid on termination of employment. The rebate will be calculated by reference to the income of the two most recent years, prior to the year of receipt, over which the lump sum accrued. Where the lump sum accrued no earlier than those two years the taxation position of a taxpayer as a consequence of the rebate will be the same as if the income had been received in the income years in which it accrued. Where the lump sum accrued over a longer period, the tax payable in respect of the arrears that accrued in those earlier years will be determined broadly on the basis of the rates of tax that would have been borne in the two most recent years before the year of receipt. The estimated cost of providing this rebate is $3m in 1988-89 and $1m in subsequent financial years.
Employee Share Acquisition Schemes

This Bill gives effect to the proposal announced in the 1988 May Economic Statement to exclude from income tax up to $200 of discounts on shares or rights acquired by employees under certain employee share acquisition schemes. To qualify for the proposed exclusion, the employee share acquisition scheme will need to be open, on a non-discriminatory basis, to all full time or permanent part time employees of at least 12 months service. In addition, shares or rights acquired under a scheme will need to be held for a minimum of three years except where employment terminates. The Bill will also ensure that, for capital gains tax purposes, the cost base of the shares or rights will be reduced by any discount that is excluded from assessable income. These changes will apply to shares or rights acquired on or after 1 July 1988 and are expected to have a revenue cost of $5m for each of the first three years, but to decline in subsequent years.
Transitional Imputation Arrangements

The Bill contains the transitional measures announced by the Treasurer in the 1988 May economic statement to prevent franked dividends paid by early balancing companies with imputation credits calculated on the basis of the 39 per cent company tax rate from being channelled through later balancing companies which, as the law presently stands, could effectively pass those dividends on to individual shareholders with higher imputation credits based on the 49 per cent company tax rate. This situation will be addressed by deeming dividends paid by early balancing companies between 1 January and 30 June 1989 to a resident company that could pay dividends franked on the basis of the 49 per cent company tax rate to be received by that company, for imputation purposes, on the first day of the franking year that corresponds to its 1989-90 tax year, generally 1 July 1989.

However, where dividends otherwise subject to this measure are actually received earlier than their deemed date of receipt and the company concerned has a franking deficit at the end of its 1988-89 franking year, the measures in the Bill will operate to apply the incoming dividends to the reduction or the elimination of that deficit. Where necessary, up to two-thirds of such dividends may be applied against the franking deficit in this way. The overall cost of the reduction of the company tax, excluding life companies, with which this transitional measure is associated is $110m in 1988-89 and $1,850m in 1989-90.
Prepaid Research and Development Expenditure

The Bill will change the timing of deductions for research and development expenditure that is incurred in advance of the provision of the services to which the expenditure relates. Instead of being fully deductable when incurred, deductions for the expenditure will be pro-rated over the period during which the services are provided. Immediate deductability will continue to be available if all of the services are provided within 13 months of incurring the expenditure, if the expenditure is less than $1,000 or if it is required to be incurred by law.

Additionally, preferred treatment will be given to expenditure incurred to an approved research institute or a registered research agency, and to expenditure incurred on syndication projects for which a company is registered by the Industry Research and Development Board. For expenditure of this kind, deductions that would be allowable in the second and subsequent years of income will be advanced to the preceding year of income. The amendments will apply to expenditure incurred after 20 November 1987.
Films

As part of the restructuring of the Government's support for the film industry, the Bill reduces the deduction for investments in qualifying Australian films from 120 per cent to 100 per cent, with no exemption from tax for income from such investments. The reduction, which was announced by the Treasurer in the 1988 May economic statement, will apply to expenditure under contracts entered into on or after 25 May 1988. The Bill also contains transitional provisions to preserve temporarily the higher rates of deduction for films substantially in production or underwritten before 25 May 1988, provided that certain conditions are met. The estimated cost of the proposed amendments is $90m over a four-year period commencing with the 1989-90 financial year. Future government assistance to the film industry will be given primarily through the Australian Film Finance Corporation Pty Ltd which has been established as a wholly Commonwealth owned company to fund qualifying Australian films.
Corporate Restructure (Debt Creation) Rules

The Bill will effect a minor amendment to the income tax law to correct a technical deficiency in the corporate restructure-debt creation-rules which, it is argued, presently grant an exemption from the legislation in a way that was not intended. The amendment will ensure that the exempting provisions do not extend to corporate restructure arrangements under which shares held by a non-resident in one resident company are sold to another company controlled by the non- resident. Although designed to do no more than clarify the intended operation of the debt creation rules that apply from 1 July 1987, to remove any suggestion of retrospectivity this measure will apply to relevant transactions entered into after today. This change will have a negligible impact on revenue.
Gifts

As foreshadowed in the Budget, this Bill will amend the gift provisions of the income tax law to allow deductions for gifts made on and after 26 September 1988 to the Australian National Gallery Foundation. The estimated cost of admitting the Foundation to the gift provisions is $500,000 in 1988-89 and subsequent years.
Cash Grants Under the Defence Service Homes Scheme

The Bill will exempt from income tax certain cash payments made instead of low-interest mortgage loans under the defence service homes scheme. The payments were made under transitional arrangements that applied between 16 September 1987 and 9 December 1987 inclusive. The cost to revenue of the exemption is estimated to be $350,000 in 1988-89 and $50,000 in 1989-90.
Fringe Benefits Tax

The Bill contains some minor fine-tuning amendments of the fringe benefits tax law that are of a concessional nature in relation to the operation of the so-called otherwise-deductible rule. These amendments will have negligible revenue effect.
Sales Tax Refund

Finally, the refund provisions of the sales tax law will be clarified to ensure that, where tax has been passed on to customers, refunds of overpaid tax are available only if the person who ultimately bore the tax has been recompensed. I present the explanatory memorandum and commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr McGauran) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Peter Morris, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PETER MORRIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill will give effect to the proposal announced in the 1988 May economic statement to reduce the company tax rate from 49 per cent to 39 per cent. The Bill will amend the Income Tax Rates Act 1986 to declare the rates of income tax payable for the 1989-90 and subsequent financial years by companies and by trustees of corporate unit trusts and public trading trusts. Income tax at the declared rate of 39 per cent will be payable on incomes of the 1988-89 and subsequent financial years. Reflecting the decrease in the company tax rate to 39 per cent, the shading-in threshold for a non-profit company that is not a registered organisation is to be reduced to $1,429. A non-profit company will pay tax at the full company rate where its taxable income exceeds $1,429.

The Bill will also declare a 39 per cent rate of tax payable by trustees on trust income of non-resident company beneficiaries in the 1988-89 and subsequent financial years. The cost to revenue of the reduction in the company tax rate and other associated rate reductions, not including any effect of proposed changes to life insurance company taxation that will be contained in a subsequent Bill, is $110m in 1988-89 and $1,850m in 1989-90 and subsequent years. A Bill to declare the rates of tax payable on incomes of superannuation funds and by registered organisations will also be introduced at a later time. The explanatory memorandum on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1988, about which I have just spoken, contains an explanation of the provisions of this Bill. I commend the Bill to the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Peter Morris, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PETER MORRIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill will make three minor amendments to the Sales Tax (Exemption and Classifications) Act to give full effect to sales tax changes announced in the 1988-89 Budget. The Bill will ensure that: goods used by retailers to wrap or secure goods for marketing are subject to tax at the 20 per cent rate; thick shake mixes used in the manufacture of thick shakes and ice creams are taxable at the rate of 10 per cent; and accessories to takeaway food containers such as spoons and serviettes are subject to tax at the 10 per cent rate. The explanatory memorandum on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1988 about which I spoke earlier contains an explanation of the provisions of this Bill. I commend the Bill to the House.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Peter Morris, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PETER MORRIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Treasurer announced in the 1988-89 Budget that the Government has decided that an annual supervisory fee is to be levied, commencing in 1988-89, on life and general insurance companies. The purpose of this fee is to recover the ongoing costs of supervision of such insurers under the Life Insurance Act 1945 and the Insurance Act 1973 respectively by the Insurance and Superannuation Commission. The Bill before the House, namely the Insurance Legislation Amendment Bill 1988, gives effect to this announcement. The opportunity has also been taken to make a number of other amendments to insurance industry supervisory legislation. The Bill incorporates measures to provide for the registration under the Insurance (Agents and Brokers) Act 1984 of insurance intermediaries dealing with unauthorised foreign insurers. It will also effect a number of amendments to the Life Insurance Act 1945 to strengthen and improve the effectiveness of the existing supervisory arrangements, all of which will increase the level of protection available to the insuring public.

The Bill is structured into five parts. Part I includes the commencement provisions and provides for specified provisions to come into operation on the twenty-eighth day after the day on which the Bill receives the royal assent, and for all other provisions to come into operation on a day or days to be fixed by proclamation. Part II amends the Insurance Act 1973 to include the new provisions relating to the levying of the annual supervisory fee on general insurers. It also repeals section 113, which deals with unauthorised foreign insurers, in order to remove legislative overlaps with section 34 of the Insurance (Agents and Brokers) Act 1984. Part III amends the Insurance (Agents and Brokers) Act 1984 to include new provisions requiring the registration of all insurance intermediaries dealing with unauthorised foreign insurers, and the collection of statistics regarding premiums remitted overseas. Part IV amends the Life Insurance Amendment Act 1977 to repeal two redundant unproclaimed sections. Part V amends the Life Insurance Act 1945 in five ways: firstly, to include the new provisions relating to the levying of the annual supervisory fee on life insurers; secondly, to introduce the concept of appointed actuary for the purpose of performing certain functions required under the Act; thirdly, to repeal certain redundant provisions; fourthly, to change the period for furnishing to Parliament the annual report on the workings of the Act-the proposed period is to be within three months of the year ending on 30 June which corresponds to the reporting period provided in the other Acts administered by the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner; and, fifthly, to effect a number of other changes intended to clarify and enhance the existing supervisory arrangements.

I would now like to address the more significant provisions of the Insurance Legislation Amendment Bill 1988-first, the annual supervisory fee in respect of life and general insurers. At present, the cost of supervising the life and general insurance industries is borne by taxpayers in general. The proposed annual supervisory fee on life and general insurance companies is based on the application of the user pays principle. This approach is not a new one; it already applies in a number of areas of government activity. For instance, registration fees are imposed by the Commonwealth in respect of insurance brokers. There is also a supervisory fee applicable to occupational superannuation funds and approved deposit funds that wish to take advantage of relevant concessions available under the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936.

The proposed fee reflects the Government's view that, generally, where a service is designed to benefit a particular group, the cost should be borne by that immediate group of beneficiaries of the service rather than by taxpayers in general. The supervisory fee will be payable into Consolidated Revenue. Its imposition will not affect the existing arrangements under which the financial resources made available to the Insurance and Superannuation Commission are subject to the same scrutiny processes as are applicable to Commonwealth departments generally.

As announced in the Budget, the proposed annual fee will be a flat fee and will be $19,000 for each registered life insurance company and $11,000 for each authorised general insurance company. Appropriate regulations to give effect to these fees will be sought later this year following passage of the Bill. The proposed supervisory fee has been estimated to raise $2.9m in a full year. The proposed fee will be payable in respect of financial years ending on or after 1 July 1988. It is intended that the fee be paid at at the same time as an insurer's annual returns are normally lodged with the Insurance and Superannuation Commission. The first fees will be payable by insurers in 1988-89 and will be applied to offset the Commonwealth's costs of supervising the industries in 1988-89.

I turn now to the proposed changes covered in parts III and V of the Bill. These proposed amendments-to the Insurance (Agents and Brokers) Act 1984 and the Life Insurance Act 1945-have been the subject of consultations with representatives of industry bodies including, where relevant, the Life Insurance Federation of Australia, the Insurance Council of Australia, the Institute of Actuaries of Australia and the National Insurance Brokers Association of Australia. In addition, some of the other amendments provided for in the Bill have emerged as a result of suggestions put forward by the industry.

Presently, the Insurance Act 1973 and the Insurance (Agents and Brokers) Act 1984 do not provide as much protection to consumers dealing with agents of unauthorised foreign insurers as to those dealing with either agents of authorised insurers or brokers. In the case of agents of authorised insurers there is more scope to enforce the statutory requirement that an insurer must accept liability for the conduct of his agent. Brokers must in general hold professional indemnity insurance. The Government is of the view that those insured should be allowed access to overseas insurance markets where they wish to seek it. At the same time the Government believes that insurance consumers should be reminded of the importance of considering the possible implications of entering into insurance contracts with offshore insurers who are not supervised under Australian insurance law.

Against this background the Bill will provide increased protection for those insured by including certain additional provisions in the Insurance (Agents and Brokers) Act 1984. A key additional requirement will be that all insurance intermediaries who arrange insurance contracts with unauthorised foreign insurers will be required to be registered under the Act, unless they are already registered as an insurance broker. In addition these intermediaries, as well as registered insurance brokers who arrange insurance contracts with unauthorised foreign insurers, will be required, first, to provide to the Insurance and Superannuation Commission a copy of any agency agreements they have with an unauthorised foreign insurer-the agreements to be available for public inspection; second, obtain written acknowledgment from the insured that cover may be provided in whole or in part by an unauthorised foreign insurer; and, third, provide an annual return to the Commission on their activities in this area. This annual return will enable the Commission to monitor the volume of business placed with unauthorised foreign insurers through insurance intermediaries. There will also be scope to make regulations to impose a requirement on intermediaries operating under these provisions to take out professional indemnity insurance cover in respect of their operations in this area.

I now turn to the proposed amendments concerning the Life Insurance Act 1945. These amendments are considered necessary to enhance the effectiveness of the Act, particularly in relation to the functions required to be performed by actuaries, and to clarify a number of the existing supervisory arrangements. The most important of these amendments will introduce a new provision to require each life insurance company to identify an actuary as the `appointed actuary' to the company. In the last decade or so, there has been a substantial increase in the variety of life insurance products marketed by life insurance companies. Consequently, life insurance business has become much more complicated than ever before.

Against this background, it has become increasingly important that actuaries of companies performing certain statutory functions under the Life Insurance Act carry out those functions in an objective and professional manner notwithstanding the fact that they may be receiving remuneration from the companies concerned. Creating the position of an `appointed actuary' will assist in achieving this objective. Provisions in the Bill will require each life insurance company to appoint an actuary as the `appointed actuary', within a certain period of time, for the purpose of performing the actuarial functions specified under a number of provisions of the Act. Small life insurance companies will not be precluded from appointing a consulting actuary as `appointed actuary'.

The position of `appointed actuary' will assist the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner in identifying the particular actuary for each company who is responsible for discharging the key actuarial functions required by the Life Insurance Act. As a minimum level of experience, an appointed actuary must be a Fellow of the Institute of Actuaries of Australia of not less than five years' standing. This qualification is regarded as necessary in view of the importance of the functions to be performed by the appointed actuary. The requirement for an appointed actuary is supported by the Institute of Actuaries of Australia and the Life Insurance Federation of Australia.

The Bill also includes provisions to increase the threshold for publication in the Gazette of life insurance unclaimed moneys from $20 to $200. Publication annually of all unclaimed moneys of not less than $20 is a time consuming and costly procedure. This proposed change will apply to statements of unclaimed moneys as at 31 December 1988 and later, and should result in significant administrative savings as it has been estimated that in excess of 50 per cent of all unclaimed moneys are below $200. The proposal will not affect a person's right to make a claim in respect of unclaimed moneys, including amounts less than $200, where satisfactory proof of claim can be made. To increase public awareness of unclaimed moneys, the Insurance and Superannuation Commission will be making available the statements of all new unclaimed moneys from 31 December 1988. These lists will be available for public inspection in the Commission's Sydney, Melbourne and Canberra offices. The unclaimed moneys provision in the Life Insurance Act is also being amended to give to the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner power to authorise payment of unclaimed moneys. This is appropriate given the arrangements put in place last year with the passage of the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner Act 1987.

Among other changes proposed in this Bill is an amendment to alter the timing for the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner to submit a report to the Treasurer on the workings of the Act. This time will be changed from five months after 31 December to three months after 30 June each year. The Office of the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner has overall responsibility for preparation of annual reports in respect of not only the Life Insurance Act 1945 but also the Insurance Act 1973, the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act 1987 and the Insurance (Agents and Brokers) Act 1984. This proposal will allow the Commissioner to more effectively carry out his responsibilities under those Acts by producing a single consolidated annual report within three months of 30 June each year. A further proposed amendment involves repeal of section 13, which permits the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner to arbitrate in a dispute between a life insurance company and a policy owner in relation to a policy. This provision has been used only once in more than 40 years of operation of the Act. It is considered that the Office of the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner is not equipped to provide arbitration services and it is therefore more appropriate that such disputes be settled by recourse to commercial, legal or other channels. At the same time, the Insurance and Superannuation Commission is examining in conjunction with other government agencies and industry bodies possible additional arrangements for resolving disputes between insurers and policy owners.

Other proposed amendments include: first, repeal of two redundant unproclaimed sections of the Life Insurance Amendment Act 1977 relating to the conduct of non-insurance business by registered life insurers without the approval in writing of the Commissioner, and the registration of companies; secondly, improvements to certain definitions within the Life Insurance Act 1945; thirdly, enhanced requirements for the provision of information in applications for registration under the Act; fourthly, clarification of a number of existing provisions to remedy uncertainties in their administration; fifthly, a reduction in the period of notice required to be given by life insurers before issuing a special policy to replace a policy that has been lost or destroyed; and sixthly, enhancements to the review provisions in the Act to take account of introduction of the appointed actuary.

In conclusion, the various measures which I have outlined will enable the Government to recover the costs of supervision of the general and life insurance industries. The measures will also provide worthwhile increased protection for the insuring public and, consistent with the Government's broad approach to regulation, will not impose undue burdens on the industries involved. I commend the Insurance Legislation Amendment Bill 1988 to honourable members and present the related explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr McGauran) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Peter Morris, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PETER MORRIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This is the first of four Bills to amend the sales tax law to give effect to the Budget announcement by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) that significant changes would be made to the sales tax treatment of computer software. At present under the sales tax law, a computer program is subject to sales tax where it is embodied in a storage medium and is imported into, or sold in, Australia. Sales tax is payable whether the program was developed for a single user or for a number of users.

This Bill, and the three other Bills that I will be introducing shortly, will change the law in two main respects. Firstly, recognising that a large part of the price of customised software can be for software-related services and that identifying the service component of the price can be difficult, programs developed for a single user are, in certain circumstances, to be freed from tax. Secondly, to remove the distortions and avoidance opportunities created by applying sales tax only to computer programs delivered in goods, multiple user programs that are delivered electronically are to be brought into the sales tax base. Both these changes will come into effect from tomorrow. To be exempt from sales tax, a single user program must only contain material developed by the programmer for the sole use of the single user as part of the program or, if it contains other material, that other material must not account for more than 20 per cent of the value of the program. Where the 20 per cent test is not met, sales tax will be payable on the value of the other material.

The Bill will also extend sales tax to computer programs transferred within Australia otherwise than when embodied in goods, that is, when transferred by electronic means. Transfers made free of charge, however, will not be affected. A further change to be made by the Bill will ensure that sales tax applies to parts of computer programs as well as to complete programs. With the availability of the exemption for single user programs, it is inappropriate for registered taxpayers to continue to be able to quote their sales tax certificate number to buy, free of tax, those goods that are for use exclusively, or primarily and principally, as an aid to embodying tax-exempt single user programs in goods. Consequently, changes to the sales tax regulations to limit the `aids to manufacture' exemption will be submitted to the Executive Council as soon as practicable. These changes will also apply to goods to be used exclusively, or primarily and principally, as an aid to transferring tax-exempt single user programs that are not embodied in goods. The changes will apply to goods bought as `aids to manufacture' after today. Some consequential changes to the sales tax regulations in relation to the quotation of sales tax certificates will be needed. Refunds will be made available to overcome any double taxation that may occur before the regulations can be amended.

Finally, the Bill contains two amendments to complement the extension of sales tax, by the Sales Tax Assessment Bill (No. 12) 1988, to computer programs transferred electronically into Australia from outside Australia. The first of these will ensure that any exemption from sales tax available for computer programs that are transferred electronically within Australia are also available for programs transferred electronically from outside Australia. The second will require the recipients of programs transferred from outside Australia to lodge sales tax returns. I present the explanatory memorandum, which deals with all four Bills in this package, and I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Downer) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Peter Morris, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PETER MORRIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

As with Sales Tax Bill (No. 12) 1988, this Bill also is necessitated by the constitutional requirement that a law imposing taxation deal with one subject of taxation only. The sales tax that will be payable under the Sales Tax Assessment Act (No. 1) 1930 on computer programs transferred electronically within Australia will be formally imposed by this Bill. The rates of sales tax declared by the Bill are the same as those for computer programs embodied in goods-generally, 20 per cent. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Downer) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Peter Morris, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PETER MORRIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

It is a requirement of the Constitution that a law imposing taxation deal only with one subject of taxation. In accordance with that requirement, this Bill will formally impose sales tax payable under the proposed Sales Tax Assessment Act (No. 12) 1988 on computer programs that are transferred electronically from outside Australia to a person in Australia who is not registered for sales tax purposes. The rates of sales tax are to be the same as those that currently apply to computer programs embodied in goods-generally, 20 per cent. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Downer) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Peter Morris, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PETER MORRIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill complements one of the main measures in the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill 1988, about which I have just spoken. By that Bill, computer programs transferred within Australia otherwise than when embodied in goods are to become subject to sales tax. This Bill will ensure that sales tax is also payable on computer programs transferred, otherwise than when embodied in goods, from outside Australia to a person in Australia who is not registered for sales tax purposes. The buyer of such a program must lodge a sales tax return and pay the tax within 21 days after the end of the month in which the program was transferred. The new assessment Act proposed by this Bill will contain machinery provisions for the collection and recovery of tax similar to those in existing Sales Tax Assessment Acts. I commend the Bill to the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY (SELF-GOVERNMENT) BILL 1988[COGNATE BILLS:AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY (ELECTORAL) BILL 1988AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY (PLANNING AND LANDMANAGEMENT) BILL 1988A.C.T. SELF-GOVERNMENT(CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1988]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 19 October, on motion by Mr Holding:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate this order of the day concurrently with orders of the day Nos 4 to 6. There being no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOLDING
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Fairly late this afternoon I received a copy of the amendments proposed for and on behalf of the Opposition. I had previously given an undertaking, both publicly and to the Opposition, that on a variety of issues which go to this legislation the Government was prepared to negotiate both the principle and some of the details proposed. I make this statement in this sense so that the House is clear that the desire of the Government is to proceed with the legislation tonight and get it into another place as soon as is practicable. In order to pursue that course I make it clear that if a division should be called and a vote recorded against a proposition that will be without prejudice to the right of the Government to continue to discuss the position and the arguments being put forward by the Opposition and to negotiate. If we can reach an accommodation we will do that.

SPEECH.PARA: Given our commitment to further negotia- tion I would see any positions that honourable members opposite may want to take in the course of this debate as also without prejudice to positions that they might subsequently want to adopt. Thus we will not be seeking to score political points in the process we now have to follow to get this legislation into another House. Again, I reaffirm the fact, as I have publicly-and a number of issues here are very important to self-government-that we stand ready to negotiate in the spirit of real principle with the Opposition and the other parties in order to get the best possible form of legislation and, hopefully, legislation which will carry the support of all parties.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —To make things clear on the Hansard record, I also wish to make a short statement on what the Minister for the Arts and Territories (Mr Holding) has just said. I appreciate what he has said. Let me make it clear, if it were not clear already, that we accept and understand what the Minister has put. From the Opposition's point of view, our position is that if we do not call for divisions on some particular matters, particularly amendments, it will be understood by everyone as being without prejudice either to any subsequent negotiations we might enter into or with respect to any position that we might subsequently take. I can well understand the Minister's concern with respect to amendments because we also, at this late hour, have received a Government amendment with respect to the proposed electoral system in the Australian Capital Territory. I am sure that the Minister and the Government understand that we need time to consider that. Even a lifetime study of electoral Bills often leads one astray. In this particular case we of course would need time. However, that is no reason why the debate should be postponed, and it is no reason why, with good grace in all quarters, considerable progress should not be made tonight. The process is assisted by the Minister's offer, and our acceptance of it, that our position on divisions tonight will not prejudice subsequent positions that might be taken.

SPEECH.PARA: Turning to the substance of what is before us tonight, this is a cognate debate on the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Bill, the Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Bill, the Australian Capital Territory (Planning and Land Management) Bill and the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government Consequential Provisions) Bill. As the names of those pieces of legislation would imply, this is a series of Bills dealing with self-government for the Australian Capital Territory. The Bills in their various manifestations provide the constitutional and legal basis for that transition to self-government, and provide considerable detail for the mechanics of the way in which it is to be done and the constitutional and legal basis of the self-governing Australian Capital Territory.

I think it is common ground that there has been, particularly over recent years, a great deal of preparatory work done for self-government for the Australian Capital Territory. Preliminary steps have been taken under which administrative functions in the Territory have been consolidated into one Australian Capital Territory Administration and under one Federal Minister. Indeed, the Territory's budget has been drawn as if the Territory were a separate entity. Furthermore, the Commonwealth Grants Commission has recently put down reports looking at the appropriate level of Commonwealth support, and the terms of self-government have been subject to considerable public input and debate. Indeed, I cannot remember a period since I came to this Parliament, where I have been on and off since 1969, when I have turned on the radio or television or read the newspapers here, when I have not seen on those occasions some new contribution and some new view being expressed on self-government for the Australian Capital Territory. So over the years the subject has been well and truly thrashed out.

I suppose it is also common ground that in politically active circles the general view seems to have emerged that the time for self-government is nigh. We on the Opposition side agree with that general position. It is obviously time for self-government for the Territory and it is obviously time that legislation was put in place to achieve that result.

As I have said, the various pieces of legislation provide a framework to achieve that, and it is not, therefore, very surprising to find that we have a general constitutional Bill, an electoral Bill, a planning and land management Bill and the inevitable consequential provisions Bill. With respect to the self-government Bill, which I suppose I might describe as the major Bill, may I say at the outset that we support that Bill but we have amendments that we will move to it at the appropriate time to improve the Bill.

What the Bill does, as honourable members know, is to establish the Australian Capital Territory as a body politic under the Crown. It also establishes a Legislative Assembly of 17 members with an Executive of four Ministers, including a Chief Minister. The Chief Minister is elected by the Assembly and there is provision for him to appoint one of his Ministers as Deputy Chief Minister. The Assembly will elect a Presiding Officer who will preside at meetings of the Assembly and who will have a deliberative vote. The Assembly is required to meet within seven days after the result of a general election and then at least once every two months thereafter. The Assembly may be dissolved by the Governor-General in certain particular circumstances, which are set out in the Bill. One week's notice must be given for an effective motion of no confidence in the Chief Minister. There is then a whole series of other provisions in the Bill which it is really not necessary for me to go into in detail on this occasion, especially as I know that there are other members, including some who have a direct and personal relationship with the ACT, who wish to speak on the Bill.

In general terms the Bill sets out a series of provisions with respect to standing rules and orders in the Assembly and it deals with the passage of laws and the publication of those laws. It deals with the powers of the Governor-General, which are presently in the Bill, to disallow a law which is passed. It goes on to set out the whole arrangement which one would expect to find if one were about to set up a new body politic under the Crown, which is what the main purpose of the Bill is.

There are, of course, as was inevitably the case, a number of controversial issues which have arisen as a result of particular provisions in the Bill, and it is to some of those matters that I would now address a few remarks. In this context we have some amendments that we will be moving, which we believe will improve the situation set out in the Bill. The first of them is put forward because there are a number of matters that are excluded from the Assembly's power to make laws.

As honourable members know, there is a general provision in the Bill for the Assembly to pass laws to govern the Territory, which one would expect to find. But then one finds that there are exclusions from those areas of law which may be covered. The Assembly does not have power to pass laws with respect to the establishment of courts or the provision of police or the admission of legal practitioners and for matters relating to corporate law. It has been argued by some that self-government is not in fact self-government if power is not given over law enforcement and the judiciary, because it is common ground that they are important areas which the government of any Territory, State or body politic should have responsibility for. I do not know why there is an exclusion with respect to courts. For all I know, it might be because there are some people in mind to be appointed to them, but there does not seem on the surface to be any reason why courts should be excluded, and nor is there any reason that I am aware of as to why supervision over legal practitioners should be excluded. We therefore have a series of amendments which will give to the Assembly an additional power to that which the Government proposes the Assembly should have, and in particular the power to deal with courts and legal practitioners.

Of course, as we go on I will be referring, as I have already said, to the particular amendments. But let me say at this stage that amendments in my name, on the Opposition's behalf, have been circulated. If honourable members look at them they will see that amendments Nos (1), (2), (3), (7) and (8) of the series of amendments relating to this Bill touch on this subject. For instance, amendment (3) will add to the Bill a proposition to the effect that the establishment of courts and the admission of persons to practise as legal practitioners will be one of the areas of authority covered by the new Assembly of the Territory.

As one looks at the amendments one sees that in those cases where it is sought to exclude the establishment of courts and matters concerning the legal profession, what the Opposition is attempting to do by way of its amendments is to give coverage of those matters to the local authorities. I will just repeat the point, and then move on, that it is really an essential part of the government of a State or Territory, or city state or body politic-use whatever expression one wishes-that because the courts enforce the laws of the Territory, they should be subject to the general government of the Territory and therefore to the law making body of the particular Territory, whatever it may be. That is one matter.

I now raise another matter. In clause 34 of the self-government Bill one finds a statement that the Bill `does not limit the operation of section 12 of the Seat of Government (Administration) Act 1910'. The practical effect of that is that the power of the Governor-General to make ordinances remains; it is embodied in the Bill. In other words, the Governor-General will have power to make ordinances for the Territory, and this seems to be a very curious provision to retain in a piece of legislation the purpose of which is to give self-government.

We propose to move an amendment, No. 5 on the list of amendments which has been circulated, the heading of which sums up the situation very clearly. The heading is `Governor-General not to have power to make ordinances'. This amendment, which I foreshadow now, proposes that from the commencement of the section the Governor-General will not have power to make an ordinance under the Seat of Government (Administration) Act 1910. It seems to us reasonable to propose an amendment to that effect because there is, on the surface, no reason why Commonwealth ordinances-for that is what they would be-should override the laws of the Territory.

Our next amendment relates to this curious post of Head of Administration. The position of Head of Administration in the new Australian Capital Territory government is described in clause 48 of the Bill and then in clause 49 his powers are set out. The Head of Administration seems to be something of a hybrid figure, because he will have responsibility for: advising the Executive on all matters relating to the powers of the Executive; arrangements with respect to the staff or the Public Service; giving effect to the Act and all other laws in force in the Territory in relation to powers of the Executive; implementing the Executive's policies and decisions; and exercising the powers conferred on the Head of Administration by some other enactment.

It is an odd situation to have such a position, and some people have said that this position will undermine the normal relationship which would exist between the head of a department and a Minister. Our position on this is that we propose to move an amendment, amendment No. 6, which I foreshadow at this stage. Looking at the terms of the amendment, as the Committee will do at a later stage, honourable members will see that its intention is to set out the proposition that the Head of Administration shall, under the Chief Minister, be responsible for members of the staff and their work, because he seems to be some sort of head of Public Service, and he shall advise the Chief Minister in all matters relating to the administration of that work. He is to exercise no powers other than those which are conferred on him by or under another enactment. We think that would be an improvement on the position of the Head of Administration.

The next amendment we propose should be of particular interest to members of this Parliament. It will have the effect of avoiding the application of enactments to the Parliament.
