It will operate in this way: if either House of this Parliament passes a resolution declaring that a particular enactment which is made after the commencement date is not to apply to this particular House-or the House that passes the resolution-to members of the House or to the parliamentary precincts, the resolution which the House of this Parliament passes will have effect according to its tenor and the enactment will not apply accordingly. That is our proposal with respect to that enactment. I must end this part of my remarks on the self-government Bill by saying, as I did at the outset, that we support self-government and we support the legislative steps which must be taken to achieve self-government. Our concern is not with opposing the Bill but rather with improving it.

We support the Australian Capital Territory (Planning and Land Management) Bill, and we do not propose to move any amendments to it. As the name implies, it is designed to repeal the National Capital Development Commission Act. It also makes provision for planning and land management in the Territory after self-government has been achieved. Clearly there must be a Bill which relates to this subject, and this is it. It will set up a National Capital Planning Authority which will have the reponsibility of preparing a national capital plan. The Bill also provides that the Assembly is to establish a Territory planning authority, the function of which is to prepare and administer a plan to provide the people of the Territory with `an attractive, safe and efficient environment in which to live and work and have their recreation'. That plan is not to be inconsistent with the national capital plan. The Bill also proposes a series of mechanical provisions to implement that very laudable objective.

I turn now to the Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Bill, in respect of which the Opposition has some concerns to express. I said earlier in the statement which I was given leave to make that the Government had now proposed at this late stage some very substantial amendments to the electoral process which is to be provided for in the new self-governing Territory. The short point about it is this: the system set out in the Bill is not one that we can support because, on an analysis of the mechanics of the system as set out in the Bill, it does not provide for a proper and effective system of preferential voting or for the distribution of the proper effect of preferences cast by voters voting at the elections in the Territory. It is, as I understand it, what is described as a modified d'Hondt system. I have been endeavouring in the short time I have had today to unravel some of the mysteries of this particular system of elections. Mr Deputy Speaker, if you are anxious to have an explanation of it-and I can see you are-I regret to inform you that you will have to seek other counsel.

The system is set out in tabular form in schedule 2 of the Bill. Let me outline the sort of situation that could arise. Let us assume that representatives from three parties and two independents are standing for election. Let us say that the first party got 12,000 votes. It would be allocated the first seat on the basis of 12,000 being divided by one. The second seat would not necessarily go to the first party because if the second party got 8,000 votes-and this is the example set out in the schedule of the Bill-it would acquire the second seat to be filled because those 8,000 votes are greater in number than the number of votes left over after the allocation of the seat to the first party. Candidates, whether from a party or independents, are progressively elected in this way. Mr Deputy Speaker, as I can see, with respect, that your mind is wandering, it might be better if I moved on.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that all you know about it?

—That is virtually the sum total of my knowledge. I am pleased to say that Senator Hill, the shadow Minister for the Australian Capital Territory, is a bottomless pit of knowledge on this subject and he will explain our position in very great detail. But we understand two things: The first is that the system which is set out in the Bill is not satisfactory because proper effect is not given to preferential votes; the second thing we understand is that we now have a second version of the Government amendments. Naturally we require time both to study these amendments and to enable Opposition members to be consulted and to give their views.

SPEECH.PARA: I should also say that we do not support in its entirety the proposal in the Bill for a four-year fixed term for the Assembly. Mr Deputy Speaker, you will have seen from the amendments that we have circulated that we support the fixed term notion but we put forward the view that it should be for three years. In all the circumstances three years seems to be an adequate period. Amendments (1), (2) and (4) which have been circulated deal with both the substance of the proposal and consequential matters. Nor do we see that there is a case for public funding of the first election which is proposed in the Australian Capital Territory. Our amendments (3) and (5) on the circulated sheet put that sentiment into legislative form. So we do not support that proposal.

Mr Deputy Speaker, at the beginning of the debate the Minister made a statement when one of your colleagues was in the chair that fortunately it will not be necessary to divide on some of the contentious areas that still remain for the reason that it is clear from the position taken by both the Government and the Opposition that further negotiations will take place before the legislation is dealt with in the Senate. I refer here particularly to the proposals to amend yet again the electoral and voting system in the Australian Capital Territory. That clearly is the major area to which we have to give further study. For that reason we propose to accept the Minister's generous invitation to engage in negotiations with the Government.

I conclude where I began by saying that none of that need impede the progress of the legislation. Of course, the group of Bills before the House is necessary to advance the cause of self-government in the ACT-a cause which we support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an historic debate-a debate for which lots of people in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) have longed for a long time; a debate which many people have worked very hard for; and the culmination of a great deal of effort by many members of this House and by many public servants. It follows decades of what could be called struggle. But certainly it has taken at least intellectual and political effort.

SPEECH.PARA: My predecessor, Ken Fry, who was the member for Fraser from 1974 to 1984 devoted the whole of his maiden speech in 1974 to the importance of self-government to the ACT. I too devoted a large part of my maiden speech to the importance of self-government. So we are amongst those who are delighted that the moment seems to have arrived. I am very glad that the Opposition is supporting the Australian Capital Territory self-government legislation. It looks as though we have a very good chance at long last of both Houses of Parliament accepting this important stage in the development of the Territory.

Self-government is essential for the ACT. Anyone who is a democrat, who believes in democracy, who considers that freedom is important, must recognise that it is an anomaly that the ACT, the capital of a democracy, does not have democracy itself. The ACT is the only part of any Western country in which there are no democratically elected representatives with direct responsibility for at least some of the region's services. Responsible government, which we are now about to get, offers us freedom to choose. We will have the opportunity to set our own priorities and to manage our own affairs.

We are currently governed by people who are not directly accountable to us. Most decisions are taken by a Minister, who is elected by people in another part of Australia, or by officials who are not elected at all. Policy for the ACT is set by fiat rather than by democratic process. Of course, the Minister is a benevolent man and is attentive to the wishes of the ACT, the officials are sensitive to community opinion and all of them do an excellent job. But the system is inadequate because it is not one that leads to decisions by people who are directly accountable to the residents of the Territory.

ACT politicians elected to both the House of representatives and the Senate have no direct formal power to represent constituents effectively. We use our influence to advocate policies on behalf of voters but the decisions are made by the Minister and by officials. The Minister, as I have said, is attentive and concerned; the officials are generally sensitive. But they are forced to make political decisions for which they are not accountable. The current structure of government in the Territory is, therefore, unrepresentative and paternalistic.

The standard of services and of the built environment in the ACT is generally high. The Commonwealth has taken seriously the building and servicing of an excellent national capital, even to an extent which causes envy in other parts of the country. L.K. Donoghue, whose letter was published in this mornings Canberra Times, is right in part when she said that services in the ACT are generally high and extensive. The issue, though, is whether they would remain so without self-government.

There have been signs of growing scepticism about Commonwealth expenditure in Canberra during the last decade. Governments have allowed national priorities rather than local needs to determine outlays in the Territory. A particularly clear example is the four-year gap in land development between 1978 and 1982 which caused the shortage of land for housing and higher land and house prices. The decisions to sell the Belconnen Mall and to reduce standards of staffing in public schools are other examples. To prevent such arbitrary decisions in the future, the ACT needs a government which can negotiate on behalf of the community in the same way as State governments and which can allocate funds to the areas which need them most. One of the principal benefits of self-government will be the opportunity to ensure that the priorities of Territory residents are reflected in the Budget, particularly in areas that people regard as of great importance, such as education.

People in the Australian Capital Territory are generally well aware of their rights, but those rights are linked with responsibilities. More people and community groups in Canberra are coming to recognise that we have to accept responsibility for our own government in the same way as every other part of Australia. That is part of growing up. Representatives of the Canberra community would be better informed and more sensitive to local opinion and, therefore, better able to choose between competing claims than Federal Cabinet.

The Minister described the content of the four Bills and the speaker on behalf of the Opposition, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown), has done so as well, but I would like briefly to summarise a few of the very important elements of the Bills, because they have been well tailored to the needs of the Territory. The principal Bill, the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Bill, sets up a body politic under the Crown. The body politic will consist of a Legislative Assembly, exercising legislative power, and an Australian Capital Territory Executive, exercising executive power. The Assembly will have 17 members, one less than the number in the previous House of Assembly. It has, therefore, been kept small. That reflects community preference for a small legislature.

The Assembly will be elected for a four-year fixed term. That is a thoroughly desirable approach, because four years gives a government a chance to introduce and apply its policies and get them fully operational before it has to face another election. The Executive will consist of a Chief Minister and three other Ministers. In other words, it will be a very small Cabinet but one which ought to be adequate for the function that it has to fulfil. There are other aspects to that Bill, but the important parts are the ones that I have already mentioned. The powers of that legislature and Executive cover all the powers of local and State governments in Australia, apart from a very few to do with the judiciary and the courts.

The second Bill is the Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Bill, which sets up the electoral system. This has been the subject of major debate over the last few years. This system tries to accommodate the concerns of the other parties. Personally, I would prefer to have single-member electorates, because I think they are best attuned to the needs of individual voters. They provide voters with an identifiable member to whom they can go and they make that member directly accountable to the people who elect him or her. Nevertheless, the other parties were keen to have proportional representation, and the system of voting that has been selected, the d'Hondt system, is ideally representative of the principle of proportional representation. It was devised by a Belgian. It is widely used throughout stable Western democracies, for example, West Germany and the Netherlands, and it reflects as closely as is mathematically possible the proportion of votes received to the number of people who are elected. The system provides for stable government and gives certainty in results, once votes are counted. It is also immune from gerrymander in that members are elected from the ACT as a single electorate. Electors will have the opportunity of voting for a party or an independent candidate or, if they choose, of indicating which candidate within a party they would prefer their choice to be given to.

The third Bill, The Australian Capital Territory (Planning and Land Management) Bill, sets up a system of both national and territorial planning. The National Capital Planning Authority and a Territory planning authority will continue the excellent work of the National Capital Development Commission. The responsibility will be divided into an overview function for the National Capital Planning Authority and detailed planning work to be done by the Territory planning authority. Finally, the ACT (Self-Government) Consequential Provisions Bill involves a whole series of important amendments to other Acts of this Parliament consequential on the changes which are being made in the three major Bills.

Two objections are commonly made to self-government. One is the cost and the other is a claim that it will lead to an excess number of politicians. I would like to discuss those very briefly. The issue of cost involves a misjudgment. The direct cost of self-government will be tiny. The Legislative Assembly, the pay of members and the administrative arrangements surrounding it will cost only just over $2m a year. That is only 0.2 per cent of the ACT budget. It is a trifle. Every $2m matters, but that is a very small amount to pay for a major improvement in the structure of government.

The Territory will continue to receive most of its revenue from the Commonwealth, as do the States. Some people seem to imagine that, because the Territory is to become self-governing, somehow we will have to raise all our revenue. That is nonsense. In exactly the same way as the States receive the major part of their revenue from the Commonwealth, the Territory will continue to do so as well. That funding will be guaranteed for the next couple of years and thereafter the Territory will be handled in exactly the same way as the States. It will attend the Premiers Conference and the Loan Council, it will receive increases in the way the States do, and it will have access to the Commonwealth Grants Commission, which will ensure that it gets a fair share of the total funding for the States and Territories which takes account of its special status as the national capital. The principle of recognising the additional costs and the fact that some revenue will be lost because the Commonwealth will not be paying some of the taxes that other employers will pay has already been accepted by the Grants Commission. That is embodied in the Grants Commission decision so far and it has been guaranteed that that will continue after self-government.

The people of the ACT have no reason at all to fear that they will be worse off than would otherwise have been the case. It is very likely that they will be better off. It is very unlikely that members of the Legislative Assembly, which will be accountable to the people of the ACT and the members of which will have to come back at the next election if they want to be re-elected, will raise taxes more than would a Commonwealth government which is not directly accountable in the same way. Local ACT members will be most reluctant to raise taxes because they know that would be unpopular. Because we are about to get democracy, we will get tax increases only when they can be fully justified and explained to the electorate in ways that the majority are likely to support. There is far less danger, it seems to me, of unexpected or unwarranted taxation under self-government than there is in the present circumstances.

The second complaint that is sometimes made by people in the ACT is that self-government will lead to an excessive number of politicians. At present there are far fewer politicians in the Territory than in any other part of Australia. There are four Federal politicians-two in this House and two in the Senate-representing 270,000 people. I know from the volume of work that that is far too few. It is simply not possible for those four people to adequately represent all the interests and concerns of the more than one-quarter of a million residents in the Territory. But after self-government, with an additional 17, there will still be fewer politicians in the ACT than in any other part of Australia.

Even disregarding local government, if one takes account of State and Federal government representation from the States and Territories only, the 17 plus four-that is, 21-representatives of the Territory will still have more people to represent than do the representatives from South Australia, Western Australia, Tasmania or the Northern Territory. However, if one includes the number of local government councillors-there will be none in the ACT-who represent every other part of Australia, there will still be fewer politicians in Canberra after self-government-far fewer than in any other part of Australia.

The Bills involve the most substantial transfer of power from the Commonwealth to a new government since Australia granted independence to Papua New Guinea. I worked in Papua New Guinea for the 12 years leading up to independence and was involved in some of the negotiation and preparation for that move to nationhood. We struggled there for independence in the 1960s and delighted in the preparations once the momentum of change had been established. In the ACT, there has never been a passionate movement demanding self-government as there was in Papua New Guinea. Yet those of us who have been close to government here or have been active in community organisations know the importance of self-government to good government of this Territory. We believe in democracy, in the right of people to govern themselves rather than to have decisions imposed upon them by a distant government, no matter how benevolent. Our priorities will be fully reflected in Budgets and programs only by representatives directly accountable to us.

There can only be rigorous and comprehensive scrutiny of the effectiveness and integrity of the ACT Administration by a parliament with sufficient time and resources. Adequate scrutiny is simply not possible by the four Federal members, as at present. There are too many demands on our time. We have to cover the national policies which affect the ACT and, no matter how assiduously we work, we cannot hope to keep an eye on every aspect of territorial administration as well. Self-government will improve the quality of government here. The Federal members will deal with national and no doubt some major territorial issues; the Legislative Assembly members will be responsible for territorial and local issues.

Before concluding I wish to express warm appreciation to everyone who has contributed to the preparation for self-government. Many parliamentarians and officials have worked long and hard to reach this point. In particular, the leadership of recent Ministers for Territories-the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren), who is here; the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes), who is also here; the honourable member for Barton (Mr Punch) and the present Minister-has been vital. Each gave preparation for self-government a high priority and each has been personally involved in the preparations and negotiations. Many public servants have made major contributions. It is invidious and unconventional to name anyone, but I doubt whether anyone would resent Gary Whitley's central role throughout the last four years also being mentioned. Each of the departmental heads and other senior officers have made vital contributions-most recently and earlier, Tony Blunn and Bill Harris. I thank both of them and all of their officers who have been involved in this very demanding task.

The introduction of self-government will create a structure which will offer the ACT the opportunity for good quality, democratic government. Whether that occurs will depend on all adults in the ACT, for we will all be voters. I look forward with hope to working closely with the new members of the Legislative Assembly to ensure that the people of the ACT are represented fully effectively.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in this cognate debate on self-government for the Australian Capital Territory for a number of reasons. Firstly, for a time I carried some responsibility on behalf of the Opposition for the Australian Capital Territory. I must say that I enjoyed that opportunity. I see my old sparring partner and a former Minister for the Territory-the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren)-nodding agreement. I trust that he enjoyed it as well. I did enjoy that opportunity. However, I have another interest in the sense that I was born in the Australian Capital Territory and, unlike some of those who have arrived later and taken an interest, I have had a continuing interest over time, although I have moved to take a seat in the Parliament representing people from another community.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to look at the history regarding self-government for the Australian Capital Territory. I notice that the Minister for the Arts and Territories (Mr Holding) and the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) did not canvass that very much in their speeches. My colleague the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown) did not have a great deal of time to deal with it because of the substantial questions in the legislation before us that needed to be addressed. It is important to recognise that Canberra is Australia's capital. It is the symbol of Australian Federation, the home of the national Parliament, our High Court and the Executive headed by our Governor-General, and it has in it the headquarters of most government departments and statutory authorities.

TALK.START.PARA: —The X-rated video capital of Australia.

—It has a university of world renown. My colleague says that it has some notorious aspects to it. I hope that those matters are being addressed seriously by the Government, although there seems to have been some delay in that respect. From a former scattered township, it has become, in 20 years or so, a cosmopolitan, sophisticated city of more than 270,000 people. The capital has attracted many national organisations seeking influence. It is the home of the diplomatic corps and many national institutions. All of that has happened in recent years. It now has a diversified private sector, with about 50 per cent of people in employment working in the private sector.

SPEECH.PARA: Canberra is a capital city which shares the functions of many capital cities around the world. However, remarkably, not too many capitals are very much alike in their system of government. Washington and Canberra are the only two cities of which I am aware that have unique national capital areas: Canberra has the Australian Capital Territory. For a long time both Washington and Canberra shared this in common: they had no system of local government. However, since 1973 Washington has had a mayor and the Council of the District of Columbia Government. Canberra's history has been dotted with many proposals and promises over time of a form of self-government, but it is only now that we are looking at detailed proposals for self-government. I will turn to those shortly.

I want to make it clear in offering these comments that I do not regard it as all that remarkable that Canberra is achieving self-government. Lesser populated territories such as the Northern Territory and Norfolk Island have had arrangements for self-government pressed upon them; yet in Canberra, which is probably one of the best educated, most middle class and more articulate areas of Australia, a system of self-government has not developed and the question remained intractable over a long period.

It is also pertinent to note that, whilst the Government is taking a great deal of pride in having developed these proposals, it brings them forward at the same time as the national Parliament is debating whether Canberra should have a casino. It is not a question that has been left for the local community to determine. It is still a matter which the national Parliament is being asked to decide upon in advance of this legislation. It is remarkable over such a long period that, in one way or another, national parliaments, where they have deemed it appropriate, have wanted to maintain a continuing and long standing interest in the affairs of the national capital. I do not think that will change all that much. We will still have elected representatives in the national parliament after self-government is in place. The national Parliament has provided a forum in the past for various issues involving the Australian Capital Territory. Committees of the Parliament-the Public Accounts Committee, the Public Works Committee and the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances-have all played a role. As was mentioned by the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) who spoke before me, there have been two members of the House of Representatives, each with full participatory rights in this chamber, and two senators, each with full participatory rights. This situation is unlike that of the District of Columbia where, interestingly enough, its members of parliament have been able to vote in the Congress of the United States only on those matters which relate particularly to the District of Columbia. Canberra has had a very considerable voice in the national Parliament. I do not think we should neglect that in the way in which we observe this matter.

The first attempt at self-government proposals for the Australian Capital Territory was made in 1982, when one of three members of the Federal Capital Development Commission was elected on what was then a property franchise. It was a body deprived of administrative and executive powers. It lasted only two years. That was the first attempt at some form of participatory arrangements for the Australian Capital Territory. In May 1930 an advisory council of four appointed officials and three elected members was established. It was to be an advisory body to Ministers. Like most of its successors, it complained frequently that few of its recommendations were found acceptable. A majority of its members were elected-in 1952 five as against four and later eight as against four. By 1974 it was abolished.

As early as 1934 the Scullin Government expressed the view that within a few years it should be able to give the people full civic control of the city. In 1949 the Chifley Government asked the Hobart Town Clerk to inquire into a possible form of self-government for the Australian Capital Territory. In 1955 a Senate Select Committee on the Development of Canberra recommended a legislative council with a State-type function but no administrative powers, and with a multiplicity of local government arrangements appended to it. In 1957 the Institute of Public Administration study group recommended a national capital council, a form of statutory authority, with the later option of a Canberra City Council. In the meantime we still had these impotent advisory councils pressing for various local government or self-government options and using public inquiries and virtual strikes-in 1969 there was a mass resignation-as devices to press their case.

In 1967 one of my former colleagues, Mr Anthony, as Minister for the Interior, proposed Commonwealth control of central Canberra with a hand-over at a later date of State-type functions and with new municipal governments in the Woden and Belconnen cities. Mr Hunt, who is still in this Parliament as the honourable member for Gwydir and who was Mr Anthony's successor as Minister for the Interior, suggested in 1971 that 1980 would be a date for self-government. Needless to say, the Advisory Council pressed for a more definite statement of policy at that time and a public inquiry into self-government.

With Labor in office in 1972 Labor Ministers asserted the freedom of the Australian Government to protect its interests in the seat of government. That was a statement by a former member for Canberra, Mr Enderby. The Advisory Council's term was extended to 30 September 1974 and the question of self-government was referred to the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the Australian Capital Territory. In May 1974 the election debate over self-government was joined and Prime Minister Whitlam asserted that self-government would arrive as soon as practicable after the presentation of the Committee's report.

The Liberal Party had some views on those questions. It released a policy in 1974 with an assertion that the Liberal Party aimed to have a legislative assembly that should attain the responsibilities and powers associated with the administration of the Australian Capital Territory, apart from the national capital aspects which should properly remain the responsibility of the Commonwealth Government. That policy was predicated on the change instituted by Gordon Bryant, as the then Minister, to create an Australian Capital Territory Legislative Assembly of 18 members elected from two of the Canberra Federal electorates-nine from each of Canberra and Fraser.

In 1975 the Committee tabled its report. It was a multi-party report. It recommended that self-government be granted to the Australian Capital Territory in as wide terms as was consistent with the national interest. It recommended a unicameral legislative assembly operating on parliamentary lines and with powers delegated in stages. The report was subject to many criticisms of detail and progress was pretty slow in relation to that. The events of 1975 overtook that committee report and the deliberations that were occurring.

The new Government headed by Malcolm Fraser came to power in 1975 with a commitment to begin the transfer of particular legislative and executive powers to the assembly by July 1976. It established a task force which by March 1976 had reported on a program of transfer of functions and necessary legislative, administrative and financial arrangements for such a transfer. The task force proposed a staged devolution of legislative and executive powers. By February 1976 Tony Staley was in office. The July deadline could not be met. In September 1977 he released detailed proposals for a one step delegation.

Interestingly enough, the Staley proposals, which were most complex, were somewhat open-ended in relation to the question of the financial implications of these new arrangements for Canberra. I think it is important to note-because it is a matter I will address in this debate-that he made some comments which were then to be the major stumbling block in terms of the pace at which we moved to self-government. I quote from the statement he released under the heading `Financial arrangements':
A separate treasury would be established for the assembly-
that is, the Capital Territory assembly-

and the moneys of the Assembly would not be paid into the Consolidated Revenue Fund of the Commonwealth. The enabling legislation would include a provision to the effect that all moneys raised by the Assembly would be placed in an appropriate assembly fund, with no moneys to be expended from the fund except through an appropriation by the Assembly. The budget of the Assembly would be prepared to cover relevant items of revenue and expenditure.
Detailed receipts which he gave for 1975-76 illustrated the financial situation of the Australian Capital Territory. He went on to say:

The figures demonstrate the substantial gap between the proceeds of municipal and territorial rates and taxes and the total receipts required to meet the costs and functions at the existing standards of service. To some large extent the gap is currently bridged by Commonwealth funds which can be seen as taking the place of funds received by the States in the form of capital and revenue grants and approved borrowing programs. In financial negotiations with the Commonwealth the Assembly would be expected to reduce this gap progressively. The result of these negotiations would largely determine the Assembly's annual budget and the standards of service to be provided.

I found that statement to be somewhat prophetic because, when we look at the Minister's own statement now in terms of the financial arrangements, we see that these same questions are very much before us. In 1978 when Mr Staley's successor, Bob Ellicott, announced that there would be a referendum on the question of self-government these financial arrangements were very much in the minds of the people.

Interestingly enough, when the people of the Australian Capital Territory had an opportunity to vote on whether they wanted self-government we saw that only 30.01 per cent of people voted in favour of the proposition that self-government be granted to the Australian Capital Territory by delegating functions to a locally elected body in stages; only 5.63 per cent voted for the proposition that a locally elected legislative body be established in the Territory with local government type legislative and executive functions; and 62.67 per cent voted for the existing arrangements for governing the Territory to continue for the time being. After that we saw that the Legislative Assembly was reconstituted on an advisory basis. The Commonwealth Grants Commission was asked to undertake certain inquiries and the issue of self-government for the Australian Capital Territory thereafter was joined. Of course, the Labor Party came into office with a commitment to giving self-government to the Australian Capital Territory. My own Party took the view, the second last time it went to the people, that the people of the Australian Capital Territory should be given another opportunity to decide by way of referendum whether they were in favour of a form of self-government.

I think it is pertinent to note that this Government has been in office for more than five years. They have had a a great deal of time in which to look at proposals and to develop them. We are looking at them now. I do not think one could necessarily say that the proposal is timely if one had an urgent desire to put self-government in place. I think the process has been protracted. In my judgment the thoughtful development of self-government for Canberra has probably been the better way to proceed. However, I do not think that one should see it as being as momentous as some honourable members would have us believe from their comments.

I said that I would address two matters in relation to the present proposals before us. The first matter is in relation to the ACT's financial autonomy. The Commonwealth has promised a number of things, as can be seen from the Minister's second reading speech. Firstly, the Minister promised that there will be direct access by the Australian Capital Territory to the Commonwealth Grants Commission at the ACT's request. He said that the Commonwealth in its funding to the ACT will recognise the effects of Canberra's role as the national capital on such things as the standards and costs of works and services. He did not mention the higher costs resulting from those standards of works and services. I notice a wry smile on the faces of some of those departmental advisers in the chamber who consider these matters. The Minister also said that the Commonwealth will retain responsibility for financing its functions within the Territory. I think that that, of course, is very appropriate. Of course, later the Minister said that after an appropriate guarantee period-we know that is of only several years:
. . . funding will be the subject of negotiation with the Executive . . .
It is certainly no blank cheque. The Minister went on to say in his second reading speech:
These arrangements will complete the ongoing process of bringing ACT finances into line with the rest of Australia . . .

It seems to me that the Minister is saying: `Sure we are going to fund you on the same basis as the States are funded by the Commonwealth, but no better and no worse'. That is how I understand the statement. The implications of that must be that the residents of the Australian Capital Territory over time will pay more. It is interesting to note that in the Minister's speech he made the observation:
In terms of the financial impact on the Commonwealth, the Bill will not involve additional Commonwealth expenditures . . .
I am certain that is not the case. More importantly, he said:
Savings will accrue to the Commonwealth through separation of responsibilities of ACT administration from the Commonwealth system.

In other words, charges for residents of the Australian Capital Territory will rise. The costs will be borne by those people who live here and who are being given this opportunity to have a say in the government of the Australian Capital Territory. I do not object to that. I do not think the people of Australia would object to it. However, I think it is important that the people of the Australian Capital Territory understand it; in other words, they should not have it thrust upon them without a clear understanding of what the implications are.

The other matter I want to address is in relation to the voting system. The Minister was at pains to emphasise that there was an effort on his part to compromise over time. He asked firstly for compromise on two bases-bases which I must say were absolutely outrageous; and totally unacceptable. The fact that the Government has moved from them I think is evidence of that alone. The system of direct proportional representation has been proposed for the ACT. This is a system which will not enable people to make choices as between candidates across political boundaries. They can make effective choices only between candidates within the political party for which they are principally voting. While there have been certain marginal modifications made to that system--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support self-government for the Australian Capital Territory (ACT). I am pleased that it is to become a reality. As Minister for Territories and Local Government in 1983-84, I introduced a number of measures moving in this direction. I hold a firm conviction that people should have a greater say over their lives and should not be governed by a patriarch, or a group of patriarchs as has been the case up until now in the ACT.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to pay tribute to the fine work carried out by Gordon Craig, the Chairperson of the Albury-Wodonga Development Corporation, who was seconded to the ACT Administration in the early days of the Hawke Government to prepare the way for self-government in the ACT. He did quite a remarkable job of education over the very wide community in the ACT. I would like also to place on record my respect for the fine work done by the National Capital Development Commission (NCDC). It has created a magnificent national capital of which all Australians can be proud.

A great deal of credit for the development of Canberra must be given to Robert Menzies for the establishment of the National Capital Development Commission in 1957 and, above all, giving it the support and resources it needed to function effectively. I was the Minister responsible for the National Capital Development Commission for five years of my political life-first as the Minister for Urban and Regional Development from 1972 to 1975 in the Whitlam Government and then again as Minister for Territories and Local Government from March 1983 until December 1984 in the Hawke Government.

The NCDC was not without criticism. I always thought it needed greater democratisation and more social understanding in its planning decisions. It needed to talk to people before it planned many of its projects and programs-not consult after an elite had decided what it felt was best for the people. It was for that reason that I appointed Jill Lang as an Associate Commissioner for the National Capital Development Commission in October 1984 to help bring about a more democratic and caring Commission. I say with some sadness that it is regrettable that such a talented public servant has been lost to the Public Service here in Canberra. I would like also to express my concern that Canberra lacks a decent, efficient rapid public transport system. As in all cities in Australia the car is God. That should have been avoided here in Canberra.

In the limited time I have I want to concentrate my remarks on the Australian Capital Territory (Planning and Land Management) Bill 1988. I have already stated that the people of Canberra should have control over their own lives. However, it must be understood that the land of the ACT belongs to the people of the Australian nation as a whole, not just to the people of Canberra. Public ownership of land and the development rights on it have enabled the Commonwealth to pursue its objectives free from the effects of land speculation and private interest. Public land ownership and integrated planning and development have enabled urban development to be coordinated on a scale far greater than anywhere else in Australia. There is no comparison anywhere else in Australia with the coordination that has been carried out here. The residents of the ACT have collectively reaped the benefit of this urban planning.

Under the proposed legislation there would be a division between national and territorial land for funding certain planning development and for management purposes. This would mean an end to the benefits currently gained from coordinating all land development with planning. The control of land in the ACT, and the accompanying development rights, would become a territorial function, subject to the declaration of national land by the Minister for the Arts and Territories. In practice, this will mean an effective Commonwealth loss of control of land and development rights. Land speculation will increase as a result of no further public land development. I say this quite advisedly: next to the Gorton Government's serious decision to amend the land tenure system in 1970, this proposal is a threat to the land tenure system in Canberra.

The Canberra system of ownership and control of land is the best of any operating in Australia. The sad thing about this proposal, in so far as land is concerned, is that it is a thimble and pea proposal. Because self-government has been designed so that the ACT Government will have access to the revenues and land and development rights over most of the ACT, economic necessity is likely to be the basis upon which future declarations of land are made. Land that is not designated or declared national will become territorial land. When the Commonwealth requires territorial land for its purposes in the future it will have to buy this land back from the ACT Government in accordance with compensation provisions outlined in the Land Acquisitions Act. Initially, the Commonwealth will transfer the land of the ACT to the territorial administration at nil cost, but the Commonwealth will have to pay market value in future years if it requires any further land. In effect, the Commonwealth will be paying the ACT Government for land and associated development rights that it presently owns.

The value of development rights for ACT land is currently in the order of $20m to $30m annually, which is marginally less than 2 per cent of the ACT budget. However, given the expected shortfall in revenues of some $80m in the Territory budget, there would be pressures for exploiting land for revenue purposes. I am deeply concerned about this. Planning powers alone have always proved insufficient to prevent all such exploitation. The proposal for privatising land development carries with it a loss of the benefits of comprehensive planning and development currently enjoyed by the ACT. It could easily result in the fragmentation of development areas with spasmodic or sparse development, causing higher costs in the provision of major infrastructure and services and also in the provision of community facilities. Escalating costs could jeopardise land affordability, particularly for first home buyers.

I know something about the cost spiral in this city as it applies to land. The honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) said that there was no real investment in land between 1978 and 1982. In fact, when I left government in 1976 there was a stockpile of 5,000 blocks of land. By the time we came to government in 1983, there were only 200 blocks. The situation with regard to the increase in the price of land was so serious that the priority of the Hawke Government in its first two years was to divert investment money into the development of land and public housing. That we stuck at. I do not like to boast in this way, but basically it was the pipeline that was set up then that put this area into a stable position. Regrettably even this Government did not continue with the land development, and there is a tendency in the Government even to move away from the public sector, which had proved to be so successful over many years in Canberra.

One might ask: What is the solution to the problems of the ACT planning and land management that would occur as a result of this legislation? And what is to be the fate of areas such as Namadgi National Park? Should Namadgi be territorial land or should it be administered by the National Parks and Wildlife Service? The park represents such a large proportion of ACT land that, if it remains under the control of the Territory, it will be continually under pressure from developers. There will be a never-ending series of grandiose schemes proposed for part of its development. The growth of Canberra will be an ongoing threat to the Namadgi National Park. Further, if Namadgi is not retained as part of the Commonwealth, the Northern Territory Government, I am sure, will ask why Kakadu and Uluru national parks should be administered by the Commonwealth when Namadgi National Park is not. It will be stated that this represents double standards in the Commonwealth's approach to the Northern Territory and the ACT. I would question the economic capacity of the ACT population of 250,000, or even if it grew to 500,000 people, to pay for the maintenance, upkeep and development of such a large national park. This will only add to the pressure from the developers.

What of the land in the Tuggeranong Valley beyond the Murrumbidgee? What about the land surrounding Lanyon? Will the Murrumbidgee conservation zone survive the developers' threats of future growth and the reliance of the ACT Administration on increased revenue from land? In my view, Namadgi is a national park and a national responsibility and should therefore be administered nationally. I do not talk lightly about conservation areas in Canberra. I know the economic pressures involved. After all, it was only a few years ago that I was the Minister who created the Namadgi National Park, under pressure and against opposition. I created the Murrumbidgee conservation area, against opposition. There were pressures to build bridges and to have a population of 75,000 on the other side of the Murrumbidgee. Of course, there were grandiose residential development schemes for the land around Lanyon. The Government should not talk about what protection it is going to have. As a former Minister, I know of the pressures then. I know the pressures that some conservative governments have used in other parts of Australia when they have come to office. Let us not kid ourselves about what protection there will be in Canberra. It will be money hungry Canberra, and I have no doubt about that. One of the sad things about this administration transfer is that, instead of giving cash, it has given land and the opportunity to raise revenue from that land. I believe that this is one of the weaknesses of this legislation and one of the weaknesses of the action of this Government.

The Commonwealth should not have to declare certain lands national in order to protect its own estate. The Commonwealth should be able to declare certain lands territorial and to do it progressively as the national capital plan is developed. In this manner the Commonwealth will maintain both ownership and control of its own estate and retain a stake in the development rights of the lands vested in it. All undeveloped land in the Territory should remain the responsibility of the Commonwealth. There are cost implications arising from land in the ACT remaining under Commonwealth management, and there would need to be recognition of this by the Commonwealth. If ownership of land in the ACT is to mean anything, the presumption should be that the land owned by the Commonwealth should be controlled by the Commonwealth. Under the proposed legislation the presumption is that all land is to be Territory land unless the Commonwealth makes a decision to declare land national.

In the last few minutes, I will turn to make some comments on the preparation of the national capital plan. The legislation sets out that the policies of the National Capital Development Commission will remain in force in the interim period between the repeal of the previous legislation and the preparation of new territorial plans and the national capital plan. However, I believe that to allow only 12 months to prepare and agree to a national capital plan is unrealistic. In the real world it is a pipedream. I say that to the Minister for the Arts and Territories (Mr Holding) quite advisedly. As part of this process the National Capital Planning Authority is obliged to undertake consultation with the Canberra community and the territorial assembly. At the minimum this would take six to 12 months, even longer, if there is to be proper democratic participation and input. This would leave a minimum time to complete a highly technical and very important task. The work could not be properly completed and the Parliament would be looking at a series of amendments. The job should be done properly the first time and adequate time should be allowed for the consultative and the mechanical processes that are necessary.

I have been tough in some of my remarks. I know that the Minister inherited this legislation, and I make no personal reflection on him. I know he has to steer it through but there are some strong criticisms about planning and control. The planning of this Bill has been shallow and ill-founded. I am not impressed with the structure of the National Capital Planning Authority. At best it appears to be in a one-man band; at worst it seems to be a powder puff authority. According to the explanatory memorandum, the National Authority may have a Chairperson and three other members, all part time, as well as a full time Chief Executive. Alternatively, the Chairperson may be appointed full time Chief Executive, in which case there would be four other part time members. The NCPA will be subject to general direction by the Minister.

I do not like part time committees. There will be a staff of 35. I understand that of that staff only 17 will be skilled planners, architects and engineers. The rest will be support staff. Not too many of them are trained to consult with the general public. I think the Department of Finance is squeezing this organisation at an early stage. It is true that the chairman could be the executive officer as well. That would give it some backbone but it would emphasise its position as a one-man band. I doubt very much whether any part time officers can combat an organisation that owes its loyalty to and obtains its information from the executive officer. If it is lucky, it may get people of integrity such as Max Neutze or Pat Troy, who know the planning problems. But as time goes on and there are no Max Neutzes or Pat Troys about, the Government will find it very hard indeed to get people of high calibre on that body. At this stage I prefer to call the National Capital Planning Authority a powder puff organisation. That is sad for me to say but such an organisation is to be responsible for the whole planning of Canberra. I emphasise to my colleagues that the land of Canberra belongs to the nation and it will be sad if the planning of Canberra breaks down.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —After hearing the less than enthusiastic support given to the legislation by the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren), one wonders to what extent the Government has probed all the aspects that the honourable member considers necessary to a good arrangement for self-government in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT). We on this side of the House have many suspicions as to what type of job the Government did to provide the best legislation it could. The type of self-government proposed is limited to a large extent. Over recent years we have seen the residents of Canberra made to dance on the strings of circumstances and juggled by the government of the day.

SPEECH.PARA: After the less than enthusiastic support of the honourable member for Reid I also believe that the residents of Canberra will be suspicious of many aspects of this legislation, particularly the retaining of powers by the Commonwealth under the new management arrangement. Such powers include the powers to make laws for the establishment of courts, the provision of police, the admission of legal practitioners, the making of corporate law and the making of ordinances which will override the laws of the Territory. This gives substantial power to the Government.

Certain residual powers have not yet been transferred to the Northern Territory either. They cover uranium mining and royalties, industrial matters and Aboriginal land. Residual powers reserved to the Commonwealth will stifle the economic development of the ACT as it tries to take its rightful place within our nation. There has been a tremendous anchor on the economic progress of the Northern Territory because of the powers retained by the Commonwealth. Residual powers are also a feature of this legislation. They will halt economic progress in the ACT. The Territory will not be able to take its full place within the Commonwealth.

The legislation envisages for the ACT Commonwealth funding arrangements the same as those for the States and the Northern Territory. It is a little unfair if the ACT is to be treated as a State for funding purposes but not given the powers of a State. This matter has not been fully addressed. I understand that the budget that is contemplated is about $1 billion, with 17,000 public servants. It will be a tremendous undertaking. The Brisbane City Council may be responsible for a larger area and probably four times the population, but the ACT Legislative Assembly will still be a big undertaking.

At this stage there is too little parliamentary supervision and probably too little accountability. One would hope that, with self-government, these limiting factors will be addressed and that there will be improved accountability. Self-government will also allow ACT representatives to administer their own affairs. It is very important that that be understood. But they will be limited in that representation because full powers will not be passed on to them. Elected members in the ACT should be allowed to govern as they would in a normal assembly.

I note that the Governor-General can dismiss the Assembly. I go back to this Government's recent experience of dismissing assemblies. The Christmas Island assembly was dismissed two weeks after election. I find that unpardonable.

TALK.START.PARA: —They got the wrong result, did they?

—They obviously got the wrong result. But if the Federal Government is so determined to give a territory self-government, I do not think that to sack an assembly after two weeks of a popular election is the way to go about it. I note this because I do not think the people of Canberra should be under any illusion that the Government would not act in exactly the same way if the mood took it. It also knocked off the only economic base that Christmas Island had-mining. It cancelled the mining endeavour that was being undertaken by the Commonwealth. At this stage it is in the melting pot as to what private enterprise people might take it up. I also note the situation with Norfolk Island, where the Assembly is trying to get back the artefact of the sailboat Sirius, which is one of the boats that formed the First Fleet. It is very much a part of Australian history, yet until less than 12 months ago this Government was denying this artefact to the Norfolk Island people. But due to pressure from the Norfolk Islanders, the Government has relented in that regard.

SPEECH.PARA: The Governor-General's sanction can be applied in certain cases, one might say in controversial issues. The Governor-General has the power to dissolve the Assembly if he determines it is incapable of effectively performing its function, or if it is conducting its affairs in a grossly improper manner. I just ask: Under what definition would one try to interpret that, in view of what happened at Christmas Island? As far as this Government is concerned, all of this Bill has the potential to do exactly the same as happened with the other territories.

I turn to the funding and the powers. This Bill allows the Assembly to provide its own Treasury. It will have the capacity to raise funds and the power to tax-basically the same powers as the States and the Northern Territory. As I said before, the ACT will be treated on the same basis as the States in regard to Commonwealth funding. I come back to the argument: without a decent economic base, just how does a Territory or an Assembly provide that sort of income?

There are powers of restraint. In the Northern Territory, as I said, the Commonwealth retains power over mining royalties and the full use of Aboriginal land. It was interesting to note the comments of the honourable member for Reid in this regard. He was complaining about there being too much of a free hand regarding land, yet the same right was not completely but partially denied to the Northern Territory in many ways. Restraint has also been exercised by the Commonwealth by promises it has given at various times. I mention the Darwin to Alice Springs railway line which was to be a means by which economic development could take place. The promise was made also in relation to the Darwin Airport, and action has fallen well short of the promise. There have been delays in the giving of final decisions on the stock routes for the Northern Territory and there have been disputes over the Ashmore and Cartier Islands.

The honourable member for Reid also mentioned the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service, which has complete control over the Uluru and Kakadu national parks. This is a restraining factor and the management of the parks could be better done by the Northern Territory Commission on a day to day basis. Somebody said that, on the basis of applying that rule, perhaps the Australian Capital Territory National Parks and Wildlife Service should take over the botanical gardens and be subject to the influences of Professor Ovington. So there is a lack of consistency in connection with some of the decisions.

When we look at the Australian Capital Territory being treated on the same basis as the States regarding funding, there is a great example in the State of Queensland as far as the funding of health services is concerned. Queensland has lagged miserably behind other States because of the peculiar situation Queensland was in at the time of transfer. The issue of increasing those health funds was only recently addressed, but at the same time the State grant was so reduced, so Queensland is still disadvantaged in that regard. And this could quite easily happen in the Australian Capital Territory.

I also wish to mention the constitutionality of the situation. I refer particularly to local government because in its own way this might be referred to as an enlarged form of local government. We have seen a denial of funds to local government by successive reductions in the percentage of personal income tax that has been given to it and also more recently the continued reduction of funds for local roads. Recently in a referendum the Government tried to hide this type of thing by trying to push through constitutional recognition of local government. There again, Canberra will probably have the same difficulties with financing as local government.

The Legislative Assembly will consist of 17 elected members. The Assembly will elect a Presiding Officer and a Chief Minister. The Chief Minister will appoint three other Ministers and these four people will form the Executive.

I raise a point about the National Capital Planning Authority and the use in due course of the old Parliament House. To my knowledge no decision has yet been made on that, and I believe it is probably within the realm of government still to make a decision. But I do believe it is time some decision was made as to the planned use of the old Parliament House-whether it will become a constitutional museum or whether it is destined for the blade of a bulldozer, or whatever. There is concern. It is a matter of national interest, yet no decision has been made. One might propose that the new Assembly might use one of the old rooms in which to conduct its affairs and take over partial use of the building while the rest is maintained as a constitutional museum. But I do think it is time that some decision was made on it, and this might be the appropriate time to mention it.

I refer to the voting pattern. Again a referendum was held and the Government tried to say to the people of Australia that the Commonwealth knows best and that the States should apply the one vote one value system. It would be interesting to know just how close to one vote one value the new voting pattern will be. I understand it will be close to the figure usually established within a democracy: if a party gets 50 per cent plus one of the votes, it rules. I want to compare that with the Commonwealth's own electoral system, which is far from perfect. I hope that no attempt whatsoever will be made to inflict that type of system on the Assembly if we are really striving for one vote one value. In the July 1987 Federal election the conservatives, having gained 25,000 more votes than the Australian Labor Party, lost by 25 seats.

TALK.START.PARA: —A black day.

—A black day, yes, not only for Canberra but for the rest of Australia. If the Government wants to say that that is a one vote one value system, where we on the conservative side have to gain over 52 per cent of the vote to win government, I just hope that the people of Canberra are not inflicted with that.

SPEECH.PARA: The States of Victoria and New South Wales are notorious in this regard. In the last election in Victoria the conservatives again won the majority of votes but failed to win government. In New South Wales the conservatives had to gain 52.5 per cent of the vote just to break even. Perhaps the Minister for the Arts and Territories (Mr Holding) might apply himself to that and assure this side of the House that no such gerrymander will apply as far as the Assembly is concerned as obviously applies in those other States and to the Commonwealth itself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it interesting that a representative from Queensland talks about gerrymanders. I do not think anyone could be a greater expert than a Queensland member of the National Party. In Queensland governments have been elected with 19 per cent of the vote.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to address the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Bill and cognate Bills before the House. I do not wish to roam all over the Pacific Ocean, the Indian Ocean and other parts of the world. Many of the examples which have been quoted by the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) are not very accurate and really do not do him credit. Canberra is the national capital and I think we should start with that point. It is not a Territory dissociated from the Commonwealth Government and it is not a State. It can never be a State. The Constitution provides that it will be the national capital. It was set aside from New South Wales for that purpose, and that is what it must remain.

The complaint that all powers over the national capital will not be transferred to local residents is one which does not stand up to critical examination and certainly was not reflected in the changes which were given to the Northern Territory by a government of another colour on another occasion. The Commonwealth Parliament does, under these Bills, retain certain powers over the national capital-in particular, over the planning and future development of and land use in this area. After 50 years of governments of almost every complexion imaginable, this city has developed into something which I believe every Australian should be proud of. It has developed under Ministers of diverse views and under planning authorities which have changed on several occasions. The National Capital Development Commission (NCDC) has existed since 1955. I believe that the present Canberra is the result of the wisdom of the government of that day-and it was not a Labor government-in setting the NCDC above day to day interference by Ministers and allowing it to plan the overall development of Canberra on a basis which is now evident. I believe it is a credit to every person who has contributed.

Prior to that, the National Capital Commission and other bodies-and sometimes Ministers-were responsible for Canberra. But the city we see today is a postwar phenomenon, and it is largely a Menzies phenomenon because he was the person who gave the impetus to the growth of Canberra in the early 1950s which resulted in Canberra reaching the size it is today.

Self-government and representation have been very slow in coming. When I came to this Parliament, the honourable member for the Australian Capital territory, Jim Fraser, went home at 5 o'clock because there was no point in his staying here as he was not allowed to participate in the affairs of this Parliament as a representative of the people of the national capital, and he had no vote. He had a great life as a member of this Parliament, but a very frustrating one because he could express his view only on those occasions when a matter directly and very narrowly relevant to the people of the Australian Capital Territory was before the Parliament. He obtained a vote, but Canberra had only one member. With the growth of Canberra, that number was expanded to two members. In 1974, and only after a double dissolution of the Parliament and a Joint Sitting, the ACT was represented in the Senate-a move opposed, I might say, by the gentlemen opposite.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a bit difficult for me to do as I was not here then.

—I said `gentlemen'. There were no ladies from the honourable member's Party in the Parliament at that time. I suppose the idea of ACT self-government gained real impetus with the election of the present Government. Prior to that it had been discussed, but it never became a serious proposal. In 1974, Gordon Bryant tried with his Assembly proposal, which envisaged that the Assembly would be given additional powers within 12 months and that subsequently its powers would be expanded. That did not occur, and ultimately I had the job of putting the Assembly to a peaceful and kindly death because it had reached the stage where its members must have found it extraordinarily frustrating to go on year after year with virtually nothing to do but to distribute the grants within the Canberra support systems for community organisations-and even then the Minister had power if he wished to exercise it.

SPEECH.PARA: I actually introduced the first Bills on self-government that went through this Parliament. They were passed in this House, and they included an electoral system based on single member electorates, which I still believe is the preferable system for direct answerability to the community and for the exercise of the responsibilities of government. They were not treated seriously by the Opposition and at no stage were any serious discussions able to be entered into on the passage of those Bills. Unfortunately, the Democrats had a Senator called Vigor. It is fair to say that he was prepared to compromise and he put up compromises about five times a day all with the proviso on all to the effect, `You will accept what I want'. I did not accept that approach. I think that we could have done with that transfer of power.

It is more than timely that the ACT had to decide its affairs some body which is elected and responsible to the people of the ACT. Members represent their views in the same way as do other members of this Parliament and they have to carry their national responsibilities-which should be a full time task-plus the responsibilities of being local government members and State members in this Territory. Whoever the Minister is, he largely occupies a position which has no relevance whatsoever to the Federal Parliament or the Federal Cabinet. It is worse than ludicrous to go to Cabinet over a dispute or a method of garbage handling or something on those lines. It is certainly not a matter which the national Parliament or national Government should be involved in. It represents solely the needs and the views of local people.

We have heard a fair amount in this debate about the financial arrangements and the capacity of the Territory to meet its obligations. On the last occasion when these figures were examined this Territory was contributing more to the overall upkeep of the services of this Territory than was at least one State, and certainly more than was the Northern Territory, and the figure was very close to the levels provided in South Australia. It is not true to say that the Territory is incapable of funding itself if it is supported by the Commonwealth for the national purposes which are provided in this area, and to the extent that support is given to the States to meet the gaps between their capacity and the funds which they are able to raise. The Loan Council will be charged with the responsibility of ensuring that the level of support for the ACT equals the burden in the ACT of running its own affairs in the same way as applies to the smaller States.

My colleague the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren) is concerned about the Namadgi National Park, which is a reasonable attitude since he was responsible for its development. As I understand the Act, the Namadgi National Park cannot be altered without the approval of this Parliament. Whether it is a national park vested in the Commonwealth national parks area or the administration of the Territory, this Parliament will always have the power to alter legislation which it itself has passed and to alter those things which it has created. In the ultimate, anything that is created by legislation of this Parliament is capable of being altered by legislation of this Parliament.

I have some concerns about some of the planning aspects. I have raised them with the Minister for the Arts and Territories (Mr Holding) and there will be some amendments to meet those concerns. I was concerned that in the transition period and in the presentation of the national plan alterations to existing restricted areas and so on could be made by omission by not being included in the new plan. The amendments which are to be moved protect that position, and any change which is made to the restrictions or basic plan of Canberra in the new plan will have to be clearly identified and subject to either disallowance or restoration by a resolution of either House of Parliament. That is the way in which the planning changes have been dealt with.

A number of people have worked very hard and for a long time on the development of proposals for self-government in Canberra. It has taken a long time for the people of the ACT to recognise that ultimately they have to make their own decisions. It is not in their best interests in the long term to be a creature of the national government at the whims of national policies which may not necessarily coincide with their needs or ambitions.

The honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) mentioned some people who had been involved with self-government. Mr Whitley, who is in the gallery tonight, worked endlessly for about four years on this project. I think a lot of thanks should go to him. Paul Whalan, who is also in the gallery and who was the Leader of the Australian Labor Party in the House of Assembly, has been a driving force in getting the legislation into the Parliament. I might say that it was not only the Opposition that did not necessarily look on self-government as the most important thing that would come up in the national Parliament in this or any other term. The Government also took a lot of convincing a few years ago that we should proceed on this course. One other person that I would like to mention-and I could mention many-is John Enfield, who was the Secretary of the Department of Territories. He contributed materially to the real-hard technical work in preparing the ACT Administration for transfer to self-government.

Fourteen Ministers used to come into this place with budgets that contained State-type ACT expenditure. We had Ministers all over the place administering the ACT. That situation has been totally changed over the last five years. We are now able to present a consolidated ACT budget with expenditures and incomes being shown very clearly. That budget is formulated in a manner which will enable the new governing body to take over an operative and clearly designated cost and revenue structure.

I thank the Minister for the Arts and Territories (Mr Holding) for the changes that have been made to the planning Bills. I think they protect the national interest. There is a national interest and a national pride in the national capital. This Parliament has a responsibility to ensure that ultimately the national capital aspect of the Territory is our responsibility and the aspect which deals with the lives of the people who live in the Territory is the Territory's responsibility.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOLDING
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Territories)

I give an undertaking to those honourable members, as I have to the Opposition, that the mere passage of this legislation through this House does not foreclose our examining all of the contributions that have been made by honourable members tonight. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 1 September 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to an advertisement on 28 November 1987 which sought public comment on the including of Rape (Brassica napus) under the Plant Variety Rights Act.
(2) Why does the Plant Varieties Journal state that it proposed to include `Brassica sp (oilseeds) (rape, mustard, etc)' when public comment has not been sought.
(3) What is meant by `etc' and what plants are covered.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Not specifically but I was aware of the advertisements inviting public comment.

(2) Because of comments received which indicated that intending applicants would require the Act to include varieties of Brassica oilseeds belonging to species and species hybrids other than B. napus. Brassica sp is more appropriate in the regulations to cover the eligible new varieties.
Public comment was actually being sought by publishing the proposed schedule in the Plant Varieties Journal. No comments have been received.

(3) `etc' is an abbreviation of et cetera meaning `and others'. In this instance it refers to other common names by which the oilseed Brassica sp are known. The names Canola, turnip rape, giant kangaroo rape, toria, sarson and raya are some examples.
