TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In answering this question I have interpreted some of the names given as intending to refer to the following plant names: (b) Ilex paraguayensis, (j) Lolium perenne, (k) Hyoscyamus muticus, (m) Salvia lavanduloides, (n) Santalum spicatum, (t) Curcuma longa, (v) Hevea brasiliensis, (w) Papaver nudicaule and (x) Asparagus sprengeri `Meyeri'.

With the exception of (b), (j), (r) and (x), all the names represent plants whose genera are potentially covered by the Plant Variety Rights Act but not yet declared by regulation in accordance with section 13 of the Act.

(b) Ilex paraguayensis, from which a stimulant beverage is prepared in South America, belongs to a group of plants which is on the proposed schedule for declaration by Plant Variety Rights Regulations. The genus Ilex, which includes holly and other related ornamentals, is proposed to be covered by the Plant Variety Rights Act by January 1989.
(j) Lolium perenne, which is commonly known as perennial ryegrass belongs to a group of plants declared by Plant Variety Rights Regulations No. 1 of April 1988 to which the Act applies.
(r) Tuber melanosporum, the French truffle, is excluded from the Plant Variety Rights Act in section 1 because it is a fungus.
(x) Asparagus sprengeri `Meyeri', an ornamental asparagus variety, is ineligible under section 14 of the Plant Variety Rights Act because it has been previously sold in Australia.

(2) There is no final date for submissions for inclusion of plants under the Act. It is intended to have all appropriate plant species included under the Act in regulations by March 1990. Any submissions for earlier inclusion of plant groups in the proposed schedule are processed promptly.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment and Education Services, on notice, on 24 March 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Were the 735,000 of the 930,000 vacancies referred to on page 81 of 1987-88 Budget-Related Paper No. 9 entitled ``Skills Formation in Australia'' in fact filled by the CES or were some of the positions registered with the CES filled by other employment agencies or by direct contact between the job applicant and the employer.
(2) If not all the positions were filled by the CES directly, what percentage was actually filled directly by the CES.
(3) What are the progress figures for 1987-88 for (a) job applicants registered, (b) positions vacant registered and (c) the percentage of jobs directly filled by the CES.
(4) What percentage of persons unemployed to date in 1987-88 have been unemployed for 6 months or more.
(5) What percentage of the long term unemployed to date in 1987-88 are aged 55-64 years.
(6) What percentage of Aboriginals of working age are employed and how much higher is the Aboriginal unemployment rate compared with the national unemployment rate.
(7) How many adults have benefited from the expanded Adult Training Program in 1987-88 and what percentage of (a) these adults were sole parents and (b) all adults and sole parents were women.
(8) How many traineeships have been granted to date in 1987-88 under the Australian Traineeship Scheme.
(9) What steps has the Government taken to increase industry's contribution to the national training effort.

(10) What steps has the Government taken to achieve a more effective relationship between industry and the formal education sector in matters such as curriculum development, the sharing of training facilities and equipment, and the provision of training itself.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The quoted figures were approximations. During 1986-87, the CES received 927,487 vacancies and the CES directly filled 734,158. These figures do not include vacancies filled by any other means.

(3) Figures for the period 1.7.87-30.6.88 are: (a) job seekers registered 2,299,618; (b) vacancies notified 1,005,986; (c) the CES has directly filled 787,016 vacancies (78.23% of vacancies notified).
(4) The Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) August 1988 Labour Force Survey shows that 48% of unemployed people have been unemployed for more than 6 months.
(5) ABS August 1988 Labour Force Survey shows that people in the age group 55-64 years comprise the following percentages of the total unemployed for the following categories.
* Care must be exercised in interpreting these estimates due to sampling variability.

(6) The most recent reliable estimate of Aboriginal employment, the 1986 Census, indicated that 42,878 Aboriginal persons (31 per cent of those of working age) were employed at 30 June 1986. Aboriginal unemployment was measured at 35 per cent compared with a national unemployment rate of 9.2 per cent measured by the Census at that time.
(7) 15,100 people benefited from the expanded Adult Training Program in 1987-88.
(a) 13.6% of these adults were sole parents
(8) There were over 10,000 trainee commencements under the Australian Traineeship System from 1 July 1987 to 30 June 1988.

(9) The Government's integrated approach to employment, education and training is outlined in `A Changing Workforce', a paper released with the Treasurer's May Statement. As elaborated in that paper, the Government is pursuing a coherent strategy to lift industry contribution to training. It has established the Task Force to examine a range of issues on this aspect. The Task Force's report will be released later this year, and will be the subject of extensive consultations with all relevant parties before the Government takes any final decisions on this issue.

In addition to encouraging industry to make a greater contribution towards the cost of training, the Government is participating in various forums to move the training system towards a competency based approach. The Government has also supported, in appropriate forums, industry restructuring designed to alleviate perceived restrictions on the training of the skilled labour force.
Several existing Commonwealth programs are also designed to assist in raising the industry contribution to training.

Traineeships have been developed across a broad range of industries and occupations including the retail, finance, hospitality, tourism, construction, road transport (furniture removal) and manufacturing sectors. All parties to the traineeships make a significant contribution to the cost of training-

industry contribution is in the payment of the trainee's wage for the duration of the traineeship and the provision of structured on-the-job training, although employers receive a contribution towards the cost of training and wage on-cost.

Under the Innovative Training Projects component of the Skills Training Program, catalytic assistance is provided to industry for them to expand training infrastructure through the development and expansion of industry-based skills centres and the piloting of innovative approaches to training.

Conditions of funding include that the Commonwealth must be the minor partner in the establishment of skill centres, with the majority of costs being met by industry (possibly with State Government assistance) and that industry meet recurrent costs of the centre.

The Government has set aside $3m of the 1988 grant for equipment, for proposals involving industry contributions towards the purchase of TAFE equipment. The objectives of this joint venture initiative are to encourage-
TAFE to seek outside sources of equipment funds
industry and TAFE to have a closer working relationship for their mutual benefit.

(10) The Government's strategy for increasing industry's commitment to training outlined in (9) above will also encourage improved co-operation between industry and formal training providers. It is also likely that as a result of these initiatives, industry will provide substantially more training `in house' and develop its own training centres.

The Government has worked closely with industry and a number of higher education institutions to develop co-operative education courses in computer science. Industry has contributed staff, equipment and scholarships for students and has been involved in course design.

The pilot program is part of the Government Information Industry Strategy and a larger scheme under which 650 extra places will become available for technology related courses for the industry. The co-operative education concept lends itself to extension into other disciplines as well as information technology.

So far as Technical and Further Education is concerned, the responsibility for the management of facilities rests with State authorities and the question is, therefore, principally a matter for those authorities. However, in making arrangements with States for the provision of Commonwealth funding for TAFE, the States have been asked to provide undertakings to increase industry input and contribution to the operation of TAFE and to implement arrangements to enable TAFE colleges to retain revenue from entrepreneurial effort.

Under the Australian Traineeship System (ATS), individual traineeship packages are developed by tripartite Industry Working Groups (IWGs). As IWGs have representation from training providers (usually TAFE), industry has a major and direct input into the development of training curriculum.

Under the Skills Training Program (STP), a number of proposals have been received for funding joint TAFE/Industry skill centres with industry having management and control of the facility. TAFE are involved on tripartite committee oversighting implementation of a number of innovative training projects involving curriculum development. TAFE in other proposed projects will be involved in training provision.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Housing and Aged Care, upon notice, on 23 August 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many Commonwealth supported aged care hostels are there in Australia on a State by State basis.
(2) How many residents are there in those hostels.
(3) What proportion of those residents suffer from some form of dementia.
(4) Do all hostels have residents with dementia.
(5) Did the Government recently announce special service program grants for dementia, if so, (a) what was the basis of those grants and (b) how were hostels selected for those grants.
(6) How are those hostels which did not receive grants and which have residents suffering from dementia expected to provide care for their residents.
(7) Does the Government's fund program for aged care facilities take account of dementia and provide additional resources; if so, how does it do so.
(8) If dementia is not accounted for, why not.
(9) What is the value of the special service program grants on a per-capita basis.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (3) There is no data collected on the proportion of dementia sufferers in Commonwealth subsidised hostels.
(4) No. Some hostels do not accept dementia sufferers due to inadequate physical design of their facility or inability of staff to cope with residents suffering from a high degree of dementia.
(5) Yes. Estimated expenditure for 1988-89 is in the order of $7m. One hundred and eighty-four hostels received funding in 1987-88.

(a) Dementia grants are paid only in respect of persons who are residents of a hostel. Dementia residents are those assessed by an assessment team or medical practitioner as suffering from some form of dementia. The level of grant depends on the number of residents. Grants are available to meet the costs of the employment of staff to provide or extend special activities for dementia sufferers and items of equipment for activities. Staff training funds are allocated to State offices for disbursement upon application from organisations.
(b) Proposals are sought each year from eligible hostels for dementia grants and the selection is based on the relative need/merit of proposals and funds available.

(6), (7) and (8) Recurrent subsidies payable to organisations in respect of hostel residents are designed to take account of the level of assessed care needs (this includes the care needs of dementia sufferers). Subsidies are payable at two levels-hostel care subsidy ($2.10 per day) and personal care subsidy ($13.45 per day).
Payment of recurrent subsidies is governed by the provisions specified in the gazetted schedule of approval for accommodation services and personal care services.

Often aged persons suffering from dementia develop other disabilities or incur losses of function which necessitate nursing home admission. The recently introduced Resident Classification Instrument for nursing home admissions takes into account the particular service needs of such people and provides commensurate funding for nursing and personal care staff.
(9) The average dementia grant per capita for 1987-88 has been estimated at $6,734.25 per year or $18.45 per day. This includes the personal care services subsidy component.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 1 September 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many business migrants entered Australia in 1987-88.
(2) From which countries did they come.
(3) What is the total sum of foreign currency gained in 1987-88 from this scheme.
(4) What type of businesses have business migrants established or invested in.
(5) What proportion of those business ventures have proved successful.
(6) Is there any policing of business migrants once they have arrived in Australia to ensure that both they and their money remain here.

(7) What is their position should they invest in, or establish, a business that subsequently fails and causes them to lose their means of support and in such circumstances are they entitled to welfare payments and government handouts, or are they to be repatriated.

(8) What measures are being undertaken by the Government to ensure that business migrants who enter Australia with a qualifying minimum of $A500,000 do not remit their funds abroad once they have gained residency, and so recycle the same qualifying funds.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In 1987/88 the total number of settler arrivals under the Business Migration Program was 7,222. This figure includes 1,794 principal applicants.

(2) In 1987/88 business migrants from 43 different countries were accepted. Accounting for 83% of the total, the main countries, in order of magnitude, were: Hong Kong, Taiwan, Malaysia, United Kingdom, South Korea, Singapore, Japan, Fiji, Indonesia, West Germany, (see Table 1).

(3) In 1987/88 business migrants had transferred $A1018.1 million to Australia at time of visa issue. Reports by Australian banks suggest that additional funds are subsequently transferred to Australia by business migrants.

(4) To date my Department has relied on survey data to identify types of business ventures. The principal types of ventures identified are: import/export, wholesale, service, property development, manufacturing, tourism,

My Department is developing a system of identifying industries in which investment is intended, based on the Australian Standard Industrial Classification System codes which will be incorporated into Business Migration Program data collection.

(5) Survey data indicates it is reasonable to expect business migrants to take up to two years after arrival to establish a business venture. A significant group establish themselves within six months. A further survey examining the July 1984 to December 1987 arrivals is currently being prepared.

A new evaluation and monitoring system, introduced in June this year, will provide for data collection on 1987/88 arrivals but it would not be available for some time as it is tied to time of resident re-entry and citizenship applications.

(6) Business migrants have the same civil rights as other Australian residents and their activities are not ``policed'' (although their activities are now monitored more than any other category of migrant). Similarly, migrants who are accepted as spouses, or nominees of employers etc are not policed. The Government's re-entry policies are designed to maintain appropriate control on residence while allowing all migrants the opportunity to engage in necessary travel during their first three years in Australia. Business migrants in particular need this facility.
(7) Business migrants have the same entitlements to benefits as other Australian residents. They have the same right to approach my Department about repatriation and the same conditions apply.

The selection criteria for the Business Migration Program ensure that they are less likely to make calls on Government services than other types of migrants. They must have a successful business background and demonstrate sufficient skills and equity to ensure the viability of the enterprise. They are required to transfer to Australia for the purposes of engaging in a commercial enterprise of benefit to Australia money, capital or other assets of at least $500,000. In addition, they must transfer funds to cover settlement costs.

(8) There is no reason to believe there is any significant recycling of funds. Indeed, my Department has no evidence of any recycling of funds. Checks on the business background of applicants help to ensure that the funds transferred are generated by their own business activities. There are no special mechanisms to lock funds into specific investments and such mechanisms are not seen as desirable as they could result in funds being locked into passive investment. The program requires business migrants to engage directly in commercial enterprise.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business, upon notice, on 29 September 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Who are the members of the Australian Space Board and what are their periods of office.
(2) What is the requirement for a quorum for a meeting of the Space Board in the event of one or more members of the Board having a conflict of interest in addressing any particular matter.
(3) Will the report of the Joint Working Group into the possibility of a Cape York Space Port be made public: if so, when will it be made public.
(4) Who are the members of the Joint Working Group.
(5) What other inquiries or economic feasibility studies are being undertaken by the Board or his Department into the economic impact of the development of a Space Port at Cape York.
(6) What international science agreements are administered by the Australian Space Board or any sections of his Department.
(7) With which countries does Australia have science agreements and (a) what are the terms of those agreements and (b) when were they signed.
(8) What have been the practical results of the signing of science agreements.
(9) How many staff members are assigned to work in the Australian Space Office and what are the functions, qualifications and levels of those staff members.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Members of the Australian Space Board are: Mr R. D. Somervaille, am, (Chairman), Mr I. J. Bettison, Dr K. G. McCracken, Mr R. Wheeldon, Professor J. H. Carver, am, Dr B. S. Middleton.

All have been members of the Board since its formation in September 1986, with the exception of Dr Middleton who replaced Dr Hayman in October 1987. Members are invited to serve for an unspecified term.
(2) Four members or more form a quorum.

(3) The Joint Working Group (JWG) is in regular contact with the two consortia conducting feasibility studies on the spaceport for the purpose of briefing the respective Ministers and to help where possible in resolving any issues. The JWG is not planning at this stage to issue a report on the activities of the consortia.
(4) Members of the Joint Working Group are:
Dr B. S. Middleton, Executive Director, Australian Space Office, Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce;
Mr G. Sanderson, Director, Projects and Programs, Premier's Department, Queensland.
(5) The Australian Space Office has commissioned the National Institute of Economic and Industry Research to undertake a study on the national economic impact of the spaceport.

(6) The International Industry and Technology Branch of the Department administers the Bilateral Science and Technology Collaboration Program. This comprises seven treaty level Agreements and four Memorandums of Understanding on science and technology collaboration.

(7) Australia has treaty level science and technology collaboration agreements with the Federal Republic of Germany, India, Japan, Mexico, the People's Republic of China, the USA and the USSR. There are Memorandums of Understanding on Science and Technology Cooperation with Indonesia, Israel, Malaysia and Thailand.

The terms of all the treaty level agreements make similar provisions: they are aimed at encouraging scientific and technical cooperation between scientists and technologists in Australia and the partner country through collaborative research projects, joint workshops and seminars. They are also aimed at promoting links between research institutions in the partner countries. Provision is made for regular meetings of officials of the partner countries to review the operation of each agreement.
The Agreement between Australia and the USA Relating to Scientific and Technical Cooperation was signed in 1968. It was most recently renewed in 1985 for a further five years.

The Agreement between Australia and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics on Scientific-Technical Cooperation was signed in 1975. The agreement was set aside in 1979 following the Soviet incursion into Afghanistan, but was reactivated in 1985.

Agreement between the Government of Australia and the Government of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics on Co-operation in Space Research and the Use of Space for Peaceful Purposes was signed on 1 December 1987.
The Agreement between Australia and the Federal Republic of Germany on Scientific and Technological Cooperation was signed in 1976.
The Agreement between Australia and Japan on Cooperation in Research and Development in Science and Technology was signed in 1980.
The Agreement between the Government of Australia and the Government of the People's Republic of China on Cooperation in Science and Technology was signed in 1980.
The Agreement between Australia and India on Cooperation in the Fields of Science and Technology was signed in 1975. It was reaffirmed by the Prime Ministers of Australia and India in 1986.
The Basic Agreement between the Government of Australia and the Government of the United Mexican States on Scientific and Technological Cooperation was signed in 1981.

Funding for cooperation under the agreements covers travel and living cost expenses, workshop and seminar costs. In the agreements with the USA, the Federal Republic of Germany and Japan, the country sending the scientist pays all costs associated with the project. In the agreements with the USSR, China, India and Mexico, the sending side pays the international travel costs while the receiving side pays the living and internal travel costs. Costs of joint seminars and workshops are shared.

The four Memorandums of Understanding on Science and Technology Cooperation are very similar in their terms to the treaties but their non-legally binding nature means that they act as an umbrella under which cooperation can be fostered, rather than requiring a specific funded program as with the treaties.

(8) The Science and Technology agreements have been very successful in providing seed funding for collaboration between Australian and overseas scientists. In many cases the agreements have given access to facilities and analytical equipment not available in Australia and which would have been prohibitively expensive for Australia to acquire.

Several hundred collaborative projects have been supported since the first agreement was signed in 1968. The agreements have contributed significantly to building links between Australia and the partner countries in Science and Technology research, thus improving Australia's capabilities in a wide range of disciplines.
(9) Twenty seven staff are employed in the Australian Space Office:
Director, ASO 8, ASO 6, ASO 6, ASO 6, ASO 5, ASO 3, ASO 3, Senior Technical Officer.
Canberra Deep Space Communications Centre (See Note 1):
Director, Engineer class 5, Engineer class 4, Engineer class 4; Senior Technical Officer.
Note 1. These staff are funded by NASA to manage NASA tracking stations in Australia.
